Just because cohesion and agriculture have been our priorities for decades doesn’t mean that they are outdated. We need to continue to invest there, but of course we need to invest in digital, climate and so on. My last word is on timing. The budget is important, but it has become urgent as well. Let us work together to achieve, in the European Council in December, a common understanding on what we expect from Europe and what we expect from the budget. Let’s not start with small discussions on figures, because those would be divisive. Firstly, a political agreement on what we expect and then to put the money where our statements and our expectations are. Thank you very much. We are ready to work with you on this. (Applause)

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I’m glad that this morning we are speaking with a European Commission that has committed to make the European Green Deal its priority. But the European Green Deal should not remain a headline. It should become a reality that makes a positive difference in our citizens’ lives wherever they live, no matter how big or small their Member State is. Embarking on a serious decarbonisation programme that keeps at its core the transformation of our industries will only strengthen our competitiveness, and the European Green Deal should go beyond targets and revolutionise the way we do business and our industries. It should revolutionise the way we act, how we help our current workers acquire new skills, and how to educate our kids for the industries of the future. We have industries and businesses that are realising that transformation needs to happen and they are looking to our institutions for clear commitment. For the Socialists and Democrats, the Green New Deal is an opportunity to ensure a new economic model that puts employees and the most vulnerable people at the centre of our policies. It is an opportunity to enhance our relationships with neighbouring continents such as Africa, for example, to foster partnerships and provide cleaner and renewable energy. And it is our opportunity to protect the social well-being of all our citizens. We are ready to work with the European Commission, and we look forward to being partners in this transformation to concretely show to our citizens, wherever they are, that the EU project is very much alive and working.

name: Malik Azmani (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the EU faces huge challenges in the coming years. Some of them are threats but others are opportunities. We cannot stand still or choose not to act on these challenges. We need to renew Europe. The record high turnout during the European elections, already six months ago, shows us that our citizens have placed their confidence in us – in all of us. In return, they expect us to deliver concrete results. That is why the European Commission needs to start work as soon as possible so that we can start delivering on our promise for a strong European Union that works for our people. The task ahead is not a small one. We need to tackle climate change, ensure a stable economy, be innovative, the digital agenda, but also protect the rule of law, gain control on migration and provide safety and security in an unstable world, where we cannot always rely on our old allies. Therefore, I urge the new European Commission to start and to work together to renew Europe to deliver the results that we need for a prosperous new European future. Madam President—elect, together with your team – and I am proud to see your work on the composition of that team – I hope we can start together to work on a renewed Europe.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I say to the President-elect: thank you very much for your priorities. They sound like the right ones and we are willing to work with you on those priorities. But it is also clear that we have our concerns, and they have been elaborated before by Ska Keller. it is on the rule of law, the social dimension of our internal market and on the humane treatment of refugees in and outside the EU. They are our concerns, so that’s why we will not give you a blank cheque, but as Greens we will work with you on the Green Deal, on digitalisation, on making sure that in those communications – and on the Green Deal we can expect one in two weeks – we can deliver further, further on probably the great words that we will hear in two weeks. But it comes down to legislation to really change our way of life within the planetary boundaries. That’s where we are going to make sure that is the direction Europe is going in. And we are going to work on the actual laws that come later, and there we expect real action. One thing, for example: the climate law, next year will be the only and last chance where we can make our ambition higher before Paris really starts. Let’s use that momentum next year and we will work with you on that.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, both with Juncker and with Mrs Von der Leyen, the majority here in the European Parliament have placed a civil figure, the image of solidity and slightly dull greyness at the head of the European Commission. But appearances are deceiving. The dullness must hide the fact that Mrs Von der Leyen is at the head of a very left-wing, globalist, globalist, centralised and centralising project in the interest of and for the benefit of the multilateralist state religion. Mrs Von der Leyen is being put in the saddle here to take the reins and to cast the whip of further federalism in the European Union.  Mrs Von der Leyen, your project is contrary to the freedom of the various Peoples of Europe and we will therefore fight your otherwise shaky and rickety coalition from the future Member State of Flanders, courteously, but with full conviction.

name: Assita Kanko (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this is a make or break Commission. The UK is leaving, or trying to. Enlargement strategy has stalled, our European way of life is under pressure and Turkish troops continue to bite at the heels of our border management policy. Let’s face facts: confidence and trust in the EU is fading, reforms are needed. We all need this Commission to deliver. You will, therefore, need to work hard to unite this fractured Union and win majorities around your agenda, especially on important issues like protecting the European way of life, ensuring effective solutions on internal security, migration management and economy. And we must lead by example on human rights. We need to increase jobs, growth and trade and to protect our environment while ensuring Europe can remain competitive. It is no small undertaking, but I hope it can be achieved. It’s a great moment to have a female President of the Commission. Suffragette Alice Paul said: ‘there will never be a new world order until women are a part of it’. My hope is that you, Madam President, and your team will show us every day that you are the woman for the job and for the change and I look forward to working with you.

name: José Gusmão (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mrs Von der Leyen, this Commission does not respond to any of the problems of the European Union. Everything that's worse doesn't change and everything that changes changes changes for the worse. The Commission's only language for economic policy remains that of austerity and the choice for the vice-presidency of the economy is to confirm this continuity.  All the policies that would allow us to respond to the need to overcome the austerity paradigm are subalternized. Cohesion policy has a brutal planned cut that the new Commission has already said it supports. The Green New Deal has a portfolio, has a vice-president and has a commissioner who is making public statements asking for resources for its policies, policies which he has not yet taken care to present to us. The eurozone budget, on the other hand, is a mountain that has given birth to a rat, a small financial envelope that will serve to implement structural austerity reforms that the European Commission has not yet been able to impose on the Member States. This Commission will be adopted because the majority of Members of this House prefer a five-year political blockade to an institutional blockade of a few months. No enthusiasm, no hope, no change project can mobilize this House for its Commission.

name: Lucy Elizabeth Harris (NI).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for saying that she is a Remainer. Clarification is always very welcome, and can I just say that it is a devastating revelation and loss to the Brexit cause. (Laughs) The EU has warned that it’s going to take legal action against my country because we refused to name a Commissioner. But what’s the point? We’re leaving anyway, and two that we’ve already had – Kinnock and Mandelson – have used it as an opportunity to feather their nests to the tune of GBP 10 million. They are extreme EU federalists with no intention to stand up for their people, but merely to comply and feather their nests.  So we’re not bothering: a decision by my country which confirms that we are indeed leaving the European Union. And remember: if we’re causing you too much trouble, you can always kick us out prematurely. (Applause from certain quarters) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: President. –
text: Ms Harris, there are just two points. This may come as some surprise to you. I’m a remainer too. The second point is: will you accept a blue card from Mr Smith?

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I am grateful to Ms Harris for giving way. I would point out that it is a legal obligation – because the EU is a community based on justice and the rule of law – for the UK to appoint a Commissioner. The UK is flagrantly in breach because of our nihilistic, irresponsible government. As fellow MEPs of course we have our own rights and privileges. But, presumably you’re in favour of you yourself giving up your salary and allowances for the time that you’re here if you’re happy for us not to have a Commissioner?

name: Lucy Elizabeth Harris (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – Under UK law we also can’t do it during election period under purdah, so that’s one reason. And another reason is that we also have to answer to the British public. We don’t answer to the EU law, and we made that very clear in 2016 when we voted to leave the European Union, sir, but thank you very much.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Madam President, President Von der Leyen, we ask you to continue to work for a stronger, more united and safer Europe. Strong, so he grows up and creates a job. United Nations, so that from the rule of law we may face the nationalisms and populism that threaten it. And surely, to defend our external borders, fight terrorism and defend democracies in the world. But we also need a more useful Europe for all citizens. We call on the new Commission to be useful, so that young people have opportunities, so that entrepreneurs, small and large enterprises, continue to create jobs, because employment is the best social policy to leave no one behind. We're watching for legal immigration. And we must also be useful in addressing the demographic challenge of our old continent, taking care of our rural world and defending our agriculture, livestock and fishing. Let us continue to be ambitious in the fight against climate change to take care of our planet and, above all, lead the technological, innovative and digital revolution for a more competitive Europe. If we are useful, Europe will be closer and we will get people's Europe, the Europe of equality.  We need more Europe, with closer management and less bureaucracy. Only together will we continue to be the best space for peace, freedom, equality and progress in the world. I am convinced that the new Commission and its president will live up to it. They have the full support of the Spanish delegation of the People's Party.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Madam President, since the elections we have had a long and intense run to get to where we are today, and while I regret that we have failed to deliver on our promise on the Spitzenkandidaten, I’m proud that all key issues that my political family campaigned for are now part of this Commission’s works programme. And the S&D Group has not been shy with our concerns and demands and we have achieved key results.  In the field of foreign affairs, let me underline that the credibility of the EU as a global actor rests on our ability to have a successful policy at our very doorstep, but first it relies on our capacity to have our own house in order. We expect this Commission to take a very firm stance on protecting the rule of law both at home and abroad, and that implies a strong stance against the Putins, Erdoğans, Bolsonaros, Trumps and Viktor Orbáns of this world. My Group also urges this Commission to do everything in its power so that early next year a green light is given to the start of accession talks with North Macedonia and Albania. Commissioners, it is time to start the really important work: to deliver results on an ambitious plan to tackle the climate crisis while ensuring a fair transition; to deliver on sustainable development goals; to give better protection to workers; and to have a value-driven foreign policy. I’m fully confident that, under the leadership of our first Vice-President and lead candidate, Frans Timmermans, with a strong team of Social Democratic Commissioners, this Commission will stand close to its citizens, is ready to listen and is determined to address their hopes and concerns.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to the President-elect that she has my vote, but it’s a vote of pragmatism and not of passion – yet. There are several positives: there are many excellent – and even exceptional – personalities, the highest number of women and even a woman President, a Green Deal, and a focus on geopolitics. That’s all good. But I also have doubts, I’ll be honest.  Madam President—elect, your stubborn refusal to withdraw the controversial title of the migration portfolio shows that you are keener to placate Warsaw and Budapest than to work with progressive forces in Parliament – and no, the cosmetic change does not convince me. An independent Commission is crucial for a well-functioning EU, and so far you’ve been the candidate mainly of the national governments. But the 200 million Europeans who voted in May this year did not vote for the old intergovernmental Europe of backroom deals, but for a modern and transparent parliamentary democracy. You need to show if you belong to the old or the new Europe.  You have my vote. Now you must earn my enthusiasm. Good luck.  (Applause)

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President. Mrs Von der Leyen, despite having some excellent representatives, this group is not going to vote today on the College which is presenting to us today. There are some tolls that make it unworkable. The most visible and obvious, having left the neighborhood policy in the hands of Viktor Orbán, something we can pay dearly. But we are also concerned about demography portfolios or the European Way of Life portfolio, titles that indicate guidance for these portfolios that we are deeply concerned about as feminists and human rights defenders. I assure you that we will be particularly attentive to the steps taken in each of these portfolios. However, Mrs Von der Leyen, we have not come here to be mere spectators. There is nothing more useless than being in institutions in a testimonial way. We have come here to change things and to give a turn and a new impetus to the European project. Therefore, to the extent that we can work in areas such as the feminization of foreign policy, in responding seriously to the climate threat, in responding to the social urgencies of many of our fellow citizens, you will find in this parliamentary group a group of Members willing to work. But now it is up to you to show that there is political will to build those majority of progress in Europe in the social, environmental and feminist key we so desperately need.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen, many of you are cheering this new Commission. I would like to express a contrary opinion here. From my point of view, it has made a smooth false start. Why? Two things: firstly, we have a provision in the Lisbon Treaty that this Commission, consisting of 26 or 27 Commissioners, should be reduced by at least a third in order to be able to tackle all the stories more efficiently, more streamlinedly and also more labour-efficiently. That has been missed. This large number of Commissioners brings with it the problem of the fact that new regulations are constantly being devised and developed, because many people, who may not even be known in their home countries, have the approach of wanting to establish their own function. Secondly, no reference has been made to the fact that there is a gulf in Europe between those – the nomenklatura – who want more centralisation and those who want more looseness, who also want more national sovereignty. No answer has been given. But it would also be possible to do so if we finally renounce this flood of regulations and focus on what Europe really needs: more security at the borders and more prosperity. The continent should not be painted with more and more regulations.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Madam President, first of all I wanted to remember, to honor here the thirteen French soldiers killed in the struggle of civilization against Islamist terrorism.  Afterwards, Mrs Von der Leyen, I wanted to tell you that we are going to vote against your Commission, because we believe that you have entered into an ideological adventure which does not really represent the interests of the Europeans and the different European nations themselves; of the sectors that are currently very frightened because you have gotten yourself – as I say – into an adventure that has everyone very concerned: what you call the Green Deal right now.  It is a real fantasy, based on chimeras, based on supposed scientific postulates, which no one demonstrates—as we have seen right now—that it is demanding not only immense amounts of money, that they will mobilize here, to control nations more, to control individuals more and to control companies more, against freedom, but also enormous sacrifices to different nations and different sectors , which will then have no compensation.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, the new Commission is distinguished by the same reactionary materials that the European Union is made of, namely a commitment to the unpopular policy of flexible labour force, even cheaper to the minimum, the demolition of social security, crumbs in extreme poverty, the blow of trade union action, a mass file, widespread expulsions of refugees and migrants. At a time of anemic recovery and signs on the horizon of a new possible synchronised crisis, green funds and handsome subsidies for digital, large areas of group profitability are being promoted. This is in the midst of trade wars, contradictions within the European Union about attitudes towards the US, China and Russia, the outcome of Brexit, the intensity of militarisation.  Symbolic and essential is the fact that the former German Minister of War was chosen as head of the Commission. You have opened and closed your speech, Mrs von der Leyen, with anti-communism, showing your opponent, showing weakness and fear for the historical truth and the struggle of the peoples, which will strengthen against the European Union, capital and governments, and for their modern needs.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs von der Leyen, we will vote confidence in your Commission because we share the commitments it has made here on the centrality of the individual, on immigration, on flexibility, on the role of industry, on internal security, on digital identity, on the fight against cancer, on innovation and research, on relations with the United States. In short, we share a political and non-bureaucratic vision of the Union. However, we will ensure that commitments are turned into concrete choices, including in the union's next budget. Of course we are committed to the fight against climate change, but we must also be careful that industry is not penalised, that our agriculture is not penalised. Industry is crucial, as is the company, to creating new jobs. That is why we need a competition policy that is appropriate to the times, enabling our companies to compete not only at national level but also at global level. We need protection against unfair competition. Attention to the Silk Road, to the Chinese hegemonic strategy, which risks putting the entire production system in difficulty, with dumping, including environmental, including social and not only commercial dumping. Attention is also paid to the protection of agriculture, as I said. We cannot allow cuts in the common agricultural policy. Agriculture remains a fundamental instrument for protecting the environment and for protecting employment in our European Union. It is therefore an unsustainable role. With regard to immigration, too, we must pay attention to Africa because we must invest more, I believe, in a great Marshall Plan to enable that continent to grow and thus reduce migratory phenomena towards Europe. A final word on the protection of the rule of law. We cannot forget the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, we must continue to speak until we find out that they are the real sponsors, and we are, fortunately, close to the truth.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Today is an important day in Parliament. We are going to approve a Commission for the next five years, and it is a high-level goal that Europe should become the first climate-neutral continent. The Green Deal is so vital for us to take our responsibilities together and hand over a sustainable Europe and a sustainable world – including a more peaceful world – to our children and grandchildren. The climate change change is about no one being left behind. A fair distribution is needed. Efforts to create more jobs with good conditions in the EU must also be speeded up; especially for Europe's women, where a third lack their own job. Citizens' social rights must be strengthened in the Member States, and work must continue on the social pillar that all Member States support. We also need to find a solidarity and responsible migration policy together as soon as possible, and I know that Ylva Johansson is the woman who can do it. I also welcome the Commission's initiative to present both an equality union and a gender equality strategy. I look forward to working together to stand up for our democratic fundamental values, focus on improving for people and delivering on important issues.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, I am going to vote yes with conviction later. We have never had a Commission that is so ambitious in terms of climate. Who is so woman-friendly and led by a woman. It is so ambitious in terms of asylum and migration and defence. This commitment is based on innovation, digitisation and our economy. With Mr. Borrell, who is going to fight for Europe's place in the world. And with you. I am counting on you to support the conference on the future of Europe. That it is a conference without limits, which can think about many things, about what the future of Europe should look like. I think, Mrs Von der Leyen, that this is a very important signal to our citizens: that we have a conference on how Europe is going to work for our citizens in the future.  Mrs. Von der Leyen, you will not be surprised to find myself talking to you as an Amazonian.  I expect you to take the reins now. That you are pushing Europe, the horse of Europe, in the right direction. That you give legs, tight reins, and advance. Go for that own policy. That is what I expect from you and all your Commissioners in the coming years. And you know, if you do not, we are going to put the whip on it from Parliament. But you're going to do it with the legs and the tight rein.

name: Ivan David (ID).
text: – Madam President, looking at the European Commission, I have considerable doubts that it will work in accordance with the interests of the citizens of the European Union. If they're really interested in losing their identity and executing orders from a remote center. With the touching care of the environment, it suddenly doesn't matter to burn Brazil's forests and import beef halfway around the globe under the Mercosur treaty. I see the biggest problem in the future job of Commissioner Vera Jourová. These are supposed to be European values such as freedom, democracy, equality, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice. How is this associated with multiple differences between countries in agricultural subsidies or the announcement of cordon sanitaire against Members elected by otherwise like-minded citizens? Under various noble pretexts, censorship is introduced and divergent views are punished. I see the slow realization of terrifying visions from George Orwell's famous 1984 novel.

name: Matthew Patten (NI).
text: – Madam President, dear Ms von der Leyen, there are many things I disagree with you about on the creeping federalisation of the European Union towards a super state, and I’m really disappointed that, after 40 years’ membership of the European Union, we’ve failed to persuade you that Europe’s success depends on protecting the sovereignty of our Member States. But we are shortly to leave, and I wanted to let you know that, despite our differences, Europe has no greater friend than the UK. We recognise your priorities of climate change, economic competitiveness, migration, security and the rule of law, and you’ll find no greater ally than the UK to achieve our mutual goals in those areas.  The coming months will present many challenges as we seek to redefine our relationship. I hope that the EU will remember that a strong and free-trading UK has always been in the best interests of Europeans, as it is of British citizens. And speaking personally, in the short time I’ve been an MEP, I’ve really enjoyed the company, the passion, and the arguments with my fellow MEP colleagues. I look forward to working with you – and them – as we look for a better future for all our citizens. (Applause)

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President-in-Office, first of all let me greet you for the speech you have made, for the programme you have made, for the team you have set up, and let me also greet you for the inspiration alcapacity you have given to so many Europeans, and in particular to us who are here in this House. And so I can say, unlike my Dutch colleague, that she has my vote, but she is already counting on my enthusiasm. I would like to draw attention to this: we cannot accept a budget that is a smaller budget than the previous one, and in particular we have to look at cohesion policies, because there is now a threat to cohesion, and without cohesion there will be no European unity. I draw attention, for example, to the risk that there is now that, in order to do something that is fundamental – which is the fair transition fund – we divert EUR 5 billion from cohesion to this fund. New priorities now involve new funding. Cohesion policy should not be affected. Finally, let me have a word on the Conference on the Future of Europe. I ask that you seriously commit yourself to this plan, that we should be able to involve the citizens and that the Commission does not, as some colleagues have already done here today, this manoeuvre of having the conclusions drawn before even listening to the citizens and involving them in that same Conference. I believe that it will be a fundamental step for this Commission, but also for all the institutions, that we have a Conference of the Future of Europe with great success.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the British general election does not preclude sending a Commissioner to the Commission. It is a legal obligation and it is a matter of regret because sincere cooperation means that. That is why we are here and that is the spirit in which we should have continued. So you’re not legally complete and that is a fact. This Commission was part of a process in its building. That is why I’m proud of the progressive Commissioners and what they can achieve, but it was part of a process. Building a Green New Deal, a just transition to a low carbon economy, workers’ rights, equality, the horizontal discrimination directive: many of these have been characterised by delay, but delay because they were challenges, challenges that had to be overcome. So the process in building you was part of our groups’ wish to create a more progressive Commission. And so we vote, but I want to mention two things which I’ve spent my last 20 years on, and which the President-designate of the Commission mentioned. One was the 39 people in the lorry, the thousands of people who have lost their lives in the Mediterranean. There will be a pact on migration within days of this Commission taking office. This is a challenge because we have not got it right, and this is an extraordinary challenge for this new Commission because it is feeling the bad politics of the European Union. So I wish you all the very best with this, but it must be in line with our fundamental EU values of human rights and dignity. For the challenges of the future, the President-designate mentioned AI and having responsible data in the future. We don’t want China and the United States still doesn’t have GDPR, so it is up to the European Union. But dealing responsibly with data innovation, that is for the European Union. These are extraordinary challenges and I’m proud to have been part of this European Union which can deal with that.

name: Charles Goerens (Renew).
text: Madam President, there is no doubt that the members of the future Commission are quality actors. I am thinking of the Commissioner of my political family, my compatriot Nicolas Schmit, whose competence is not disputed by anyone, and many others. However, I cannot help but think of Sylvie Goulard, who has not demerited in any way but who, in my view, was abused by some during her parliamentary hearing. Of course, a parliamentary hearing is not a leisure time. Of course, in these circumstances, critical questions are not only desirable but absolutely indispensable. However, there is no justification for the frankly biased, hostile and even hateful attitude of some of the European Parliament's actors towards it, which culminated in the announcement 'We will kill her', an attitude which is not compatible with correct parliamentary behaviour. When a decision of this nature is made without respect or objectivity, one can stand in the way of an exceptional talent. I cannot accept the form in which this decision was taken by some of my colleagues.

name: Jaak Madison (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Unfortunately, it is impossible to support this Commission. Why? The Commission at issue lacks any democratic legitimacy. The President-elect, Mrs von der Leyen, was not even on the ballot paper for the EU election. Her appointment could also be discussed if she had been the leading candidate for this position. But she wasn't. It would also have been understandable if she had been best qualified. It is not. Under her leadership, the German Ministry of Defence was characterised by unprecedentedly poor performances and questionable external contracts. What will happen to Europe under their leadership? With this new President of the Commission, the future of Europe looks rather bleak. Unfortunately, this Commission does not have a realistic view of the future. It has now shifted its focus to climate hysteria and the creation of the United States of Europe. But the EU is not a federal state with Member States as municipalities, it is a voluntary association of sovereign states.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, unlike the previous speaker, I believe that this Commission should gain confidence. I thank the President for remembering the Velvet Revolution and Václav Havel in her opening speech.  After today's approval, the new Commission will finally be able to take on its role and we can start working on the tasks ahead. I will now speak as coordinator of my faction for the Committee on Culture and Education. I very much appreciate the fact that the President of the Commission has met our request, as well as that of the professional public, and added the words 'culture, education and research' to Commissioner Gabriel's portfolio name.  I believe that the Commission will also support sport as an important tool for improving health and social inclusion. Since this word is not in the portfolio, I would ask my colleagues to support the creation of an intergroup for sport so that this intergroup can work and promote sport within the European Parliament. In this context, I would like to call on the Commission to support the triple budget for the Erasmus programme. It is a programme that has high added value, which helps teachers and pupils to improve their skills, their experience and has great added value in their European experience. It is a programme that allows for inclusion, but it will only be better if the budget increases, so it is important. I also expect us to start the Solidarity Corps programme, which is very important for the young generation.

name: Andrius Kubilius (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate President von der Leyen on what she has done up till now and on what she is going to do. Ms von der Leyen, as a Lithuanian and as a human being with some political experience, I simply trust you. I will not try to give you any more political advice – you have had a lot of that. You know very well what you will need to accomplish. This will be a huge task. Perhaps, during the next five years, there will be more challenging days compared with this day. I would simply like to wish you not to lose your personal motivation, your energy and your leadership skills, even in the most difficult circumstances. From my own experience of being Prime Minister during the crisis, I know how difficult it can be, and I simply share the hope that this House will be a constructive partner to you personally, and to your Commission, despite our political differences.  Let’s get back to the serious job. Let’s  leave simple and primitive political infights behind. Good luck! (Applause)

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, President of the new European Commission, our vote today is a vote of confidence. It is a vote of confidence in the green agreement that can be the reason for the change in our economy and life in the European Union. All we have to do is agree here that we need brave funding, private sector involvement and encouragement with all the instruments available to us for innovation.  Along with europe going forward, which will be the first continent with a zero carbon footprint in 2050, there is also a Europe that depends on coal and must not be left behind. The thousands of families in the forty-one coal-dependent regions in Western Macedonia, Megalopolis, expect you today to be supported, to have the assurance that they will have many sustainable jobs to which they can respond. A fair transition, based on the Fair Transition Fund, should be at the top of your agenda.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D).
text: – Madam President! I will support the entire Commission team, although I do not agree with the overall composition. Every month of the Commission's failure to work is a lost month for both the European Union and Slovenia. I would like the Commission to work primarily for the common good and to keep all the promises it has made in the European Parliament. In particular, I consider the following challenges to be important: first of all, transformation, and this green, social and digital, which is combined together with a just and solidarity transition to it. It is important to work on greater integration for the best of all people and human rights, a European strategy for sustainable development, common technological progress and its own infrastructure. Finally, to the very enlargement to the Western Balkans, and also to play the geopolitical bastion of multilateralism and the rule of international law.

name: Martin Horwood (Renew).
text: – Madam President, President von der Leyen, thank you for your declaration that you are a remainer. I am too, and so are tens of millions of Britons who will warmly welcome your words. Now we’ve completed a thorough process of democratic scrutiny, I welcome the opportunity to vote for the Commission today and see it get down to work on the huge issues that face our continent: climate change, trade wars, exploitation, injustice and discrimination. But can I say that I, too, am embarrassed and saddened that the United Kingdom has broken EU rules, and so far failed to nominate a Commissioner? While 27 other countries compete for portfolios and put their brightest and best forward to serve all of Europe, our government has chosen to leave its seat at the table empty. This must be one of the first examples in world history of a nation working hard for less influence, shouting for a smaller voice, lobbying to be silent. I very much hope that a new British Government will show much more sense.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the news brought by the new composition of the European Commission is not limited to new faces and more women, but we are witnessing a complete organisational overhaul. The new names and competences of individual portfolios are quite confusing and I am sure that they will not lead to efficiency gains. The commission's former technocratic set-up, which had its flaws but served a purpose, has been replaced by a rather ideologised new structure. Although it has commissioners from different groups in its ranks, such a Commission looks less and less like the executor of what has been agreed between Member States and increasingly as a structure with its own political agenda. Mrs von der Leyen, you get my vote out of sheer pragmatism and I sincerely hope that soon you will pleasantly and positively surprise me.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Madam Von der Leyen, by its composition, by its political programme, this is a Commission chosen and mandated by those who command the European Union to defend their interests, a Commission that the great powers can count on to defend and deepen their instruments of dominance – from the single market to the euro – at the expense of the growing sacrifice of the countries facing greater difficulties. A Commission in which the promiscuity between political power and economic power, big capital, large economic and financial groups that have a direct seat in Berlaymont, is in sight. A Commission that takes on a secondary and subversion of cohesion policy, associating it with so-called structural reforms, which have not served anything other than destroying public services and sow precariousness at work and in life. A Commission that has taken on a vision and own conceptions of the far right, as seen in the distribution that was made of the portfolios. A Commission that demonstrates that, after all, the great coalition between the right and the social is very much alive—democracy that the Greens now want... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, both personally and politically I am delighted to support President von der Leyen, and indeed the college, and I look forward to working with them over the next four years – especially my colleague from Ireland,  Commissioner Hogan. Ms von der Leyen, I saw how you tried to build support for your candidacy – and especially how you bent over backwards to get the support of the Greens, who make up less than 10% of Parliament, promising them a new green deal. Given that they fail to support you, that they may not support the College of Commissioners today, and that they may not be happy with whatever you come forward with in the New Green Deal, saying that it is not ambitious enough, would you and Mr Timmermans consider changing the title to what it actually is, or will be: ‘an enhanced climate change strategy for Europe’. Because all sides of the House here are committed to combating climate change: no one Group has ownership of it, and I think calling it an ‘enhanced climate change strategy’ would be sensible.

name: Pedro Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Madam President of the European Commission, we really need to get to work. You will have the support of this political group because you have made our proposals and because you have some of our best on your team. But a good program or speech will be nothing more than beautiful words if it is not implemented without excuses and with sufficient resources.  It is time to unite around the future of Europe. CO2 emissions do not wait for our hesitations, as we have seen in fires and floods across Europe. China and the United States appreciate our hesitation in leading digitization. The poorest in Europe and those who die in the Mediterranean cannot cross the sea of indifference alone. That's why it's time to act. I am counting on this Parliament to take the initiative, we are counting on you to build bridges with and within the Council. We have to be up to the wishes of our citizens.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the Basque Nationalist Party supports the most joint European Commission in history. We need you to manage in women, to show citizens that our Union is based on values, not interests, with a strong industrial policy that integrates the productive sectors in the transition from our productive model to the circular economy. This is how the climate emergency must be addressed, along with integrated, intelligent and sustainable mobility. To bet on sustainability is also to subordinate the financial economy to the productive economy, to achieve Union-wide social protection standards based on the principle of decent living, an income guarantee of income and a human immigration policy that has cities and regions, which they integrate and welcome. We also expect a definitive impetus to the instrument to control the quality of the rule of law, the best response to the ultras who want to return to the past and threaten democracy. More democracy, politics with capital letters, dialogue, empathy, agreements, humanity: this is Paco Gambús, partner of coalition and seat, a great person. Goian bego. Rest in peace.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, I will vote against the new Commission and its programme, because I believe that the objectives you have set cannot be achieved with a budget of only 1% of European GDP. Because I disagree with the great cuts that the Commission is making to social and regional cohesion policies and to the common agricultural policy. Because I find it shameful that the European Union is paralyzed and cannot give a European answer based on humanity and the rule of law on the refugee issue. Because I do not want the Commission to be held hostage by Mr Orbán and Mr Salvini. And because I believe that we need more ambitious targets both to tackle climate change and to tackle corruption and to tackle opacity.  That is why the eurogroup on the left will vote against the new Commission and have constructive, strict opposition for five years.

name: Ljudmila Novak (PPE).
text: – Dear Madam President, Honourable Commissioners. Sincere congratulations on an excellent presentation of your programme. I am also pleased that half of the team is women, because I am convinced that the work is more successful when men and women are involved in the work. You have also highlighted the right priorities: climate change, digitalisation, innovation, health, safety. All of this is important. And also that your objectives, the measures, must be supported by a budget, because only then will we achieve these objectives much more easily and effectively. But what impresses me most is that you put at the heart of your policies of man, of man with his own needs. And people all over Europe have the same needs: we want security, peace, cooperation. These are the values that make Europe ... (The Presiding Speaker takes the floor)

name: Leszek Miller (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Last year, the European Commission presented two draft directives aimed at establishing a revenue tax for the provision of certain digital services. Mrs von der Leyen also mentioned the need for a fair digital tax. I would like to warmly support you in this regard and wish you stubbornness and consistency, because this is necessary to do. Unfortunately, the work in the European Council shows how difficult the digital tax is, how many opponents it has and what resistance it faces. But even more so, Madam President, I wish you stubbornness, consistency, and I hope that you will not withdraw from this intention.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Honourable Madam President, Honourable Mrs von der Leyen, honourable team. You have my support. Congratulations on a competent, balanced team. You have presented and addressed the real problems we face, from climate change, migration, digitalisation, health, demographic problems. And what I am particularly pleased to see is that you want to solve problems in such a way as to create new opportunities. This is a guarantee that Europe will continue to be the most beautiful continent, a continent on which life will be highest and where people will be happy to feel and stay and also develop this beautiful continent. I am pleased that you are supporting the enlargement of the European Union to the Western Balkans. I think it is a necessity that we must do everything to democratize these countries, while also helping them in the development backlog. However, the focus is also on demographic problems, and with the Smart Villages project, I will also try to help find solutions. For specifically (indidiciable words) and ... (The Speaker takes the floor.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President invested, I want to announce from the outset that I voted for you, I gave you a blank check, I listened carefully to what you said today. You have a lot of questions to answer, and I would have liked you to focus on a united Europe. We have three more states that are not in Schengen, we have resolutions of Parliament. My country for 12 years has been a member of the European Union, but it is not in Schengen. I would have liked you to respond to things that are happening and are negative. We don't have to put the mat over the trash. We have big problems, with acts of terrorism, with stolen children, with violence of women. What solutions do we find here? With interference in the elections and yes, you have been very hesitant in the formation of the Commission and this has diminished from the trust that we have had in you. You need to regain your confidence. Today's vote is, in particular, a vote of conjuncture and trust, of access to trust.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Andrus Ansip (Renew)
text: Writing. – It is regrettable that the new Commission was not able to start work in due time, i.e. on 1 November. The European Parliament is known to have no right to take legislative initiatives, the draft is drawn up by the European Commission. If there is no new commission, there are no bills, so there is no full application in the new Parliament. Certainly, the postponement of the Commission's recruitment process will not have a positive impact on the European economy. In addition, it is deeply regrettable that for five months there has been no Commissioner in the European Commission from Estonia and Romania. Commissioners represent the interests of Europe as a whole, not just their own country. However, under the Treaties, the Commission makes the best decisions when there are commissioners from all Member States. It is useful for Estonia and the whole of the European Union to start a new Commission as soon as possible.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to congratulate the new President of the Commission and her efforts in shaping the commission's new composition. You take over the leadership of the Commission when there are many unresolved problems ahead of us, and at the same time many new challenges that require urgent solutions. European citizens are very encouraging towards you and expect to respond adequately to their expectations. And there are many of them – increasing poverty among workers, persistent high youth unemployment, unjustifiably high numbers of children in poverty. There is also a continuing structural problem of gender equality, which is manifested by lower women's wages and the threat of poverty in retirement, and many others. I very much hope, honourable President, that this Commission will be able to strike a balance between economic interests and the priorities of a social Europe. Over the next five years, we expect the full implementation of the social pillar in the EU Member States and a much more active role for the Commission in the implementation process. Mr President, only a socially strong and responsible Europe can unite the faith and trust of our citizens in the European Union and be able to unite in response to new global challenges such as migration, climate change, the transition to a clean economy and many others.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – I am delighted that the New European Commission's College of Commissioners is standing before us and that today we can finally vote on their election. I would like to thank Mrs Von der Leyen in particular for the fact that culture and education have been included in the name of Mariya Gabriel's portfolio, as we have asked many times here in the European Parliament. I am pleased that Hungary Commissioner has been given a key portfolio such as enlargement and neighbourhood policy. I trust that the new European Commission will pay more attention to the problems of the Hungarian community in Transcarpathia and that, in the dialogue with Ukraine, they will also be able to achieve respect for minority rights and equal, non-discriminatory educational and linguistic opportunities.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D)
text: Writing. – After five months of gruelling negotiations and hearings, we voted today with the new European Commission. The Socialists and Democrats have nine Commissioners in the new college. I am convinced that they will act for the good of the people and of our planet and leave a positive mark in their areas that are crucial for the future: ensuring a welfare state and a just society, strengthening democracy, the Sustainable Development Goals, gender equality, a new migration deal, a fairness fund. A great friend of Slovenia first vice-president Timmermans takes on the care of all generations and the planet's most important task - combating climate change and a just transition to a carbon-free society.  We have entered the campaign for elections to the European Parliament with a sincere desire to change the political, economic and social situation of our continent. We fought for the progressive left - left - green alliance, for a turn towards development, solidarity, the fight against inequality, for putting environmental protection at the heart of all Union policies.  I am also determined to work in advance with the new Commission by delivering on the promises and commitments I have made to the people: for a European minimum income standard, for a European minimum income standard, a ban on the import of goods made with child labour, the rule of law, democracy and media freedom, the enlargement of the Union to the Western Balkans, and, above all, for the dignity of all European women and Europeans.

name: Alexis Georgoulis (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Being sceptical about the College of the European Commission I decided to abstain from the vote. Some Commissioner-designates still face issues with their conflicts of interest. However, Europe requires an urgent action and cannot remain for long without guidance. The request I sent in the form of a letter to the President of the Commission regarding the portfolio of the Commissioners responsible for culture and education, was not answered. My firm belief is that culture and education should be prioritized. A priority mirrored not only in the titles of the portfolios but also in the policymaking of the relevant Directorate-General. Our stance and fight now moves to the different proposals and files to arrive to the Parliament. As a House, we should make sure to exercise our right of scrutiny as efficiently as possible holding it accountable at every occasion. The new Commission nonetheless, represents a much more diverse setting than previous colleges and I look forward to constructively engage with the relevant Commissioners to serve all the people in the Union without discrimination.

name: Enikő Győri (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Hungarian people look on the new Commission with confidence. I hope they're not disappointed. President Ursula von der Leyen promised courageous action. I wish that to be the case. I ask you to focus on meat-cutting issues instead of voicing ideological battles and slogans that go nowhere. Step out of current fashion topics and add content to your every move. It's the only way he's going to be able to withstand the pressure from the left and make irresponsible decisions. It's the only way he's going to be able to enforce the founding contracts. Be under no illusions: many will come up with ideas that would strike a balance between the EU institutions and policies.  In accordance with everything, I ask you to respect the nations, member states, and constitutional identities that under the foundation of the Union. Because we're 27-28 equal, but we're not the same. Be sensitive to the fact that citizens in some places are susceptible to something else. They have different situations, whether it is the transition to a green economy, migration or the norms of social coexistence. Accept that we can think of things differently. Respect what falls within our sovereignty, but act on matters of common competence. Do not sacrifice European agriculture and industry on the altar of climate policy. Instead, find a balance between sustainability and finance. With this attitude, it will be able to overcome the east-west fault line, which has become much stronger than before.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the new European Commission and I hope that the strong political mandate will allow President Ursula von der Leyen to deliver what our citizens expect. Higher turnout in May European elections means that the expectations of citizens are also higher. I am aware that the task will not be easy. EC is expected to deliver good results in traditional areas as cohesion policy, new priorities as digital market, artificial intelligence and fighting climate change, but especially to protect social rights. For all this EC will need sufficient financial resources, so it is of utmost importance to have a balanced MFF focused on the implementation of all priorities mentioned above. A transition to greener economy based on new technologies and artificial intelligence will also require enormous resources in order to be implemented properly. The countries dependent in energy resourcing on fossil fuels and nuclear will need to get substantial financial assistance from the EU if they want to be successful in satisfying the climate goals. Taking into account the strong mandate I expect the EC to act and effectively deliver in line with the ambitious priorities in order to meet the expectations of the citizens.

name: Πέτρος Κόκκαλης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – European citizens demand projects, not words, for the drastic resolution of serious problems, and after the long democratic process we must support the Commission in its work. Frans Timmermans' leadership is a guarantee of an immediate, effective and fair transition to a climate security world. I believe that the European Green Pact marks the beginning of the end of the hegemony of neoliberal dogma and the beginning of a progressive human-centred policy.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. – On key issues concerning the EU there is silence, such as dealing with expansionist Turkey. The unanimous decision of the European Council imposing measures against Turkey does not allow silence. Nor is it simply a matter of EU solidarity with one of its Member States, the Republic of Cyprus. It is about how we deal with the brutal violation of international and European law, which is an existential issue for the EU and concerns the 500 million European citizens. Moreover, it is about how we move towards the EU's strategic autonomy in the international environment in the future. Today we are voting for the College of Commissioners, including several notable members, some of whom I have worked with and have a personal understanding of their leadership skills. By a positive vote we provide a time credit so that with the necessary will the Commission's commitments can be implemented, such as in economic matters with the completion of the Banking Union through a pan-European deposit guarantee, in society and in the hot issues of the environment. These are issues on which determination is needed, and we will monitor closely and constructively. However, personally, I will not hesitate to attack you strongly if you do not respond in practice - apart from words - to those principles that unite us and are in the best interests of the EU.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The College of Commissioners and the programme presented by the President-elect of the Commission is the result of an institutional scrutiny process in which the European Parliament has taken on an active and fundamental role. The action plan and the proposed team to implement it resulted from political commitments made to political forces that wanted to focus on institutional soundness at a time of enormous challenge for the future of the European Union. In particular, I would like to point out the progressive pillars included in the programme in areas such as combating climate change, the fair energy transition, the digital transition at the service of people and the reduction of inequalities and the attention paid to policies of proximity, convergence and cohesion, and which result from proposals from the S&D Group. The key issue for success in implementing the programme is its funding. To be consistent with the ambition of its programme, the new Commission must be in solidarity with the European Parliament in order to achieve a Multiannual Financing Programme 2021–2027 that ensures the combined focus on cohesion, convergence and innovation, consolidating the European project and its affirmation in a changing world.

name: Presidente. –
text: First of all, we have the pleasure of welcoming delegates from the National Diet, the House of Representatives and the House of Councillors of Japan to the official gallery. I am here for the EU-Japan interparliamentary meeting. The delegation is led and chaired for the Diet by Mr Onodera, Member of the House of Representatives. It is an honour to welcome our friends to Strasbourg. I am also pleased to welcome eighty pupils to the official gallery accompanied by their teachers who have come to the European Parliament to present their declaration on the rights of the planet. Welcome guys! We thank them and we are happy to welcome them to the European Parliament. * * * *

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two days ago, thirteen French soldiers were killed in a counter-terrorism operation and this Parliament did not have the opportunity to honour their sacrifice with a minute's silence. I therefore propose to you, Mr President, to observe a minute's silence and that all our colleagues stand up for our soldiers who have sacrificed themselves in Mali.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mrs Jadot, perhaps you were not here yesterday when we greeted the soldiers who fell in Mali. Perhaps he was distracted or perhaps not present, but this House has already paid tribute to the soldiers who have fallen in Mali. No, I don't give you the floor. To your distraction, since this is a common feeling of all Members, I invite you to give a minute's silence. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Presidente. –
text: Let us begin with the vote on the election of the Commission. I would like to inform you that the votes will be preceded by a round of speeches by the political groups in reverse order.

name: Claire Fox (NI).
text: – Mr President, my fellow MEPs, let’s be honest with our voters at home. This process is a sham. We are being used as a stage army marched out today to rubber-stamp a thoroughly anti-democratic imposition of a top-down power at Commission level. This Parliament is no more than a faux-democratic charade used to give a veneer of legitimacy to an illegitimate decision-making process. We may salve our consciences by rejecting a few bad eggs at bogus committee hearings, but the truth is all we can do is accept or reject from a bunch of pre-selected candidates, with no real choice. You can heckle as much as you want, but I’m finishing. This hypocrisy is summed up for me by that gigantic poster of Ursula von der Leyen outside the Parliament in Brussels. It is frankly distasteful Orwellian propaganda. It reads: ‘In fair and free elections the power of the people determines the people in power’. That is true in national democracies but it is a flagrant lie, fake news and disinformation in relation to the Commission. Ms von der Leyen herself was not elevated to a position of power due to people power. The only power on display in her election was a behind-the-scenes cabal, which pushed her forward as a last-minute compromise candidate. And although she only scraped through, she now has the power to dictate the priorities of Europe. She has the power to impose her agenda on millions of European citizens, whether they like it or not. From the Commission’s ambition for a Green New Deal, for deeper monetary integration or austerity, or appointing Josep Borrell, who endorses qualified majority voting on foreign policy that strips nation states of the right to determine their own foreign policy. This federalism steals power from the people and is a naked power grab from the demos to technocrats in the Commission, and we’re expected to nod it through. (Protests) In the UK, we’re mid general election. Voters will directly vote on who they will loan their authority to, yet that... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's vote is not a vote like any other, it is a major vote, perhaps the vote of the century to face the two greatest challenges of our time: the climate catastrophe and the crisis of inequality, two issues that cannot be accommodated by vague or contradictory commitments. However, at the end of this sequence of auditions, it is clear that we remain hungry. From an ethical point of view first, three candidate commissioners have been dismissed for conflict of interest, and serious doubts remain about the independence of other members of the Commission. On the substance, there are of course promises to be welcomed, such as the minimum wage, the right to commit, the right of initiative of parliamentarians or the prospect of a major plan to insulate buildings. On all these issues, we will be vigilant allies in forming majorities of social progress. However, beyond these few advances, you remain clinging to the dogmas responsible for today's social, democratic and ecological crises. How can we aim for a green pact while pursuing climate-friendly free trade agreements? How can we combat tax evasion by protecting, within it, among the worst tax havens in the world? How can we think of a humanist policy by refusing a welcome worthy of exiles? Finally, how can we give hope to the peoples of Europe by continuing to impose on them the shackles of austerity? You can't be both firefighters and arsonists. The fire threatens everywhere, the European Union is now playing its survival, as citizens' distrust of the institutions has already exceeded the alert threshold. Faced with these challenges, people and the planet deserve better. People and the planet deserve a truly ambitious new green pact that creates hundreds of thousands of jobs by changing our agricultural systems, our industrial practices, our consumption patterns and our means of transport. People and the world deserve fiscal justice and end the impunity of multinationals that do not pay their fair share of taxes. People and the planet deserve a civilian body of rescue at sea, not a commissioner for the promotion of the European way of life who will turn a blind eye to the dead in the Mediterranean. People and the planet finally deserve better public services and social protections to lift the 113 million Europeans out of extreme poverty. Wouldn't this program be a thousand times more exciting for our future than yet another project, certainly with a renewed package, but worn down to the rope? As you will have understood, Mrs von der Leyen, our group of the European Unitarian Left is not ready, under these conditions, to entrust you with the reins of the European Union. People and the planet deserve much better.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to Ms von der Leyen that, Madam President, your Commission is a chance for a new beginning, and we hope there will be a new beginning. My Group will support you in many things. We will definitely support you in finding a compromise on the budget. We will support you in the opening up of the single market in services, in finding a lasting solution to migration and in implementing ambitious climate plans, but let me emphasise we will give full support to the communities whose livelihoods are threatened by the absurd ramping-up of climate ambitions. Please keep in mind that there is not, and there never will be, an EU nation. The EU is made up of 26 (or 28, if you will) sovereign countries, and no two countries are the same. Do not try to take away power from Member States by removing the rights of veto. Remember that the institution that sets the EU’s agenda is the European Council, not the European Parliament. Please do not continue the previous Commission’s practice of violating the letter and the spirit of the Treaties to enforce the process of integration. Despite what you hear in this Chamber or in meeting rooms in Brussels, there is a completely different view of what the EU is or what the EU should and shouldn’t be in communities across our Member States, so please let this be about evidence-based policy, not policy-based evidence. Ms von der Leyen, good luck.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs von der Leyen, finally, after months of quarrels and squabbles between the different souls that make up this majority, we have a Commission. Unfortunately, at the time of the greatest crisis that the European institutions are experiencing, we will have the weakest Commission, a Commission that has already been born lame and which, from its words or from what it has promised in these five months, also looks like a blind Commission, a Commission that has not understood the message of the European citizens and that refuses to propose a radically different approach to what are today the problems of our citizens. You spoke in your speech today about gender balance, you spoke of a green new deal, but unfortunately what the citizens of Europe think about in the morning when they wake up is not whether the European Commission has a gender balance, they think about how to get to the end of the month, they think about how to find work, they think about how to support their wages. And even on the green new deal your approach seems very ideological and we would not want this to lead to a further competitive disadvantage for our companies. Europe has already done so much today in terms of reducing emissions, it is others outside who have to do their job. We would not like your measures on this issue to carry a further burden on our businesses and to carry a further burden on our economies. I have not heard of the very important elements. We know of the threats to our competitiveness coming from outside, but I have not heard any proposals on how to correct the functioning of our internal market, I have not heard of the social and wage dumping taking place within the Union, I have not heard of fiscal dumping and deindustrialisation, which are processes taking place within the Union because of the distortions of our internal market. This group will proudly say no today to those who, through its insemo union, really want to destroy Europe. My suggestion is: get back involved, understand the mistakes of the policies you have pursued in the past and make a change of gear, which is what the citizens of Europe are asking for, otherwise Europe will unfortunately have no future.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the new Commission takes office at a time when the climate emergency doesn’t leave us much time to act. We’re happy to see that climate and environmental issues are a key priority for the new Commission and, by the way, also a key priority for more than 90% of the European population. However, we’re not so sure that the headlines will be followed by concrete action because if the Commission, as it has announced, does not change its agricultural and trade policy, then any climate measure will remain half—hearted. We are also happy to see that more women than ever are part of the Commission, even though it’s curious to see that some governments couldn’t find any women in their country. So, more work needs to be done to ensure a gender balance and also an overall better representation of European society in the Commission.  We have found in the hearings some very good candidates, but also some that made us have doubts – doubts on conflict of interest and how serious you are on European values, on the rule of law and on women’s rights. Madam President—elect, we will not support a Commission that is not clear on those issues. But be sure that, whenever you take an initiative that protects the climate, that strengthens a social Europe and that enhances the rule of law, we are more than ready to support you. But we will also point out when we think that the Commission is taking a wrong turn or is being too timid. Europe needs decisive action now and we hope that you will feel the courage and the strength to push for change, to stand up against the Council when needed, and to base your work on European values, such as human rights for all and on the rule of law. We want you to act because it’s high time and that’s why we don’t give you a red card, even though we have pointed out all of those problems I’ve mentioned today at various times and we haven’t seen them addressed.  But we also don’t want to give you a blank cheque either and that’s why our group has decided to abstain today as a head start in terms of trust that we hope will be justified. We’re looking forward to a good cooperation with you and we wish you and your College all the strength, all the courage and energy that it takes not just to hold our continent together, but to bring it forward.  (Applause)

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam President, there are many things on which this Commission will have to demonstrate its determination, its effectiveness and its ability to convince Member States and citizens that they have every reason to believe in its plans. We must, however, recognise that Europe has never had a Commission with such a high level of ambition for the environment and digital, with an angle of attack that seems effective and promising. We have never had a Commission that applies gender equality in this way, since gender equality is indeed important to all of us, since equality also means giving everyone the opportunity to express themselves. We have never had a Commission committed to promoting the rule of law and protecting individual freedoms. We have never had such a dialogue to build a political agenda together. Parliament has put its stamp on this programme. Our group will therefore support your Commission, Madam President. However, I would like to say that it will not be a blank cheque. I hope that all those who have made the environment, equality and the rule of law their standard will do the same and assume their responsibility rather than simply expressing wishes. For the programme to be implemented, we here in Parliament must build a clear, honest and trust-based partnership, since without trust between us there will be no results, and without the prospect of results, Renew will not be able to be part of it. We will therefore be very vigilant about the proposals that will be put forward. Each Commissioner has a key role in restoring the envy of Europe, with a vision, ambition and passion for Europe. From east to west, from north to south, we all have a clear mission here to re-enchant the European project and we will not achieve it with great declarations or only good promises, but with facts and measures that will make Europe concrete and useful in the daily lives of our citizens. It is for such a Commission that we will vote, Madam President.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, in May this year European citizenship gave us a very clear message: they want Europe, but a different Europe, a transformed Europe, a Europe that will once again be that space of opportunity.  The Socialist Group is very clear about our work over the next five years. We are going to work for a more environmental Europe, for a more feminist Europe, for a more social Europe. And we hope that the Commission will also act responsibly.  We hope you act bravely. We will even allow them to make a mistake; what we will never allow is for them to resign themselves, is that they are immobile, that they are not able to meet the challenges and challenges that Europe needs. Therefore, we will be vigilant; we're going to be engaged; we're going to cooperate; let's control. But I am sure that we have five years of intense work ahead of us to restore hope to the citizens outside this Parliament in the project that European men and women expect from us.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the We live in a time when extreme positions are popular and widespread on social media. That is why the presentation of Ursula von der Leyen today is particularly beneficial: to seek balance, to practice coexistence, to put the offer on the table, to work together for this continent. She has presented us today with a strong team that wants to tackle, that is motivated, and today we have the chance to give this team a democratic mandate. The Commissioners have taken office through their Member States, through the Council. But they will successfully leave office, together with Parliament. They need us to support them, to build a partnership between Parliament and the Commission at the end of the day and to work together for this united Europe. That is the responsibility we have. And when I hear in the final round now how leftists and, unfortunately, many right-wingers in this House are already agitating against the new Commission and are again launching attacks and denying themselves responsibility, then the best answer we can give today is a strong 'yes' to this Commission. Let's start to deliver, let's deliver a strong and united European Union.

name: Presidente. –
text: We shall now proceed to the vote. I would like to inform you that, exceptionally, explanations of vote are postponed until tomorrow. I would remind you that explanations of vote may also be submitted in writing. Ladies and gentlemen, pursuant to Rule 125 of the Rules of Procedure, Parliament shall elect or reject the Commission by a majority of the votes cast by roll call. After the vote, I shall announce the results of the votes. If the Commission receives a majority of the votes cast, I will sign the letter of transmission announcing Parliament's approval, hand it over to the President of the Commission and inform the Council there of it. On this basis, the European Council will officially appoint the Commission. (Election of the Roll-Call Committee) Approved by 461 votes to 157 with 89 abstentions. (Loud and sustained applause) Before signing the act of appointment, I would like to say to parliament as a whole, to the Commission and to the Council that we are very proud of the work that the European Parliament has done. It has been a democratic, serious and transparent process, respecting the Treaties and the rules and rules of our Parliament. I would like to thank the parliamentary committees, their chairmen, all the Members and the political groups. I would like to highlight the great work that Parliament's administration has done. Finally, I would like to thank the press and the media for their attention to the work of our institution. I wish Mrs von der Leyen and the new Commission every success in their work. Now we sign the letter and I have to come and deliver it to him. (Loud applause)

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I congratulate honourable Members for concluding their vote on the budget of the European Union for the financial year 2020. The Council notes with satisfaction that the Parliament confirmed the agreement reached at the Conciliation Committee meeting on 18 November with such wide political support from here. I take this opportunity to once again thank the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, Johan Van Overtveld, and the rapporteurs, Monika Hohlmeier and Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, as well as all other Members of Parliament who participated in the budgetary procedure, for your constructive approach. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for his support of this work.  (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: The joint text on which the Conciliation Committee reached agreement on 18 November was approved by both Parliament and the Council. The budgetary procedure was implemented in accordance with Article 314 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
