The budgetary procedure for the financial year 2020 can therefore be considered completed. I therefore declare the Eu ropean Union budget for the financial year 2020 finally adopted and will now proceed to the budget. That concludes voting time.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on a topical issue (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure) on the interference of other countries in our democracies and our elections (2019/2941(RSP)). I would like to inform Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in this debate and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Caroline Voaden
text: representative of Renew Group. – Madam President, in the last few years we have seen a sea change in the way politics and elections are conducted. We may still deliver leaflets, knock on doors and transmit party political broadcasts on TV, but increasingly our voters are getting their information online through social media platforms and cleverly targeted advertising that takes advantage of ever more effective algorithms to target them individually from thousands of miles away.  It’s fair to say that citizens all over Europe are at the mercy of anyone with a sinister agenda and a computer. We are undergoing a quantum leap in our electoral processes, one that eclipses the advent of the printing press, the newspaper, the radio and the television, but the gap between this evolving technology, on the one hand, and regulation and legislation on the other, has now become a great digital chasm. Both literally and metaphorically, the old rules cease to apply as our legislation falls woefully behind reality. The stubborn refusal of companies such as Facebook to take clear and decisive action to police their platforms opens a door into our elections that any foreign actor can waltz through unimpeded. The proper regulation of platforms such as Facebook is not an infringement on freedom of speech. It is our moral duty. We must take stronger action against fake profiles and accounts. We must strengthen the EU Code of Conduct on disinformation, and we must reform electoral laws to cater for the modern era. We must investigate the financing of political parties by the Kremlin. For instance, in the UK, we know that Russian oligarchs have paid huge sums of money to play tennis with Boris Johnson.  Hostile governments are taking advantage of the digital space to interfere in our elections to further their own political goals. With over 50 national, regional and local elections due in Europe before the end of 2020, we must start taking this threat seriously. Those who detest the idea of democracy and view the messy process of elections as a charade to shore up their positions – Vladimir Putin chief amongst them – pour millions in economic and human resources into targeting European voters.  We have seen this in the UK, France and Spain, too. But it’s not just Putin who is playing this sinister game. We know that Dominic Cummings, who is advising our own government, spent time in Russia. This must be investigated, and there are many in this House who are here because of the darling of the US alt-right, Steve Bannon. There are those within our own Member States who are more than happy to accept the help of these external actors in their quest for power. I would look at Nigel Farage but he hasn’t turned up this week. I also look to the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom who has refused to disclose a parliamentary report on Russian interference in the Brexit referendum of 2016. He knows what is in that report. We know what is in that report, but he refuses to release it because the truth stands in the way of his personal ambition. Boris Johnson – release the Russia report now!  Things have got so bad that in the UK electoral campaign the government is now impersonating fact-checking websites to spread misinformation. Vladimir would be proud. He doesn’t even need to interfere any more. That one of the oldest political parties in Europe is willing to do this, says much about how foreign electoral interference takes root, infects our society and becomes the norm.  There must be a parliamentary response to this unacceptable behaviour and there must be decisive action, both in Member States and in Europe, and yet politicians have so far come up short. Facebook still operates as the Trojan horse into our democracy. The time has come for this new Parliament, for this new Commission, for this new reality we live in, to get serious. If not, we will be forever at the mercy of any authoritarian at a keyboard. I welcome your opinion, colleagues, and I hope you sense the same danger that I do. (Applause)

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, John F. Kennedy once said: ‘The ignorance of one voter in a democracy impairs the security of all’. I believe that maliciously-influenced or misled voters could pose a similar risk to our societies. Evolving malicious interference and online manipulation shows that this risk to our democratic institutions is real and requires our constant attention. We are therefore grateful for this new opportunity to engage with you on this important topic. Let me repeat that our Presidency’s priority is to make sustained efforts to raise awareness, increase preparedness and strengthen the resilience of our democracies to disinformation. Hybrid threats, including foreign interference in our democracies, remain, therefore, at the top of our political agenda. The Presidency has taken a number of steps, in particular a dedicated and permanent horizontal working party of the Council was created during the first month of our Presidency. It discusses how to strengthen the EU’s capabilities in countering hybrid threats and to build resilience in the EU and Member States. The mandate of the group includes election interference and disinformation campaigns. We have proposed Council conclusions to be adopted in December on complementary efforts to enhance resilience and counter hybrid threats, building on the important work done at the EU level in recent years. The conclusions also pay attention to countering disinformation and securing free and fair elections. The last debate held in this House in September sought broad agreement that foreign interference and disinformation pose a major threat to democracy and EU values. Without a doubt, the EU institutions and the Member States have an important role to play; this is in the remit of their competencies in the protection of democratic processes. It is therefore appropriate that protecting European democracy is also a priority for President von der Leyen. We have in particular noted with great interest that Vice-President Jourová will be responsible for coordinating the work on a Europe and Democracy Action Plan that will include a set of initiatives. This will require a focus on building up resilience and countering disinformation while pursuing and protecting fundamental freedoms. Countering hybrid threats requires a comprehensive approach and a horizontal working method. This is why the work needs to be done in close alignment with all relevant stakeholders in the EU institutions as well as in the Member States to enhance the EU’s ability to prevent, detect and respond to hybrid threats. Protection of our democracies and elections involves concerted efforts by the EU and the Member States, but also by civil society and industry. Our response has to be comprehensive, with a focus on both the internal and external dimensions of the threat. Much has been done already, both by the EU institutions and individual Member States. Let me just briefly mention the main milestones, such as regular exchanges in the European election cooperation network, setting up the Rapid Alert System, enhancement of strategic communication, facilitating networks of independent fact checkers, promotion of media and digital literacy and awareness-raising activities, and monitoring of the implementation of the code of practice by social media platforms. But it is also important that we further develop institutional mechanisms and tools to fulfil the objectives set by the European Council. It is also essential to continue developing partnerships, especially our cooperation with NATO. In this regard, the Helsinki European Centre of Excellence for Countering Hybrid Threats also contributes to fostering cooperation in this field. Likewise, disinformation strategies by foreign actors are deployed beyond our borders. So we need to work with partners in the eastern and southern neighbourhood and in the Western Balkans. As stressed in the conclusions on democracy adopted by the Council last month, exposing disinformation, effective scrutiny over the financing of political messaging, strengthening media, information and digital literacy skills are key elements in this regard. We need to act together in a structured and coordinated way in order to tackle these challenges. Protecting elections is at the core of defending our European values.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to take the floor on the issue of interference from other countries in our democracies and elections. The Commission has been deeply engaged in broad efforts to address the manifold risks stemming from lack of transparency, disinformation and other manipulations of electoral and democratic processes, and is committed to strengthening this path in the upcoming term. Indeed, as we heard from the Presidency, it will be one of my biggest tasks in the new Commission. Thank you for the support. The conduct of free and fair elections is primarily the responsibility of Member States. Nevertheless, a European approach is necessary given the cross-border dimension of efforts to manipulate democracy and the importance of joining efforts to address the threats. Just as with the rule of law, what affects one Member State can affect all and impact the Union itself. The threats at stake are complex and the targets are constantly evolving. For instance, external actors are more often using domestic proxies. We also see new technological developments allowing for new forms and strategies of interference. In the context of the 2019 elections, the Commission has taken a number of concrete steps to address the challenges, including with the election package of measures to secure free and fair elections in Europe, with the Code of Practice on Disinformation, which has been signed by Facebook, Twitter, Google and Microsoft, and with the Action Plan on Disinformation, with which we have also made some progress. We will build on this work in the upcoming term. We have worked to put a holistic and permanent framework in place, with an aim to strengthen the resilience of our democracies and adapt to the evolving threats and coordinated and intentional manipulation.  To address the threats at stake, a coordinated and comprehensive approach is necessary, involving all actors across government, including regulatory and enforcement authorities, political parties, journalists, fact-checkers, researchers, educators and society and civil society at large, as well as industry and the online platforms. Some of them I mentioned, but of course we need to invite more to work with us. And of course we will need citizens to work on strengthening their own resilience against these new threats. I sometimes say that we have to work on increasing the demand for truth, and this will be a very big task ahead of us.  We need to get better when it comes to detecting, analysing and exposing disinformation and other manipulations of European democratic processes, whatever the tactics and actors employed. This needs to go hand in hand with wider efforts on monitoring cybersecurity and resilience against hybrid threats. In terms of cooperation, we can be pleased with the European cooperation network on elections, which meets today for the fifth time to discuss its future work on safeguarding elections. This is a new club and a very important piece of our toolkit. We also need to further enhance cooperation between EU institutions and EU Member States via this network and the Rapid Alert System, which will help us build a genuine community of practitioners. It will also allow us to build meaningful cooperation with international partners, such as the G7 or NATO, because we are facing a real global problem. We can improve the effectiveness of communication through a coordinated response to disinformation incidents, as well as raising public awareness more generally.  To this end, it is important to pursue our efforts aimed at facilitating the establishment of an independent community of fact-checkers and academic researchers to detect and expose disinformation campaigns across social networks.  Following its initial 12-month period of implementation, the Code of Practice on Disinformation is now in the process of being evaluated. Should the results under the Code prove unsatisfactory, the Commission may propose further measures, including of a regulatory nature. We also need to invest in strengthening media literacy, which is key to resilient and democratic societies. Citizens must be empowered to have the adequate tools for a well-informed participation in democratic processes. President-elect von der Leyen has proposed a new digital services act, which will upgrade our liability and safety rules for digital platforms, services and products. She has also pledged to put forward a coordinated European approach on artificial intelligence. These efforts will be vital if we are to ensure a prosperous, safe and democratic digital future for Europe. Building on the political guidelines of President-elect von der Leyen, I will in the new Commission lead on the work towards a European democracy action plan addressing the threat of interference in our European elections, whilst being mindful of the need to protect the freedom of expression. I will look into possible legislative proposals to ensure clearer rules on the financing of European political parties and greater transparency on paid political advertising. In our actions we must never lose the balance. Our goal is to protect our European democracy. So it is clear that the respect for freedom of speech and our fundamental rights and values must be our cornerstones.

name: Paulo Rangel
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first I would like to congratulate Commissioner Jourová for her nomination and to wish her well.  Commissioner, we know from experience that you are truly and deeply committed to the tasks that are involved in your portfolio. We know that your challenge is a difficult one, but I think there is also some enthusiasm, so I wish you all the best. You know that you will have the cooperation of our group and, I believe, of the House. The House has supported the whole Commission in a very strong and clear way, so I think we will have a very good relationship. I will now turn to my national language.  Madam President, the attempt to meddling, whether by foreign powers or sometimes with some complicity of internal forces, is undoubtedly a serious problem. Disinformation is not a new problem in history, but today, thanks to technological elements, it has a much stronger repercussion throughout society. We know that, for example recently, the Czech intelligence services have drawn attention to Russian and Chinese interference in the political and institutional process. We know that, in the case of Brexit, as has already been said here, there has been interference. We know that in the case of Catalonia an important part of the IPs is based in Greater Moscow. And so we know that there is foreign interference, that they take advantage of the internal political dynamics, that it is real and that there are tensions, to exploit it, expand and create instability, and also create disinformation, in the context of our societies. And so here I believe that it is fundamental, that it is indeed decisive, that we have, first of all, a great concern for the education of citizens. Citizens, and young people in particular, must be able to discern, to differentiate what is true from what is false, they have to have critical capacity.  There are very important social workers here: politicians, of course, religious leaders, scientists at the academy and journalists in particular, are four groups that we must have as target groups to rightly train and transmit, say, this to society. On the other hand, I think we could also use the External Action Service, because it must be effective in the capitals where we suspect there is such interference, to show the displeasure of the European Union.  And I must say by the way: there is also some interference linked to problems, the threats to internal democracy, and I can not help today remember the case of Malta, where the murder of journalist Daphne Galizia was something terrifying and that shows that free information is in danger even with the physical threat, and not just with the digital threat.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner on behalf of the S&D Group. Free and fair elections are at the very heart of democracy, of our European project and our Union, but free and fair elections are not a given and should not be taken for granted. Election interference challenges the foundations of our democratic systems and risks are growing day after day and they are there to stay unless we take action. This is a major issue in many of our Member States and current policies are insufficient to counter this hybrid assault on our democracies. Millions of Europeans are being exposed to massive disinformation campaigns due to foreign interference. Cyberattacks have risen to an unprecedented level, with dangerous access to strategic infrastructure and data. Electoral rules on the financing of political parties by third countries are being breached. However, EU governments are still failing to act. Some governments are even hiding the truth from the public. This is the case of the UK Government of Boris Johnson, for instance. It recently refused to release the Intelligence and Security Committee report on the Russian threat to UK democracy. But this is far from being an isolated case. This comes after a plan by Russian actors to fund the Lega of Matteo Salvini, the Austrian FPO Ibiza scandal, the case of the French Front National, the Leave.EU campaign in the UK and suspicious online activities during the last European elections in Germany.  Last month, at the initiative of the S&D Group, the European Parliament adopted a resolution in which we called for bold action here in Parliament. We understood the importance of this issue and we called for the establishment of a special parliamentary committee on election interference to address the challenges effectively and holistically. But the proposal did not pass, due to the opposition of 52 Renew colleagues. I am puzzled why our colleagues from Renew, and more specifically the UK Lib Dems, insisted on having this topic on the agenda yet voted against the special committee addressing this issue here in the European Parliament. However, sometimes we find that it takes time to come to challenges. So let’s unite, let’s work together and let’s ensure that in the European Parliament too, we take this issue very seriously.

name: Pascal Durand
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Madam Vice-President, of course I congratulate you on behalf of the Renew Group on your re-election this morning. I would like to add, as a personal matter, all the pleasure I have in seeing you on the subjects that had already associated us in the previous Parliament, namely democracy and the rule of law. Our history is made of the search for a somewhat complicated balance. As Mrs von der Leyen pointed out this morning, the fragility of our democracies and the European Union stems from this historic search between the defence of freedom, the defence of freedoms, the right to think and the right to express ourselves and, at the same time, respect for the rules of law that are required of all so that we can live together in society. Throughout our history, we have invented printing, through which we have developed knowledge and ideas and advanced humanism. We invented and defended freedom of the press and freedom of thought, but we have been able to balance - you know, Madam Vice-President, especially since you come from a country that has not always experienced freedom of expression and freedom of thought freely - this freedom of thought by the principle of responsibility of those who disseminate and , at the same time, by rules imposed on the press and broadcasting. We can't spread everything in our democracies. When I hear, at a time when the internet is replacing the printing scheme, the press, etc. and going much faster, that we must give it total freedom, that it should not be regulated, that it should be allowed to self-manage, I think, Madam Vice-President, that we are undermining the very essence of the value of European democracy, that of the balance between freedom and the rule. I will end with this: let us not make the internet a space of lawlessness, let us not make social networks a space of freedom without control.

name: Sergey Lagodinsky
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Congratulations also from the Greens, Madam Vice-President, on your election. Today, however, we are talking about a different subject. "The conflict between Russia and Ukraine is ruining our economy" – that was the subject line of the email that paralyzed the Bundestag for weeks. This was a virus that, as it later turned out, was smuggled in by a group close to the Russian military intelligence service GRU. This was only the most obvious example of external intervention in our democratic institutions. But a lot of things are under the radar, and that is really a cause for concern. Everything that takes place in agitation in this form is part of a veritable ideological confrontation, a propaganda war in the digital sphere, it has to be said, between Russia and China on the one hand and the liberal democracies on the other. This does not only happen in German or English, it also happens in Russian. The case of Lisa in my city of Berlin – Berlin-Marzahn – where many hundreds of Russian speakers were mobilized by reports on Russian TV, by fake reports on Russian TV, is well known. But this propaganda is also happening on German, and not only in the form of Russia Today; Redfish on Facebook is a radical left group that actually calls for interesting and good and important climate policy concerns, but at the same time incorporates agitatory propaganda and belongs to the Russian news agencies. So we must also look at these ways, and these news agencies too. But we must also look at our own colleagues. There are parties that have a deep contempt for our democracy today and also contempt for this Europe, and they are also sitting here. Just today, there have been reports about the AfD – a pity that our colleagues are not sitting there: Jörg Meuthen EUR 95 000, Guido Reil EUR 45 000 – that is the donations that – it has just become clear – have been recruited via fake donors for these colleagues who are sitting among us every day. We have to ask them where this money comes from when the AfD is already openly saying that it is going to the Russian embassy for consultations again and again. Where does this money come from? Many of these funds came through Switzerland. It would be interesting to get answers to these questions. But it is not just about the anti-Europeans, it is also about us. We must strengthen our own democratic institutions, we must not fall into the anti-democratic patterns ourselves. This also includes the digital culture, digital competence and the resilience of our institutions – also here and also towards our colleagues, who owe us answers.

name: Jordan Bardella
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, forgive me for disturbing the paranoia, but let us not unnecessarily turn around the pot. If this theme is imposed on us, it is obviously to reinforce the idea that Vladimir Putin's Russia would hide behind the successes recorded by sovereignist forces on a European continent." If President Macron, Chancellor Merkel and their friends rack up electoral setbacks, this could only be explained by manipulation from abroad. The National Agency for Security of Information Systems claimed last year that during the French presidential campaign, there were no Russian cyberattacks, giving the wrong of President Macron's camp. Even better, the report published on 14th June by the European Commission was quite unable to identify any disinformation campaign organised from abroad and focused on the European elections. So it's quite amusing to see that it's those who claim to uncover plots that resort to conspiracy by regularly imagining an invisible Russian hand. Interferences are clearly visible and very real, but they are not where you would like to see them. Didn't former US President Barack Obama interfere in the French election by openly supporting Emmanuel Macron in the inter-round? Didn't Chancellor Angela Merkel say in 2016 that she wanted to roll back the National Front? Finally, what about the threatening statements of European leaders or officials to intimidate the British people during the Brexit referendum or after the election of Mr Salvini in Italy? Ladies and gentlemen, therefore, stop making people's awakening look like a phenomenon whose causes are irrational or obscure. It is explained by the impasse in which you have been driving them for so long and in your inability to meet the real aspirations of the European peoples.

name: Peter Lundgren
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Foreign election influence is something that worries many people. Most people probably think of the Us elections and of countries such as China, Iran and Russia as election influencers.  In Sweden, the thoughts right now are probably going extra to China, which recently quite openly tried to influence a minister and the Swedish government not to award a prize to a person who displeased the Chinese regime. It naturally raises thoughts about how much electoral influence China is trying to do under the surface when they are so brazen in the public sphere.  It is not only anti-democratic foreign powers that are trying to influence elections in democratic countries. The EU, too, uses propaganda to influence elections by painting a picture of who is evil and who is good. They also often paint a purely apocalyptic picture of the threats to the EU and the community and cooperation that exists. This is, of course, pure scare mongering to influence the national elections. And is there any difference between who is trying to influence an election? No, it's not. Trying to influence the elections in a democratic country and not respect an election result is never accepted. We should never allow it and must always stand up to the influence of both the EU and foreign powers such as China and Russia.

name: Martina Anderson
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we cannot talk about foreign interference in elections without calling out the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which has never been held to account for taking half a million pounds of dark money during the Brexit campaign – dark, shadowy money that was given to the DUP through an alleged international criminal businessperson. They did not spend it in the North of Ireland; instead, the DUP spent it in a country where they do not field candidates – England – in order to circumvent English electoral law. There was no investigation into where it came from.  After the Brexit referendum, legislation was put in place that protected the DUP from having to disclose the source. This is the same DUP which is currently inciting loyalist mobs to campaign for DUP Brexiteers. Loyalists have put up intimidatory posters against Sinn Féin candidate and Mayor of Belfast, John Finucane, whose father, Pat, was murdered by Loyalists and British State Agents.  If this was happening anywhere else, the EU would be condemning it. However, the partition of Ireland with an in—built unionist majority was designed to facilitate gerrymandering and obstruct the democratic will of the people – by whatever means. This underpinned the foundation of a discriminatory Orange State with oppressive laws that were the envy of apartheid South Africa.  Thankfully, the Orange State and the inbuilt undemocratic Unionist majority are gone, and we are on a pathway towards an inclusive, democratic United Ireland.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Mr President, this is not the first time we have been talking about fake news and foreign interference. A year ago, we were standing here. Two months ago, we had this debate. Last month we adopted another resolution, and today we are standing here again. We stand here again because it remains important and because it seems like real action is not there.  The European elections are over. We have seen several studies showing that almost half – 250 million – of Europeans were exposed to fake news from Russian trolls in the run-up to that election. We've seen networks operating in different countries to spread disinformation. Users and pages have been removed from Facebook, among others, but only after they've been viewed hundreds of millions of times. The fact-checkers of our own East StratCom Task Force recorded more than 1 000 cases of Russian interference, more than doubling from the previous year: a clear confirmation of the challenge we all face, and the Commission confirmed this. The Task Force was expanded, but is that enough? I put that question to the EU Foreign Service and the answer was very clear: with this budget, we cannot adequately address the problem.  So we have to do more. Less talk, more action. I would like to call on the Commission to really address this in the coming period. This must be done in two specific areas. Resources, more resources to really tackle the problem. More money for analysis and research, more money for anti-disinformation campaigns, more investment in technology, more commitment to our own resilience and our awareness of all of us. Second, the tech giants: put an end to the "freedom, happiness" approach to platforms like Facebook. It is high time that they finally took responsibility. No voluntary codes of conduct, but binding measures to enforce transparency and cooperation.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr Lenaers just said that we have just had a resolution, we’ve just had a debate and now, of course, we’re back debating the same thing, but there is a reason for this and the reason is that something is happening. This is not an exaggerated issue; this is an issue on which the Commission – Commissioner Jourová and Commissioner King – have been working now for months. This is an issue on which we have been working. We wanted a special committee for a reason and the reason is not that some Donald Trump says to Boris Johnson, I like you, I want your NHS, I’d like to buy it. That is not the interference we’re talking about. I don’t like it, but it is not what we’re talking about. It is talking about a growing body of evidence that there is illegal and covert interference, what John F Kennedy would not have liked. Because at least one voter is voting differently because they have been targeted. Cambridge Analytica, the theft of private information for covert and illegal use against a constitution and against a body of jurisprudence and law. So let’s just be clear what we are talking about. It is illegal and it is covert. Today it will harm us; maybe tomorrow it will harm you. So, this is what we are talking about and I welcome what my UK colleagues have done in initiating this debate because what they are doing is uncovering the latest element of this in my own country, which is where our Conservative Government is covering up the truth from the public by refusing to release the Intelligence and Security Committee (ISC) report on the Russian threat to UK politics. One of our big Member States of the European Union. The report has been approved by the UK intelligence agencies, there is no impediment to publication, and yet, they’re not publishing. How much more evidence do we need to understand that this evidence is real? Well, the Commission, of course, talked about continued and sustained misinformation during the last May elections, similar to those carried out in the US and France. The report, of course, talks about limited action and I encourage the Commissioner, of course, in her new role, with the new College, to do as much as possible. Because what we’re talking about is online and offline safeguards, the banning of profiling for electoral purposes, the content shared by bots, the removal of fake accounts. Neither the private sector nor indeed our governments are doing enough yet. There can be nothing more important than free and fair elections. This is against the law, it’s covert, it is illegal and we must do something about it to safeguard our democracies.

name: Martin Horwood (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Vice-President on her election. I apologise for not being here for your opening statement but I understand you promised a coordinated response to foreign interference. It must be coordinated with Member States, Brexit or no Brexit. We know Russian money is invested in the UK in particular and in London in particular and that should have given us leverage in resisting and sanctioning against interference in our democratic processes. But the still unpublished Intelligence and Security Committee report, which has already been referred to, may reveal just how inadequate our response has been. Will it detail Russian influence in the narrowly won Brexit referendum? We don’t know because our government, as has just been said by Mr Moraes quite rightly, has tried to silence our national parliament but still refuses to publish this report, although we know that no government agency or department stands in the way of publication, only the Prime Minister’s political will. Perhaps this is because the report may detail Russian donations to our ruling Conservative party and to the Brexit campaign. Our national parliament is currently dissolved and our government may have been at best asleep on the job, but I’m delighted that the European Parliament has provided a democratic forum in which we can ring the alarm bell and sound the wake-up call and I hope the Commission’s response will be much more determined.

name: Alice Kuhnke (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In many ways, cyberattacks are a nightmare, an enemy that is not visible but exists and is deadly. It may sound big, but it is, as we all know, no exaggeration. The attacks are ongoing and they represent a clear and strong threat to the values and democratic principles on which we have built the European Union. That knowledge requires action. Last year, the Commission presented a plan on how to combat online disinformation. We have thus taken the first steps in the fight against cyberattacks. But that's not enough. Europe must do much more. Europol's cybercrime department – where analysis and research are linked to strategies and action plans – is good, but it is not enough. Europe must ensure that every Member State takes the cyber threat seriously, because confidence in europe and for us elected politicians stands and falls with whether we take the threat to our democracies seriously. Governments, parliaments, civil society and schools must be given missions and resources so that we are all equipped to take responsibility and act on our various platforms against the forces that threaten our democracy.

name: Laura Huhtasaari (ID).
text: – Mr President, attempts to influence European elections from outside must be rejected. We must ensure that Europeans are highly educated so that we can distinguish the right information from propaganda. It is completely intolerable if Russia, China or a third country seeks to influence the holding of elections in European democracy.  This real phenomenon must not be abused by misleading people. Russian troll factories on social media have not led people to vote for nationalist parties. You consensus parties make people vote for the alternative offered by patriotic parties. Open borders immigration policy, Islamisation, climate hysteria, the ceiling on industrial jobs and the erosion of welfare services are some of the reasons why mainstream parties are losing elections.  In Sweden, bombings and shootings are now part of everyday Swedish life. This is what mainstream party politics have led to. That is what we nationalist parties are correcting. Make Europe safe again! This is where someone called for where we got the money. At least I have paid for my campaign myself because I believe in a better and safer Europe.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Dear Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, congratulations on your choice. You've got a hard job ahead of you. Dear colleagues, once again we see a very pronounced double standard in this chamber. Most of you who spoke out were against the intervention and funding outside of political parties. But only when it comes to parties you don't like - like the Conservative Party in Britain, for example. However, when it comes to the bottomless pockets of billionaire, infamous billionaire and financial speculator Soros, who funds very strong propaganda in Central and Eastern Europe, you are not against it. And that's a double standard. You have to choose – you are either against external interference or you cannot make a ministry of truth. I've heard a few colleagues here- titans of political thought, say they're going to shut down the internet, censor it. Good luck to you! George Orwell wrote "Ministry of Truth" for you. When we talk about external intervention, there has to be the same standard. Everyone should be placed under a common denominator and not acted so hypocritically and selectively.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the defence of democracy requires a pluralistic, democratic and independent media sector. It demands the defence of the independence of the media from economic power, preventing the monopolistic concentration of media companies and advocating the strengthening of the public service, guaranteeing the rights of journalists and other information professionals and their respect for ethical and ethical principles. The growing concentration promoted in the European Union serving the interests of dominant policies and major economic groups goes in the opposite direction, limiting the freedom and independence of the press, facilitating the spread of lies or the silencing of communist and progressive forces, their proposals and their actions, while promoting imperialism, obscurantism, populism and their undemocratic objectives , opening the doors to the far right. The so-called external threats that the European Union and this Parliament insist on pointing out are only a pretext for masking this reality and for continuing on the dangerous path of single, reactionary thinking.

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Commission Vice—President on her election today. It was only timely that Ms Ursula von der Leyen in her speech today mentioned the many Czechs and Slovaks who, 30 years ago during the Velvet Revolution, fought for freedom. Thanks to that fight, freedom and free and fair elections are something that we have across Europe in a much larger number today. It also something that we must safeguard, and we must take action, because we have been under threat. This is not just a debate about the lies before Brexit; it’s something which concerns all of us and which we experienced in every election, including the European election – in every national contest. Indeed, this Parliament did adopt a resolution last month on how to best approach the fight against foreign interference and against the spread of disinformation. I think this is a very good start for political action.  Let me just underline three things which we would expect from the Commission. First, this fight against external interference, and also the fight against disinformation, must become our political priority. This is not just a technical issue; this has to be at the forefront of the Commission’s political fight in the next five years. We have to make it a political issue; we can’t just keep on talking about who is responsible, who is to blame. We must take action, and indeed, we must be bold in terms of proposing also regulation. We must safeguard the space on the internet. We must safeguard Europe’s values. We must safeguard our democracy. We must also invest more money, more resources, into education – indeed, into education in the area where our citizens are most vulnerable: in cyberspace; on the Internet; in the digital space. I hope we can all do this.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is true that the European Parliament has already adopted a resolution last October, on the initiative of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, condemning interference in our democratic processes by foreign powers, but new cases are emerging. Meanwhile, the Italian judiciary recently opened an investigation into international corruption into the affair of alleged Russian funding to matteo salvini's League, but beyond the criminal implications, murky events remain in evidence, never fully clarified. The Italian case was preceded by an Austrian case, a French case, and, just to be in the most recent news, interference emerged during the referendum campaign for Britain's exit from Europe. All this is not conspiracy, all this is dangerous for the maintenance of our democratic systems, because often, by fomenting hate campaigns on the web, public opinion is conditioned and therefore electoral processes are influenced. That is why it is important for the debate to continue and for the spotlight not to go out, in case we also propose a parliamentary committee again. We have a duty to clarify and defend our democratic institutions.

name: Nathalie Loiseau (Renew).
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, what underpins our European model is first and foremost the freedom to choose those who govern us. Increasingly, however, we are seeing foreign powers seeking to influence the outcome of our votes with the obvious aim of weakening us. We can see it, we can deplore it, we can condemn these interferences, or rather this cancer that is struggling to damage our free world. But above all, we must act and act without delay. To do this, why not create a European agency to protect democracies that would provide each Member State with the necessary expertise to counter cyber-attacks, manipulation and misinformation that target electoral processes? We do have a European food security agency. If we are able to protect what is coming on our plate, we should be able to protect what goes through our ballot boxes and ballots. Democratic intoxication has consequences at least as severe as food poisoning, and is sometimes much more difficult to cure. Madam President, I congratulate you on your election and thank you for your commitment to protecting our democracies.

name: Christian Allard (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate you as well on your election. We adopted the text of this resolution in October, and today I very much welcome this debate. Like many speakers before me, I think a lot more should be done because – as we have already heard – in the US it is now accepted that Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election took place. In the UK we are not there yet, as our Prime Minister – Boris Johnson – claimed last week that he had never seen any evidence of Russian interference in UK democratic processes. However, in December 2017, the then UK Foreign Secretary – Boris Johnson – said that he had seen evidence of Russian interference in UK democratic processes. Which Boris Johnson is telling the truth? As our First Minister of Scotland said today, Prime Minister Boris Johnson is dangerous and unfit for office. In this climate of xenophobia, racism and intolerance towards foreigners, I’m very pleased to hear the tone of the debate today. When I read the text first of all, earlier this year, on our right to engage and make sure that when we talk in this debate, we choose our words very carefully. It is the state organisations and their representatives that get involved in this interference, in which it is not the people who exercise their democratic right to vote and to stand for election in their adopted country. I would know, as a French citizen who represents Scotland in this Parliament. Let’s stop the interference of foreign states, but let’s open up our democracies to all the people who live among us – foreigners like me included. In this coming election, I will not be voting at Westminster, but I wish all the candidates good luck – especially the MEPs here, and especially Alyn Smith, my cher collègue, to whom I wish all the best in the coming election.  (Applause)

name: Thierry Mariani (ID).
text: Madam President, in France, after 1870, a terror gripped the parliamentary and journalistic circles that saw Germany's hand in all the elections. Similar phenomena continued to do the history of the Member States. Sometimes these fears are legitimate; often, they are just fantasies. They were always overtaken by one element: the feeling of the necessary national unity to maintain the European homelands. The European Union is now paradoxical in its attitude to this danger. She describes any return to national sentiment as a danger and both claims to protect us from foreign interference. Any debate or resolution concerning the interference of foreign countries in elections is in fact very clear political attacks on European patriotic movements and, often, on Russia, accused of being major actors in foreign electoral interference and misinformation in national and European democratic processes. I can also cite proven cases of direct and overt foreign interference by leaders or lobby groups in the recent elections in the European Union: Mr Soros and his Open Society, which put out anti-Hungarian government watchwords on the walls of Budapest; Algerian leaders, who regularly call for the dissolution of the National Gathering; Mr Erdogan, with the abundant subsidies we give him, who gives voting instructions to dual nationals in Germany and France; and Mr. Obama, who is providing broad media support for Mr. Macron two days before the presidential election. Finally, Madam President, I have just come out of a meeting where MEPs are asking for more support for the opposition in Belarus. Before we receive lessons, let's make sure we don't be guilty ourselves.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Madam President. Congratulations to the curator on the re-election. I wanted to talk about interference. Interferences we're seeing a lot. There has been talk of interference in Catalonia by Russian agents. There are, no doubt. But we've been seeing a lot of interference in Europe. We have seen Mrs Merkel's interference in virtually every European election held from Hungary to Austria massively, etc. What has there been no interference from Europeans towards the United States in 2016 when they all devoted themselves as a chorus to insulting Trump? But I'm going to talk about a much more serious interference than that and it's the one we have right now in Spain. In Spain the Socialist Party is about to make an electoral alliance with the support of the Catalan separatists, but with an alliance with podemos's communists. Podemos is a Venezuelan franchise formed in Venezuela by Chávez and the Cubans, financed by them and that will have a place in the Council of Ministers, with which we will practically have Maduro within the Council of Ministers in Spain. The risk of the mass interference of the Sao Paulo Forum throughout Latin America will be repeated in Europe with that alliance of socialists and communists in Spain.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I wanted to ask the question by raising the blue card to my two previous words, because I think there is a mix of two concepts. On the one hand, it is the concept of influencing, that is, when someone informs someone about something truthfully, independently, and the concept of spreading false news, and that is the problem that we encounter. Spreading disinformation is spreading lies! No one here is against free media, including social networks, spreading truthful information. No one here is protesting that. But we are all aware that false information is spreading on social media, and both the European Union and the Member States must oppose this. In the Czech Republic, for example, civil intelligence warns against Russian and Chinese influence. Its annual report draws attention to a Russian-backed campaign on social media and in the media to weaken both the European Union and NATO, in the form of false information. Influencing political processes seeks to put Member States in conflict and, of course, it is in the UK that this has succeeded. This means that this is about preventing the spread of lies, not restricting media freedom. On the contrary, we want free media, that's what we're all calling for. That is why I think that both the European Union and the Member States must support authors, they must promote media freedom, public media. I think that we are now facing a situation where the Member States have to implement the Audiovisual Services Directive, the Copyright Directive, which will ensure the promotion of quality media. And I think that's the point. I also ask for greater support for StratCom so that the European Union can face what is massively financially supported elsewhere. I am talking specifically about China and Russia. Please do it!

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: – Madam President, congratulations also to Mrs Jourová for being commissioner again and returning to the Commission; we have a lot of issues to work on together besides this one. On this, I would like to say that the Europeans and political leaders of the European Union must stop having any hope of naivety, because there is clearly a coalition of enemies, outside the European Union, which seeks to weaken it — if not also destroy it — and which is also in alliance with people within our Member States , either in political movements or in other structures.  This is a reality, and we need to have the means to deal with this threat and deactivate it. Let us think that, of course, we have at European Union level prohibitions for foreign powers to finance election campaigns for European elections, but are we sure that we have the same degree of protection in the Member States? Because through there the European Union is also deactivated and damaged.

name: Lucy Nethsingha (Renew).
text: – Madam President, this debate is particularly timely for the UK where the issue of electoral interference is really high on the agenda in our current election. The Conservative Party in the UK has transformed beyond recognition over the last three years, and there are many in the UK who have huge concerns about the influence from both Russia and the USA in that massive change. At the most basic level, the scale of donations from Russian oligarchs or their wives is extraordinary: GBP 200 000 from one individual in the first week of this election campaign alone. Those with deep pockets have always tried to influence elections, but the scale and the technology is new. The impact of misinformation has been recognised by serious research, which has shown that those who have been fed false information are significantly harder to persuade of the true facts than people with no prior knowledge. Years of relative peace and security after the end of the Cold War have allowed us here in Europe to grow relaxed about the dangers of foreign propaganda. We need to wake up to the serious threats facing our democracies. That means publishing the Russia files in the UK and getting tough with all forms of media about their responsibilities to validate the truth of what they publish.

name: Catherine Rowett (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, once upon a time, we would surely have named the British Parliament alongside Athens as twin archetypes for democracy. But every democracy need safeguards; its sanctions need to match the power of its emerging oligarchs. If the UK safeguards once sufficed when the right honourable members in parliament were honourable and not so far right, those times seem long gone, as Boris Johnson’s ignominious cronies obstruct publication of the UK Parliament’s Intelligence and Security Committee (ISC) report on Russian interference, redact the names of those involved, bribe millionaire lobbyists with cash for access, and avert their eyes from incriminating evidence against their own team over the 2016 Brexit campaign. All this should have been rectified before precipitating yet another election accompanied by profligate spending, misinformation and manipulation with the very same individuals in the driving seat. In Ancient Athens a pile of broken pot-shards solved such problems. Empowered with these, the demos could ostracise anyone who threatened the rule of law, isolating him from political office for 10 years. Modern democracy, too, needs a decent tool for this job, and it should include exclusion, since to the super-rich any fine seems just fine.

name: Silvia Sardone (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, are we really talking for the umpteenth time about other countries' interference in our democracy and elections? I really think we're at the tragicomic.  You don't understand the people's vote. You see the Brexit vote, Trump, Bolsonaro, the victories of sovereignists in Europe or the triumph of Matteo Salvini's League at the European elections and you wonder how it is possible, for you it is a mystery. So try to justify the popular vote, which you do not accept, by inventing absurd plots and going to gag the Internet, because in your opinion we are the producers of fake news. It is a pity that it is you who give the nonsense news, with your pro-European propaganda paid for by taxpayers. It is your fault, and only yours, that Europe likes it less and less. You are locked in palaces and unable to listen to and respond to the needs of citizens. Crush populists, because you are incapable of listening and giving answers to the people. But, I have to say, really keep it up! Don't be self-critical and come up with conspiracy justifications for the popular vote. We will continue to be among the people, to respond to the needs of our citizens and to protect the interests of our country, with pride and with our heads held high.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is another debate on the same subject. The subject, the problem seems very important, and the debate unnecessary. It seems to me that the European Parliament seems to be succumbing to conspiracy theories, easying external interventions in any election that does not correspond to the main parties. However, It seems to me that we should be worried about something else, other forms of interference in the democratic processes in Europe: for example, Russian influence in the German SPD through former Chancellor Gerhard Schröder or Gazprom's influence in the country, influence over the Austrian SPÖ through former Chancellor Gusenbauer, Russian influence also in other parties or on President Macron, which can be felt in his recent speeches , especially in a famous interview with The Economist. This is a serious problem and we should also discuss it.

name: Javier Zarzalejos (PPE).
text: – Madam President. Thank you very much, Commissioner, for your renewal. Interference is a fact, but at the same time you have to know that interference is a strategy. So it's a plan and it's a goal. And that objective is to weaken our democratic systems and the European Union itself. And, set to weaken democratic systems and the European Union, nothing better than using those who in the past have destroyed European democratic systems and destroyed Europe, that is, nationalisms and populism. Fortunately, we live in democratic systems and in a democratic European Union in which, among other things, they allow such bizarre claims to be heard that federal chancellor Angela Merkel is external interference in Europe. That said, it must be said that the challenge launched by countries such as Russia, China and others are existential challenges that do not allow compromises. Interference isn't just about social media. It's media manipulation, it's agent infiltration, it's forgery, it's funding from screen organizations and political parties. It is extremely serious, and it is also no secret, that the presence and activity of Russian espionage agents in several countries of the Union has already been detected in Europe. The latter, by the way Spain, which has determined the opening of a judicial investigation into the presence and activities of these agents in Catalonia around the dates of the illegal vote of 2017. This serious threat gives new meaning to the European Commission's position as guarantor of the Treaties, in this case as a guarantor of Europe's democratic architecture as well. We have to be clear in the complaint, we have to be active in using all means and we also need to be clear in demanding that everyone, public actors and private actors, take responsibility for responding to this threat.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, I am pleased that this topic is coming to our agenda again despite the recent narrow rejection of the initiative of the Socialists and Democrats to establish a special committee. With each new election in the Member States, we see the extent of this problem. The latest case is the upcoming UK election. It is inadmissible for foreign digital platforms to share unverified information without verifying the veracity of content, based only on paid ads. Citizens clearly recognized this problem. As many as two-thirds expressed concern. However, it should be stressed that the prevention of foreign interference in electoral processes should not be limited to preventing the spread of fake news. It is necessary to work on discovering foreign sources of financing for political parties and their influence on the content of political campaigns. That is why I once again call on my colleagues to support the establishment of a special committee to investigate foreign influences on our electoral processes. Free and transparent elections are the foundation of the democratic process and the defence of European values. This is why the Institutions of the European Union must provide a concrete response to this growing problem.

name: Barbara Ann Gibson (Renew).
text: – Madam President, looking at this issue, I feel like I’ve discovered the arch-villain in a James Bond film. All the plot lines seem to lead to one man – Steve Bannon – who has openly declared his plans to fund and orchestrate a populist nationalist movement to take over the world. This incredible plot is credible, because he’s been the driver behind Cambridge Analytica and Breitbart News, a propaganda machine synonymous with fake news. We’ve seen allegations of dark money, dirty data and campaigns based on lies and hate, designed to discourage specific groups of people from voting. The evidence is strong that this interference influenced the outcome of the Brexit referendum. Steve Bannon is a puppet master and his puppets include Donald Trump, Boris Johnson and Nigel Farage. Investigations have uncovered foreign dark money pouring into their campaigns. This is not a fictional film plot: this is a strategic campaign of manipulation that threatens not only the outcome of single elections, but also our democracies, our cultures and our freedoms. It must be stopped.

name: Ellie Chowns (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, today we are debating interference from other countries in our democracies and elections, a topic which is sadly very topical in my own country of the UK. We’ve all had enough of lies and misinformation, so my speech is composed of three facts and one question. Fact one: on 17 October, the UK Intelligence and Security Committee of our Parliament finalised its report on allegations of Russian interference in UK elections, particularly the June 2016 Brexit referendum. It passed that report to Downing Street. It should have been published within ten days, according to the Chairman of that Committee. Fact two: a leaked early version of that report found that Russia could indeed have influenced the outcome of the referendum and also raises questions about links between Boris Johnson – our current Prime Minister, the Conservative Party, and Russian donors. Fact three: that same Boris Johnson has sat on that report and refused to publish it according to the normal timetable. The Chairman of the Committee, Dominic Grieve, has called that action jaw—dropping and said that Boris Johnson’s excuses are bogus.  So my question is this: what is it that Boris Johnson is so desperate to hide? You don’t have to be Sherlock Holmes to deduce the answer.  (Applause)

name: Hélène Laporte (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about external interference in our elections, it is a good tone to systematically tap into Russia. These accusations are obsessive and are intended only to justify sanctions against the Russians and a more Atlanticist rapprochement, as if the Cold War were still relevant. We forget about internal interference in our democracies. For who voted on a resolution to sanction the government of Viktor Orban, officially for violation of the rule of law, unofficially for the refusal of the plan to relocate migrants? This is the European Parliament. Who looks kindly at NGOs, such as that of George Soros, which promote mass immigration and serve political interests contrary to those of our nations? It is the European Union. Who has been uncompromising with the UK government on the Brexit negotiations in order to deter any other such initiative? It is also the European Union. Finally, who created a task force in 2015 to monitor information described as questionable circulating on the web?  In the French language, this is called censorship. Again, it is the European Union. Wouldn't the misinformation to which you keep referring, ultimately be information that does not fit within the framework of your political correctness? We can ask ourselves that question. These elements demonstrate once again that the European Union and its Parliament are not left behind when it comes to interference, which is why this institution is losing all legitimacy to debate this subject.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the interference of foreign states in electoral processes in Europe, whether national or supranational level, is nothing new. Foreign powers have always tried to exercise political influence over European states, among others in such a way. Due to technological advances, we may be more exposed today than before, but the intention of external factors is the same. It is important to protect ourselves from foreign influence on our electoral and political processes in general. This is in the interest of our citizens who are often targeted by propaganda activities, specifically designed to mislead them. But it is equally important that we stop deceiving ourselves by attributing our own failings to others. Growing dissatisfaction with political elites and democratic institutions in Europe is only partly the fruit of foreign propaganda, and much more bad work by European politicians who have distanced themselves from the people.

name: Frances Fitzgerald (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we are living in an age of misinformation. We are facing a crisis in our ‘information ecosystem’, as Lydia Polgreen described it. The viral spread of misinformation has wreaked havoc in our political systems, namely through interference in our democracies and elections. To emphasise the threat we face: in the first quarter of 2019, 2.2 billion fake Facebook accounts were removed, and Twitter challenged almost 77 million spam or fake accounts. From the Brexit referendum, to the election of President Trump, to the recent European elections, all have been subjected in some way to disinformation campaigns.  While fake news proliferates, high-quality journalism suffers. Populations are best served by a political system held to account by a well briefed, expert media who are sceptical – not cynical, and inquisitive – not inquisitorial. Consensus is not truth. Rumour is not fact. Defamation is not heroism. Career destruction is not systemic reform. Europeans recognise the threat of misinformation, and they want action.  A recent Eurobarometer poll showed that 83% of Europeans think that fake news is a threat to our democracy. There is a serious urgency to this. Doing nothing risks the fundamental foundations of our democracy. We need a quick—access route to deal with online lies. For too long, social media has operated as a Wild West of human discourse. The snowflake never needs to feel responsible for the Avalanche. We must have well—funded cybersecurity systems in place to counter the threat of fake news and foreign interference, with all Member States working together. Without proper facts and information, our laws will have little value. Without proper facts, our citizens cannot be confident in our institutions, including this one. So for this mandate, let’s ensure that our political system places the highest value in truth and fact.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, many of us this morning voted with a large majority to support the Commission of which you are Vice-President. We expect a lot from your team: an upward budget — finally with your own resources — to restore the social agenda, but above all the defence of the rule of law, democracy and European values, for which you are responsible in your Securities and Transparency portfolio. In all the languages of the Union, episodes of interference in electoral processes have been recounted at this session again. It is impossible for me not to mention the investigation activated at the Audiencia Nacional, in Spain, by the interference of the sinister group of Russian spies experts in destabilization of Unit 29155.  But they're not alone, nor is it the only threat. Also the sinister Steve Bannon dwells among us, and always in favor of populism, far-rightness and reactionary nationalism. And so it is not enough just to launch a working group, nor with the special committee we require in this European Parliament. It is imperative to invest in a European intelligence architecture that defends democracy. There is nothing more important than defending European values and defending democracy in the European Union.

name: Katalin Cseh (Renew).
text: – Madam President, behind the Article 7 procedure there is George Soros, as his people cannot accept that Hungary will not welcome migrants. Cohesion funds will be taken away and given to Soros’ organisations. We won’t be a European colony. Just a few examples of good old school disinformation at its finest, straight from the heart of the European Union. Fake news, bots, troll farms, propaganda, disinformation. In case you haven’t noticed, we are at war, and the stakes could not be higher. We are fighting for truth. Not our truth, not their truth, not anyone’s truth: it is the fight for objective facts and reality and – eventually – our sanity, and we are losing. We live in an era where facts and fiction are intertwined, and the border between arguments and propaganda is blurred. But I believe we have much to protect: the very foundation of our democracies depends on our ability to defend our values, our principles, and the right to objective truth. The EU as a community of shared values must be at the forefront of this fight. With Brexit, we have already witnessed how disinformation leads to disintegration, and for once, history should not repeat itself.

name: Maximilian Krah (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I grew up in the communist part of Germany, and I remember the textbooks explaining that riaS in Berlin or Radio Free Europe would try to undermine the democratic processes of socialism. In this respect, I note that I seem to be coming from the future when I hear Mrs Gibson's remarkable conspiracy theories or the Spanish proposal to put an end to it with a European secret service for freedom of expression and the competition of news. Ladies and gentlemen, people therefore choose parties that you do not like because they do not like your policy. People are therefore informing themselves from objective – including foreign – news sources, because they realize that they are not sufficiently informed by the public and also the government-affiliated private television and radio stations. Who could explain on public service radio why Trump was elected or how the war in eastern Ukraine is going? There is nothing but conspiracy theories, but no in-depth analysis. So anyone who is concerned about democracy must create the competition of opinions and competition from providers, but certainly not try to silence other opinions with intelligence services.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for This is your first on-call call, your first speech since the election of the European Commission, so congratulations! I voted for you for the second time in five years and I wish you and the Commission good luck. I will say in this way that we need to talk very openly about this interference from the outside. This must not be demonised. This is a big problem, although it would not be good for those who lose elections to stubbornly fail precisely by external interference. This is not serious.  I would caution against such a very one-sided look at this problem, that is, if I hear in the speech that there is no Russian problem at all and that there is only Steve, and there is no Vladimir Vladimirovich, Then I have the impression that someone is here in the virtual world, and I invite you to the real world. Of course, Russia – but not just Russia – is interfering, we should know it, we should stigmatise it, we should be in solidarity here.

name: Bartosz Arłukowicz (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We live in interesting but very difficult times. We live in a time when, in order to destabilise another country, you no longer need to drive tanks or sail submarines today. But since we live in interesting times, we need to realize how much responsibility lies in the hands of politicians. I am a doctor and my education has taught me that in order to solve the problem well, it is necessary to diagnose it well, that is, to tell the truth about what is happening here and now. The safety of our children – not us, but our children – is in our hands today and depends on our decisions.  We should realise that the great challenge for our adversaries, for the great powers, is precisely destabilisation and chaos in the European Union. It is not necessary to balance the open door, just get acquainted with gierasimov's strategy (Gierasimov was the chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation). He wrote in seven points what needed to be done to destabilize another country without entering it with a single tank. Let us answer the question whether these processes are not happening in our countries.  The first point of Gierasimov's strategy is social disintegration, opposing social groups, building better and worse. The second point of Gierasimov's strategy is the devaluation of elites and the exchange of elites among the people who today represent, on people who will be easier to control and manipulate. The third point is the disorganisation of state administration – let us answer the question whether this is not happening today in the European Union and in the Member States. The next point, the fourth, gierasimov's strategy is the centralization of power – we have to answer ourselves, is power not centralized today, which is easier to control afterwards? After all, there is a change of history, a change of historical heroes, a change in historical truth. And the last point of the strategy is to destroy the law. Let us answer the question whether Gierasimov did not foresee an effective method of disinformation and chaos.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, democracy is part of our genetic matrix. For her we have fought hard and we are a global reference of the rule of law, freedom of expression and political choice. But today we are faced with new challenges, diffuse, disseminated by the increasingly strong torrent of information, true or manipulated, inducing emotions and contexts that influence the results and the choice of voters, from virtual territories not delimited by physical borders. And that's why we have to fight a global fight. And what weapons do we have? Widespread digital literacy and universal internet access are a key basis. The application of shared values, as an embryo of a European digital identity, is very urgent.  Deepening an internal ethical code and included in our international partnerships makes more sense than ever. We must unite around the defence of European democracy and make every citizen a soldier in this fight, before others continue to recruit them to ultimately weaken us.

name: Dragoş Tudorache (Renew).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, I would like to talk today about responsibilities. The first is the responsibility of those who command, direct or finance actions to undermine democratic processes in our Member States. Let's put it very clearly, this is a form of asymmetric aggression for which Russia is responsible, and our political response must remain as firm as possible. Secondly, we are talking about a responsibility of those who manage the technologies used for such subversive actions. The code of conduct signed with major online platforms is a good step. If that's enough, it remains to be seen. We must maintain our political space of analysis and appreciation and demand that these platforms be as transparent and accountable as possible. The third is our responsibility, the European institutions. If we take these threats to democracy seriously, we must allocate the necessary resources to combat them. It is a responsibility that I propose that we discuss seriously in future budgetary debates. Thanks.

name: Jaak Madison (ID).
text: – Mr President, this is a very important topic, and foreign and local interference in European democracies and elections is a clear and direct violation of Member States sovereignty and should be treated as such. It is key for all Member States to ensure that, specifically in relation to cyber threats, security policies are developed and effectively implemented.  However, the current trend of blaming an unfavourable election result on foreign interference must end. The left has been notorious in blaming election results that do not suit them on interference from a foreign power. This not only undercuts European democracies but also underestimates the intelligence of European voters. Equally, the impact of the distribution of this information by foreign powers and local actors alike must not be underestimated.  It should also be pointed out that right-wing political parties have been disproportionately and unfairly accused of using and benefiting from such disinformation. In this regard. I will therefore emphasise that all forms of disinformation should be countered even when directed against right-wing political parties, in accordance with the European values of equality, rule of law and democracy.

name: Geoffroy Didier (PPE).
text: Mr President, in this debate, it is not a question of preventing the leaders of a foreign country from displaying their preferences, let alone their worldview. We remember, for example, that François Hollande had - wrongly, of course - made Hillary Clinton the future president of the United States in 2016. We remember that a year later, Emmanuel Macron had suggested to the Poles - not without a certain arrogance, for that matter - to acquire better leaders. The purpose of this debate should not be to hope that politicians will no longer be able to give their opinion. The real question is the nature of the means used. Today, some foreign powers have understood that more than half of Europeans only find out about social networks. Thanks to the misuse of algorithms, bots and artificial intelligence, many European Internet users unfortunately end up believing anonymous people, who post defamatory and hateful opinions, more than their democratically elected leaders. On Twitter, more than 150,000 Russian-speaking accounts were created in English in 2016, weeks before the Brexit referendum, to destabilise Europe. I am announcing that in the coming days I will be taking up the new European Commission, which I congratulate, to set up a programme to detect converging messages from foreign powers, in order to alert the population on social networks during an election campaign. The technological means of this ambition exist perfectly, and the role of the European Union is to be much more offensive and to compete with the manipulators on their own ground. European Internet users are not destined to become digital valets of Russian or American interests. Let us share with us this beautiful conviction of Hannah Arendt, who said: "Totalitarianism is when the distinction between fact and fiction no longer exists". The naivety of Europe is unfortunately not a fiction, so let us at least make the reactivity of the European Union a reality.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, congratulations, Commissioner, on your re-election. Sure, this isn't the first time we've debated this subject. The European Union has been declaring since 2015 that it will actively deal with misinformation and fake news. But here's what we have now: half of the OECD member countries where there were elections in 2018 have been targeted by cyberattacks, three times more than in 2015. Obviously, we live in the age of social media and voters are the main target, even more so than candidates in elections. We all know in our country that this is happening. Foreign online interference is the immediate objective, obviously, of manipulating information and changing the voter's opinion. We must not, Commissioner, run away from regulation. Democracy isn't just about rights, it's not chaos. Without restricting freedom of the press, we must take the decision and you have Parliament's resolution.
