Maybe our policy of softly-softly in the region is not delivering the results we wanted. I wondered what advice the High Representative would have for her successor regarding how they should look at a new strategy. (The speaker declined to answer a blue-card question from Mr Băsescu)

name: Bernard Guetta (Renew).
text: Madam President, it was a duty and a necessity. As the Union was to open up to the countries of Central Europe, it had to offer a partnership to the Eastern country whose enlargement had made our new neighbours. This partnership has its weaknesses and successes, but ten years later, it must be obvious to us: in our Eastern partnership, we have forgotten Russia or, more precisely, we did not want to see it, as the problems it poses seemed intractable to us. Today, we must work to repair this political cowardice by exploring the possibility of new Helsinki agreements with Moscow, security agreements and cooperation. It will be difficult, they will say. No, it will be extremely difficult and totally uncertain, but we must try to do so because the Russian Federation is the other half of the continent, the largest country in the world; an impoverished and dilapidated country, whose capacity for nuisance remains considerable.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the European Union has been developing particularly good relations with its immediate neighbours for many years. How important such an approach can be and how much potential still lies there, we have seen during the migrant crisis. Better relations with neighbours and stronger political-trade relations with them would be a guarantee of greater resilience to such crises. There are several countries in our east with whom we develop good relations under the Eastern Partnership, but there is a long way to go towards becoming stable partners for us. Some of these states are still in a state of war, and some are in the midst of a transitional path that is extremely painful. All these countries are also extremely important to us in terms of positioning themselves towards Russia. The European interest here must be to develop them into fully functioning democracies with a developed rule of law and market freedom. We need partners like that and it pays to invest in. (The Representative agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, here, Mrs. Tomašić, I am very pleased that you are praising, as I understand it, the foreign policy of the European Union and advocating for common solutions and common interests. Given this and on the track of what you have said now, do you think that the Competences of the European Union in foreign policy need to be strengthened so that this foreign policy is even stronger and that it can strengthen relations with these countries that you mentioned?

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, of course I think that our positions should be strengthened, but in cooperation with all Member States. So not only does Brussels decide what happens, but that all Member States can decide.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I want to refer to two eastern european countries, Ukraine and the Republic of Moldova. Ukraine is a country badly hit by the Russian Federation, a country that lost Crimea, which actually has a civil war disguised in the east of the territory, a country that has ports often blocked on the Black Sea.  Why this? Because the Russian Federation cannot accept this country's orientation towards the European Union. The solution for Ukraine to remain whole is to be supported and helped by European experts, showing the government the error, if the Steinmeier plan were to be implemented. It is the risk of losing eastern Ukraine, because a referendum will follow after federalisation and the declaration of independence will follow, as in Hosetia, in Abkhazia, in Crimea. It's Russian technique.  In connection with the Republic of Moldova, unfortunately Mrs. Maia Sandu has entered the situation of losing the government alone. In Moldova it is a paradox. The opposition, which consists of two pro-European parties, is witnessing a tough, minority government of pro-Russian Dodon. It is time for the European Union, which invests money, to ask the two opposition leaders and, I repeat, to do their duty to the Republic of Moldova, reorienting the country, taking over the government and reorienting the country to the west.

name: Петър Витанов (S&D).
text: – Madam President, High Representative, the European Union's policy towards its eastern neighbours was once declared a high-priority policy and, on the other hand, highly underestimated and negligible because of the problem points in individual countries, in relations between them or in relations with the European Union. And it is as if we are taking into account more the huge deposits of energy raw materials and the possibilities for their transfer to European markets than the serious geostrality of the region. At the same time, this region is an arena of opposition to two competing concepts: that of European integration and of the European cooperative. Ten years from now, the Eastern Partnership should do two things. First, a frank overview of what has been achieved so far and, secondly, a greater commitment of the European Union to setting the next priorities for developing cooperation in the region needs to be demonstrated. Because otherwise we risk pushing countries into another political orbit and facilitating the realisation of foreign interests of the Community.

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew).
text: – Madam President, a direct message to those concerned. The dismissal and lightning replacement of the pro-European government in Chisinau following The Courage of Maia Sandu not to play President Dodon's game and not to subordinate the justice of the political interests of some oligarchs or the proposal of the Tbilisi government to change the electoral law so that the power to secure its seats in Parliament are big steps back on the way to Europe. The guilty must feel responsible, because they are taking the citizens of their countries away from the European Union and its benefits. Strict conditionality is a firm principle in providing macro-financial assistance, but it is time for the Union to invest much more in explaining to the citizens of these states why conditionalities are important and what reform entails. Otherwise any anti-reform government hijacks the discourse into an anti-EU one and we start over forever. The countries in the eastern neighbourhood must truly be a priority of the new Commission, and the door of Europe must remain open, invest in these countries economically, energetically and really finance pro-democracy, pro-justice and pro-rule reforms.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam High Representative, i would like to thank you for your excellent work The Eastern Partnership is an important instrument. Maybe we used to have all the higher hopes for him, but he's still needed, he's still a bridge. Note! It seems to me that, of course, formally, we can divide these six countries into three groups: the pellet of primate mentioned by Andrzej Halicki, my esteemed colleague, Ukraine, Georgia, Moldova. Two countries that have signed agreements with Russia, Belarus and Armenia. And Azerbaijan, which is neither here nor here. However, It seems to me that we should be open to all six countries. Let us not turn our backs on Belarus and Armenia, so as not to hand them over to Russia. Let us cooperate very strongly with Azerbaijan, rewarding the country for the certain neutrality it has demonstrated and the fact that it has not signed any economic agreements with Moscow. It seems to me that here we should also be very open to those countries that have not yet signed association agreements with us. And here I appeal.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the Vice—President / High Representative and thank her for all the work she has done in promoting the Eastern Partnership. This is such a strong tool for peace and reconciliation and for the security of the European Union. Together with the Committee on Foreign Affairs all of us are working hard to get citizens of these countries to understand that European values are the only values that will transform their societies and bring better things for their societies, and we will continue working on it. I strongly support the idea of my colleague, Mr Kubilius, to focus on three countries that we are still hoping will get on the right track. We have provided visa—free travel and all the opportunities for young people, and we have provided them with a window of opportunity to see how much the European Union can contribute to better their societies. I hope that this Parliament and the new Commission will continue along this path and the Commission will have the strongest allies in us.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear Mrs Mogherini, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The experience of ten years of the Eastern Partnership justifies the need for its continued existence. Minister Sikorski, the creator of this idea, is with us in the chamber. However, decisions are needed to respond to new challenges and dilemmas. The main problem is the partnership model, which, on the one hand, integrates economically and to a lesser extent politically the countries belonging to it with the European Union and, on the other hand, retains it at the pre-accession stage. The partnership as it used to be is regarded by members as a kind of alternative to full membership of the European Union.  After ten years, something has to be decided on, because maintaining the existing model will not bring success. I believe that our Eastern partners should receive a clear message from us as to their future in the European Union.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, we are celebrating ten years of the Eastern Partnership and we can say that this programme has indeed proved successful. Of course, that wasn't easy. The fact is that Eurasia is an area where the key interests of the world's geopolitical players interbreed, where more than 70% of the world's population lives, where 75% of the world's energy reserves are located. And of course there is also Russia and China and many other countries seeing their interest, and the European Union of course needs to define its own.  In this sense, really good results have been achieved, but unfortunately we see that in some countries we have a reverse process, that certain democratic standards are being lowered and that the process of adopting Western standards of democracy and the protection of human rights unfortunately does not go as we should perhaps all together.  Here I would send three messages of what I think the European Union should do, what principles should guide its policies. First, it should be unique. We must not allow the individual geopolitical interests of some Member States of the European Union to impede the achievement or undermine the credibility of a common European policy. This uniqueness, this definition of common interests is the only way for the European Union to be a serious player on the world stage.  Secondly, the European Union needs to be clear and open, without a finger in its pocket. It needs to clearly define its interests and in this open and transparent way approach those pro-European and pro-Western forces in these countries in this area.  And third thing, the European Union needs to deliver on its promises. Without fulfilling promises, without honoring those results achieved in individual countries in the long term, these countries will lose any motive to approach Europe, to approach the West.  Of course, negative phenomena should be condemned, but all those positive things should also be honored. And I would emphasize that no one is good just because they are pro-Western oriented, political or words-oriented, but should show it by deeds. Respecting all those standards on which the European Union is founded and which we all protect, namely the rule of law and the protection of human rights, democracy and freedom.

name: Monika Beňová (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Mrs Mogherini for her five years' work and commitment, but if you will allow me, I would now like to address the new Commission and also the individual Member States so that they are consistent and accountable in the future. We cannot allow us to abandon our eastern neighbours, and I think it is wrong that we have stopped the accession processes with Macedonia and Albania. Macedonia in specialty has made huge decisions and a lot of work to disincentive them in this way, and we must be aware that such decisions are also disincentives for our eastern partners. A stable neighbourhood is essential for the EU. Also for the sake of stability, prosperity and security here in the EU. Cooperation with our Eastern partners is also a huge opportunity to spread European ideas. Accession negotiations, as well as international cooperation to the east, also serve as a tool for spreading the values that we want to dominate the world. Ukraine, Moldova, Armenia look to Europe, so we should not disappoint them with our negative attitudes in the future.

name: Jarosław Duda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As a preliminary point, I would like to express my satisfaction with the progress made by the Eastern Partnership countries, despite the difficulties mentioned here, and in particular with the progress made by Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova in making changes to further integrate into the European Union. I believe that the Union should send a clear signal that it appreciates the efforts and determination of these countries. I support the initiative to develop a Trio 2030 strategy offering concrete long-term instruments to support further reforms and investments. The road to European integration is not easy. We in Poland remember this. We value and want to support the efforts of our eastern neighbours all the more. In particular, I would like to refer to the progress of reforms in Ukraine. I congratulate the new authorities on their enthusiasm and courage in making the changes that both Ukrainian society and eu partners are waiting for. The fight against corruption, judicial reform, responsible and effective governance are great challenges. The progress of decentralisation and the strengthening of civil society are also crucial for the development of Ukrainian democracy.  However, while appreciating the determination of the authorities, I would like to stress the importance of extensive consultation, the inclusion of all partners – including civil society – at all levels of change. This is essential for both public acceptance, effective implementation and sustainability of reforms.  I would also like to highlight the positive impact of Ukraine's participation in European programmes, including the numerous participation of young people in the Erasmus+ programme. My meetings with fantastic, knowledge-hungry, ambitious, open Ukrainian youth make me very optimistic.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say that I am pleased that we can evaluate this partnership here after ten years. Ten years ago, it was launched when the Czech Republic was president of the European Union, and that's when we Czechs stood by it. I also remember those debates on the part of the Czech Government, in which I had the honour of being, when the main philosophy was to help countries that are between the European Union and Russia, fill this space and, unfortunately, are often under enormous pressure and influence from Russia. I think this partnership fulfils this geopolitical reason. If we were to vacate this area and stop communicating with these countries, to support them, I fear that russia's influence, which has unfortunately been increasing in some of these countries recently, see Moldova, for example, would increase even further in the future. So the geopolitical plane here is unequivocal, but then there is the simple reason that these are countries whose people, at least in no small part, want to live in freedom, democracy and prosperous states. These are our European values that we should support in these states. I think that, despite some problems, this partnership can be evaluated positively and we should intensify and strengthen this cooperation for the next decade. It must be said, as some colleagues have said, that these six countries do not logically have a unified development – there are some internal problems, there are varying degrees of Ingerence of Russia – and that we should therefore have a different strategy for individual states. But the general trend that such a partnership makes sense, that we should promote cooperation between these states and the European Union is, I think, unequivocal, and it is by no means that these states should be entering the European Union any time soon.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the response to developments in the Balkans after the European Council refused to open negotiations on the accession of North Macedonia and Albania to the EU shows that the EU cannot afford to gamble with friendship and good relations with neighbouring countries. Otherwise, he's losing geopolitically. And other powers, such as Russia or China, or possibly Iran, are keen to take its place. It is therefore good that the EU continues to strengthen its relations with countries to the east of it, at different levels. That is why it is for the benefit of our people, as well as the people of these countries. Differentiation is the key word for eastern neighbourhood policy. This means that we need to differentiate between countries. Of some, we already have an association agreement, with others only some good trade relations, but with each of us we must strive to ensure that those relations also go deep and that they are also in our favour in the fields of energy, transport or student exchange, or in the area of culture. Like each of the states, Ukraine, Georgia, Moldava and Armenia, Azerbaijan, and even Belarus must have a really good place in our policy. And I think we can also help them in their reform, such as the judiciary or other areas.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Ms Mogherini, you said that the Eastern Partnerships are not against anyone. Would you not do not admit that US and European involvement in Ukraine has very much an anti-Russian element to it? I think it would be very hard to ignore that. Do you not think that if Russia was interfering in Canada or Mexico that there would be serious tensions also with America? Do you not think that it is about time that Europe worked for peace with Russia? The European project was built on a peaceful one, and it would make so much more sense now to look for peace with Russia and engage those countries around it, make them independent, so they don’t need the West or Russia. At the moment, Europe is increasing its militarisation, instead of decreasing it. We are liable to go into another arms race. Why don’t we work with Russia and lift the sanctions? Ms Mogherini, I haven't been here very long and we haven’t agreed on very much, but I’ll still miss you. Good luck.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the Eastern Partnership I think is the greatest achievement on foreign policy in the last ten years, but it must be developed. I am from Iaşi, Romania, and I appreciate many of the cross-border projects, and Romania can be an example of good practice in terms of cross-border emergency healthcare with the Republic of Moldova or in terms of scholarships. On the other hand, I also tell you that in addition to the two hundred projects, you can also enter others. Those from the Republic of Moldova, Romanian citizens from the Republic of Moldova want those roaming charges to be the same as in the European Union. They have relatives who have gone abroad and who they cannot call, or on the other hand they can also work in Europe because, if we are at this stage where people are the most important, we can thus gain confidence in the values of the European Union and, why not, easily reach the European Union on that motorway of union financed by European funds from Targu Mureş and Iasi and Chisinau. I am convinced that you can include these projects for what you want to develop, and the Eastern Partnership will move to a new stage, because really beyond geostrategy, beyond politics, people are the most important, and those there, even in the east, see them as European citizens over the next ten years.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Oleg Sentsov’s visit to our European Parliament this week to receive his well—deserved 2018 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought reminds us of the terrible price still being paid every day by the Ukrainian people for defending their territorial integrity. There’s a war going on in our Eastern neighbourhood and it’s barely mentioned in the media, yet the UN Human Rights Agency estimates that 13 000 people or more have already lost their lives in the Donbass area. The illegal annexation of Crimea is an affront to all of us who care about democracy. I’m proud that this Parliament supports Ukraine and its aspirations to move closer to our European family. In 2011, I was involved in a year—long cultural exchange project with Ukrainian partners. I fell in love with the country and its people. I learned about the largely unknown Holodomor, or hunger, a planned genocide which killed 7 million Ukrainians. Russian abuses continue, and I urge colleagues to join our MEP Friends of Ukraine group, because there’s never been a more important time to reach out and embrace Ukraine.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I think this discussion shows once again the relevance of parliamentary work in support of our partnerships. I’ve said it several times, not only with the Eastern partners but also with other partners we have around the world: the role of Parliament is key. I believe that when it comes to the Eastern Partnership specifically, in the terms of both the partnership with the six countries and on the specific parliamentary work you have done and also the work you have done with the civil society and the social players that have roots in each of the six specific countries: the added value is enormous. This is quite an unusual session for debates for me because, obviously, I cannot commit for the future steps. That will be, obviously, in the wise hands of my successor and the next Commission. But I am sure that the track that was started wisely ten years ago and then followed in this most recent years – that of deepening our partnership in all fields with the six countries we have to our east – is going to be strengthened even more in the future. I’m sure that it will have the possibility of counting on your full support, as I have been privileged to be accompanied in this particular work by you, with your advisors, with your work. Many of you have thanked me for this partnership. Let me pay back by thanking you because I think that we have shown that, even if not always sharing exactly the same perspectives, but that’s the positive point of democracy. You can disagree on some points, but you can still work in the same direction on some issues. I think that, in particular on the Eastern Partnership, we have proven that Parliament, Commission, Council can work together in unison and try to bridge some of the difficulties are still lying ahead. Again, thank you for five years of support on this file and looking forward to staying in touch. But, as I was mentioning to the previous President of the session, I will stay with you for the rest of the evening and tomorrow. So that’s not yet the last word of goodbye.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over.  Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Today's debate sends a clear signal that the overall situation of our Eastern partners is becoming increasingly complicated. In this context, the question arises as to what we, as the European Union, should do. We must work – within the framework of the Eastern Partnership, but also bilateral contacts between individual Member States – to support our partners where needed. Above all, we should consider how to make the neighbourhood formula more attractive in order to encourage them to do more to strengthen cooperation with the EU and to carry out democratic reforms.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: The situation in Israel and Paleste, including in settlements (2019/2935(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me start by sharing with you a personal memory, maybe an anecdote, it is no mystery. When I took office exactly five years ago, five years and a couple of weeks ago, I paid my first visit outside of the European Union to Israel and Palestine, including a visit in Gaza. And I said at that time that I believe that a two—state solution could be achieved during my mandate. This was the goal that I kept in my mind and in my actions all of these years. And, at some points, I have to say this goal seemed to be getting closer, but we all know what the situation looks like today. This doesn’t mean that the perspective is not there and is not valid anymore. I think it is a matter of political will and political conditions, and I’ll get back to that. But today, clearly, if I paid the same visit probably I wouldn’t say that I believe that that solution could be achieved in the coming months or years. The very idea of two states today has come under attack as never before from many sides. Yet, we should all know that a two—state solution remains – I’m profoundly convinced of this – the best and the only realistic chance for peace and also for security in the holy places. This is a principled and a pragmatic position at the same time. Nobody – nobody – has presented a credible alternative to two states so far. Many have argued against, but nobody has expressed any clear view that can substitute that objective realistically. And any plan that is not firmly anchored in international law – and let me add, also in the profound aspirations and interests of the people, not only of Palestine and Israel but also of the region – would ultimately fail. Our support for the two states is a matter of international law, is a matter of justice and democracy, but, as I mentioned, is also a matter of realism. In these years, we have worked full time to avoid the dissolution of the two—states perspective. And the work continues today, even in such difficult circumstances, let me say especially in such difficult circumstances. Because sometimes we have the impression – as do some of our friends in the UN system, in the Arab world, but also a little bit farther away in Africa and Asia – that especially in this moment where it is so difficult to keep the perspective alive, that the voices of wisdom and realism need to be heard and need to speak up. This is why we have, as the objective was fading away, kept our position and our work at full speed and with all our strength. This explains our position on all recent developments. First, on settlements: we have always believed that border changes can only be decided through direct negotiations between the parties based on the pre—1967 borders. Israeli settlements in the occupied Palestinian territory are illegal under international law. They constitute an obstacle to peace and threaten to make a two—state solution impossible. In addition, settlement activity in East Jerusalem seriously jeopardises the possibility of Jerusalem serving as the future capital of both states. We have never shied away from restating this position, including just a week ago, and it is a united European position. I frequently hear many people inviting us to speak with one voice. In difficult times in difficult years, this has remained and remains the strong united European Union position. Our position is also clear and unchanged regarding the security of the state of Israel. Firing rockets on Israel’s civilian population is simply unacceptable, and I’m grateful to Egypt for their diplomatic efforts, which helped to stop the recent escalation. And I will repeat once again: Israel has the right to security, Israelis have the right to security. But we are also convinced that security will only be sustainable and real if it is built on peace and on a two-state solution. As you know, in recent years we have also worked constantly to alleviate the suffering of the people of Gaza. With the Gaza desalination plant we are providing concrete and long—lasting support which will benefit hospitals, schools, enterprises and every citizen of Gaza. Yet the crisis in Gaza is inherently political in nature and requires a political solution. The closure must end and crossings must be fully opened. At the same time it is also clear that Gaza is part of the future state of Palestine and that Palestinians themselves must find unity beyond their divisions. We know that the current political outlook is uncertain, both in Palestine and in Israel. Discussions among Palestinian factions have not yet led to a substantial reconciliation. President Abbas has announced his intention to set a date for elections. And on the Israeli side, the political stalemate continues and might lead to an unprecedented situation with the third election in just one year. It is my firm conviction that, with courageous leadership, a return to negotiations is possible. I am still convinced today, five years after my first visit as a High Representative in Palestine and Israel, that that is the goal and that is realistically achievable. Actually, I’m convinced that this is the only achievable, sustainable, realistic solution to this conflict. And let me say, personally I’m also deeply convinced that, out of all the crises and conflicts of the region of the Middle East, this is probably the easiest to settle in concrete terms, provided – and this is the most difficult thing to achieve – there is political will among the parties and among the international players to accompany this process. There won’t be peace without a strong political commitment by both sides and by the international community. On the European Union side, we have always been, and we will continue to be – I’m sure about that – ready to support, to encourage and to accompany all efforts to build peace and security and a negotiated two—state solution for Israel and Palestine.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to thank you for these five years of frank exchange of views with her here. What you have just said now on the issue of Israel and Palestine I am sure has been one of the toughest issues you have ever had to deal with. I give her all the support, and I certainly share a lot of what she has said in a situation that is logically not going to be resolved immediately, but in which we all try in good faith, from different angles of view, to participate so that there is at last a peace, which will give stability not only to the region, because of this terrible conflict that has been spending it for years , but also us Europeans, and the rest of the world. Congratulations, Vice President, on the work done. And, in our case, I want to make it clear that Israel is a preferred strategic partner with whom we share history and values. We are, after all, the European Union and Israel, democracies that we strive to promote throughout the world our principles and our vision of a world that respects the right to assistance of other States and peoples. Israel is concerned about its security. It's logical and normal. We've all seen how the cloud of rockets that came out of Gaza began. It is no less true, too, that there should be no escalations, and we welcome the slowing down of this in the end. We cannot do so with our statements; and I always have a bit of a feeling that we're always talking based on what Americans say. Let us see if we already in the European Union react and act on our own in this matter. I believe that we can contribute to dialogue, we can contribute to peace in our own way. I think it's important not to get carried away by tweets and statements. I think it is important that we work, that members of the Knesset come, as they will come ⸺I have asked for it and they will come, I believe, in two weeks' time to the Strasbourg plenary⸺; that, at the executive level, these ministerial meetings continue that were interrupted, and that we continue with that dialogue. And then the work we can do. I think it's a big mistake about the labelling on the products in the settlement areas. I think it is the other way around, the European Union should be working with Israel and the Palestinians and helping the development of the region. I think it would be necessary to make a new approach that will give more prosperity to the area. Maybe we can actually help put an end to this. Some communist comrades on the far left are already laughing. Logically, we'll listen to them. I don't want to insult anyone, I don't want to mess with anyone. I believe that, between Palestinians and Israelis, the European Union could make the right approach. Let's do it and you'll see. In my speech there has been no reference or attack on Palestine. We'll see what some teammates say. I listen carefully.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, we are extremely concerned about the recent US statement. Only days after yet another round of violence in and around the Gaza Strip, US State Secretary Pompeo announced a major U-turn of US policy towards Israeli settlements. He declared, and I quote: ‘the establishment of Israel’s civilian settlements in the West Bank is not, per se, inconsistent with international law’. This declaration clearly goes against the 4th Geneva Convention, UN Security Council resolutions and the 2004 opinion of the International Court of Justice. I welcome and fully support the immediate and strong reaction by you, High Representative. Israeli settlements are illegal under international law and Israel has the obligation to end all settlement activity as an occupying power. Pompeo’s announcement is yet another example of the Trump administration’s obsessive support for Prime Minister Netanyahu. This includes the recognition of Jerusalem as Israel’s capital, moving the US Embassy there and recognising Israel’s sovereignty over the occupied Golan Heights. It seems that the Trump administration, instead of coming up with the so-called deal of the century, has decided to play with escalating the conflict at the expense of Palestinians, Israelis and the international community at large. President Trump must understand that the Middle East is not his foreign policy playground. It is the home of millions of Israelis and Palestinians striving for peace, day after day. The steady increase in Israeli settlements in the West Bank, including in east Jerusalem, clearly undermines the prospect of any viable two-state solution. This is our only hope for a just and lasting peace in the region. It is in this spirit that we also support the recent ruling by the European Court of Justice about the labelling of Israeli settlement products in the EU market.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, I would like to thank you very much in the first place. We have debated here many times over the last five years until very late in the evening. I always enjoyed having to go into the debates with you. Moreover, I think that we have debated Israel and Palestine most often. You said it was your first shipment outside the EU. Well, I think, ladies and gentlemen, that we have debated the situation in Israel and Palestine the most many times in the last legislature, because we are concerned, and because we continue to be concerned.  If we now just look at the fact that since 2017 Israel has built up 12 000 dwellings a year in the West Bank, that 26 illegal outposts have been built, and that since 2009 no fewer than 6 000 Palestinian buildings in the West Bank have been destroyed, including buildings financed with European taxpayers' money, then I think it should be clear. Israel is working step by step towards a one-state reality, on a fragmentation of the Palestinian territory where there will soon be no room for the Palestinians at all. We can't let this happen. I would like to hear you say: 'We need political will'. Well, Europe stands for an international legal order based on rules. It's up to us to go against that power policy of Netanyahu and Trump, against the settlement politics that they are purposefully escalating. It is up to us, Europe, to continue to fight for this two-state solution, which I believe is the only solution.  Madam High Representative, it will probably be one of your last debates here in the plenary in Strasbourg. So I ask you, but also your successor, to oppose any decision that is a step back in the peace process, to act hard when our projects are destroyed and to speak out unequivocally – as you have already done against Trump and Netanyahu – when a decision violates international law. Madam High Representative, you have the support of this Parliament, and I would like to thank you once again and wish you every success in your future career, career or whatever you are going to do.

name: Grace O’Sullivan
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Trump administration’s move to recognise the illegal settlements in the West Bank is just the latest in a litany of deeply destructive interventions from a government that seems determined to wreck any chance of peace. By recognising the illegal settlements, the United States has once again put itself outside the norms of international law. It has supported those that seek to ensure that any future Palestinian state would be unviable. Israel’s right to exist is beyond debate. Any country’s right to illegally occupy territory seized in military conflicts is not beyond debate. There are differing views, I know, across the Chamber in regard to this conflict, but I believe there is a common wish to see a lasting peaceful solution that represents both sides. Each step along the road to occupation and annexation is a step away from a stable two-state agreement. What does it mean for the EU? Firstly, we know that the US has not been, and will not be, a reliable partner in this process while the current administration is in place. The EU is therefore the leading world power interested in promoting a lasting solution for the region and willing to act as an honest broker between peace-seeking elements in both governments. Secondly, we need to consider how we as an economic union can influence the situation. I do not, and will not, support the BDS Movement but, nor can I support the economic activities taking place on stolen land in contravention of international law. In the Irish Senate I supported a bill from my colleague Senator Frances Black to prohibit goods from illegal settlements being imported into Ireland, a measure that would only have called on the Irish Government to make real its commitment to the provisions of the Geneva Conventions. Currently goods grown or produced in illegal settlements in the West Bank are being imported into the EU as part of a trade agreement with Israel that does not extend to the territories. I would ask you to consider how, and why, that is allowed to continue?

name: Nicolaus Fest
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank mrs Mogherini for her excellent work and for the work she has done. You said that the two-state solution was the best, the most sustainable and the most pragmatic solution. The opposite is true. The two-state solution has long been an expression of the EU's political cluelessness and loss of reality. The two-state solution means the return of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Will this bring peace? No. Let us remember that in 2000 Yasser Arafat rejected a very generous offer to exchange territory. In 2008, Mahmoud Abbas did exactly the same thing. When Israel withdrew in 2005, Hamas immediately demanded the total liberation of Palestine, i.e. the expulsion and murder of all Israelis. Finally, understand that Hamas and Al Fatah are not concerned with the West Bank, nor are they concerned with Gaza. They are concerned with Haifa, tel aviv and also with Jerusalem. You spoke, Mrs Mogherini, of the political will needed to solve this problem. Please take note of this at long last: there is no will on the part of the Palestinians, the Palestinian leadership, nor will it exist. That is why your policy, the policy of a two-state solution, is wrong.

name: Bert-Jan Ruissen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, Secretary Pompeo's statement on settlements has caused a great deal of controversy, but in the meantime he certainly had a point. Those who describe the settlements as illegal use very big words. It does not do justice to the complexity of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, pre-emes the outcome of necessary peace talks and ignores israel's failure to make legitimate claims in the territories concerned, both historically and legally. These are not occupied territories, but actually disputed areas, for which a solution can only be found through negotiation. I would therefore urge the High Representative not to put any energy into the exchange with the US on this issue. Then we're not going to get any further. Instead, invest in measures that do matter that can bring peace in the area closer. That is why I say: stop supporting terrorists and their families indirectly through the Palestinian Authority, following a recent decision by the Netherlands. Stop paying to UNRWA, which has maintained an unhealthy refugee situation for decades. And opt for a much tougher stance towards Iran, which plays a very aggressive and dubious role in the region.

name: Manu Pineda
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate Mrs Mogherini on her statement following Mr Pompeo's statements in which she gave a letter of guarantee to illegal Israeli settlements in occupied Palestinian territory. I would like to congratulate you on the content of the statement and on the immediacy of your reaction. And I would also like to point out that this has been a constant in his tenure. I hope — and I am convinced that this will be the case — that with Mr Borrell it will remain the same. But we will have to agree, Mrs Mogherini, that although these statements have always been timely and necessary, and have value — they have value because they are somehow opposing Israel's systematic violation of the human rights of the Palestinian people and international law — the effect has been very limited.  The Oslo Accords are reached by the generosity of the Palestinian people, who cede 78% of their territory and recognize the occupying power as a state in exchange for the remaining 22% establishing a Palestinian state. That's signed in the Oslo Accords.  Israel has violated the Agreements from the outing point, and not just the Agreements: it has violated international law and UN Resolutions. In the meantime, Palestine has comprehensively fulfilled all its commitments.  What are Israel's non-compliances that I can set an example for? The blockade of Gaza; systematic bombing of Gaza's civilian population; ten or twelve days ago, the last attack. Because Netanyahu has an internal problem, he solves it by bombing Gaza, causing. Rockets are coming... I ask you to move from words to deeds.  The European Union must recognise the Palestinian state and encourage Member States to recognise it as well. And we have to question, suspend the Treaty... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Lance Forman (NI).
text: – Madam President, it is a lie that Israeli settlements are illegal. Disputed, yes, illegal no. Israel’s future boundaries were drawn up in the 1920 San Remo Agreement and confirmed by the League of Nations in 1922. No other internationally legally binding agreement has ever superseded that, and the West Bank is part of Israel in that agreement. it is never been a separate sovereign state. When the British left in 1948, war broke out between Arabs and Jews, and the West Bank was seized by Jordan. But their annexation was never recognised. So, when Israel took back control of its land 19 years later in a defensive six-day war in 1967, it did not cross an international boundary. So, those who say the settlements are illegal are completely misinterpreting Article 49 of the 4th Geneva Convention. Two weeks ago, the EU passed a law forcing Jewish-owned businesses in the West Bank to label their goods differently to non-Jews. This racist law, reminding us of an earlier periods in European history, will not lead to peace in the region. The EU should be ashamed of itself for perpetuating the myth that settlements are illegal under international law when that ruling lacks legal evidence. Someone once said, ‘if you tell a lie big enough and keep repeating it, people will eventually come to believe it’. You know who that person was. And it’s time Europe moves on. Peace can only come if it is based on truth.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the High Commissioner for these positive words and that bringing in the Middle East, bringing peace between Israel and Palestine will be a lasting peace and it can be easily done if we can open the channels of communication. I must remind you that Israel is an important partner for the European Union. Colleagues in this House have declared several times the importance of a comprehensive solution in the Middle East to end the conflict and contribute to the security and stability in the region, and that includes also a safe Israeli state. The EU has to remain relevant as an honest and balanced broker in the future of the political process between Israel and Palestine.  Lasting peace can be based only on an enduring commitment to non-violence, justice and mutual recognition, building upon previous agreements and legal obligations. The two-state solution envisaged in the region, where two states, Israel and Palestine, live side by side in peace within secure and recognised borders. I must remind you that Israel has been singled out many times in the UN Human Rights Council and that’s not right. Israel shouldn’t be the only country that is being treated separately from other countries and this should be corrected as the EU is financing a multilateral system and it should be an honest broker that includes Israel that is the greatest democracy in this part of the region.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, the Security Council reaffirms that Israel's establishment of settlements in the Palestinian territory occupied since 1967, including East Jerusalem, has no basis in law and constitutes a flagrant violation of international law and a major obstacle to achieving the two-state solution and the establishment of a comprehensive and lasting peace. This is paragraph 1 of Security Council Resolution 2334 of 2016. Under international law, the Golan Heights and the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, are not part of the Israeli territories (point 16 of the 12 November 2019 judgment of the European Court of Justice), and I could continue to list references under international and European law decreeing the illegality of settlements; The list is long. In this context, Mr. Pompeo's announcement on 18 November appears to be an additional provocation. What should we do? Respect international law, respect European law. I thank Mrs Mogherini for the work she has done in both directions, in respect of international law - the 1967 borders - but also in respect of European law. The Court of Justice reminds us that on 12 November it obliges the European Union and the Member States to guarantee the consumer correct and precise labelling, distinguishing products from the Palestinian territories, or Israeli territories, or its colonies. We are in the European Parliament, you are in the Commission, we must all respect international and European law; it is our duty, it is our responsibility.

name: Javier Nart (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the main asset in international relations is not military force but economic power. The European Union should therefore be the main strategic player in the Israel-Palestine conflict. But Israel systematically violates United Nations resolutions, the Fourth Geneva Convention and the Association Agreement itself with the European Union ⸻and I quote verbatim⸻, which determines and is based on respect for democratic principles and human rights, constituting an essential element of the Agreement. I ask: When will we enforce this Agreement? Cooperation, yes, but with whom it meets. And, if that were not enough, our supposed ally, the United States, ignores us, dynamiting the Oslo accords, recognizing Israeli sovereignty over the occupied territories. We are irrelevant, because they do not respect us and because we do not respect ourselves. Half a century of occupation is somewhat intolerable, inadmissible. All convictions are left, because they are perfectly useless. Let's move on to the facts.

name: Mounir Satouri (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, at a time when the United States is reinventing international law as it sees fit, I welcome legal sobriety and European consistency. In accordance with international law, the judgment of the European Court of Justice reiterates its position. It distinguishes Israel from its settlements in the West Bank, East Jerusalem and the Syrian Golan Heights, which is essential. As we know, colonization is a real obstacle to peace. Since 1967, not to mention East Jerusalem, we have gone from 16,000 to 427,000 settlers, that's the 2018 figures of the Israeli organization Peace Now. Thank you, therefore, to Europe, which remains strong on its values, but it is also time for our Europe to live up to its actions. It is time to help make peace in practice. The European Union has sufficiently proclaimed the law; it is now up to them to apply it and enforce it, because it has the means to do so. It is up to the Commission to ensure that Member States comply with the labelling of colonial products. It is also the Council's responsibility to have the courage to go further and to take responsibility for enforcing international law.

name: Elena Lizzi (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative Mogherini, according to the US Secretary of State, Jewish settlements in the West Bank do not violate international law. The judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union, on the other hand, requires Israel to signal on the label of its products if they come from settlements located in one of the so-called occupied territories. Why is Europe not interested in labelling in the same way any product of the more than two hundred territorial disputes in the world? The protests of Arab-Sunni states to Washington's policy have been weak and make it clear that Iranian action is the main concern. The European Union continues to strike at Israel, the only true democracy in the Middle East, when Islamic terrorism should be the enemy to be combated. The European Union allocates millions of euros to Islamic Turkey but forgets to label it for the occupation of Cyprus. Is Netanyahu right to talk about a new anti-Semitism in Europe?

name: Alexandr Vondra (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I think that the settlement issue is a part of the broader framework of the negotiations between Israel and Palestine, and singling it out does not contribute to the promotion of peace. Israel is an important partner for the European Union in the area of security, in the area of economy, and with shared values. We need Israel and Israel needs us. The EU has to remain relevant in a future political process between Israel and Palestine, and to be received as an honest and balanced broker it’s important for the EU not to undermine its position by mishandling this. Peace between Israelis and Palestinians can only be when the Palestinians are under one legitimate, democratic leadership that rejects all violence, and Europe here has to be not just a payer but also a player. The EU must therefore use this leverage to end the ‘pay-for-slay’ scheme, to end the systematic incitement of the Palestinian Authority and, last but not least, to work to phase out a United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) whose mandate perpetuates the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá mé sásta a bheith anseo ag caint ar an díospóireacht seo inniu mar... finally the European Court of Justice ruled that the selling of food and drink produced in illegal settlements and stolen Palestinian land must be labelled, and that’s a start. However, this does not go nearly far enough. The UN special rapporteur, Michael Lynk, was right when he said any trade or investment with Israeli settlements provides them with the economic oxygen to continue to grow. We in the EU cannot call these settlements illegal and an obstacle to peace and, at the same time, continue to provide them with the economic means to thrive. Trade with illegal settlements makes us complicit in the oppression of the Palestinian people.  Both houses of the Oireachtas is Ireland have voted in favour of a bill which would prohibit imports from illegal settlements, yet the Irish government continues to block this legislation. Member States, including Ireland, wax lyrical about supporting the two- state solution but fail to recognise one of these states – Palestine. Fence-sitting by EU Member States emboldens the unstable Trump administration and its dangerous policy towards Israel. (The President interrupted the speaker) I have one and a half minutes, Chair. For years we’ve had and we’ve heard mealy-mouth sentiments from the EU about Israeli violence, Israeli violation of human rights and breaches to the EU and yet the EU applies moral equivalence to the occupier and the occupied. Is mór an náire é.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in a move that is perhaps not too unexpected, given the precedents, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced on 18 November a radical change in US policy on Israeli settlements in the West Bank, stating that they will no longer consider them illegal, which do not correspond to international law. With this unholy decision, the US administration has, probably definitively, given up being a credible mediator in the Middle East conflict and, at the same time, dealt a further painful blow to the prospects for a two-state solution. It's really hard, given the situation, but I want to be constructive. With the United States voluntarily abdicating the impartiality necessary to play this role, it is now more than ever up to the Union to take a step forward and try to resurrect from the ashes a peace process that is so complex, but absolutely necessary. In fact, while the entire Middle East is on fire, there is a tendency to put the decades-long Israeli-Palestinian conflict in the background, deeming it a non-priority, a status quo that is ultimately 'sustainable'. This is a big mistake. It is in fact the mother of all regional disputes and its solution is a sine qua non for the stability of the entire macro area. I would like to thank the outgoing High Representative for his commitment and ask the new Commission and the new High Representative to have courage and to show initiative, coming before the parties, Israel and Palestine, with a new roadmap, with a new concrete proposal and a new hope. Respect for international law, respect for the judgments of our Court of Justice and consistency. We owe it to our values, we owe it to our role as credible mediators, otherwise we will lose another chance to be truly decisive in our neighbourhood.

name: Lukas Mandl (PPE).
text: – Madam President, there is a political aspect, there is a moral aspect, there is the role of the European Union, and there is the overall position of the European Union. The moral aspect, in my view, is that we are talking about the only Jewish state on this planet, and we are talking about the ancient home of the Jewish people, which has been the home of the Jewish people not only for decades or for centuries, but for thousands of years. So who are we as the European Parliament to judge any Jew who settles there? Then there is the political aspect. If we isolate the question of settlements from everything else, this would mean violating the peace process, not to support it. Because it is only one aspect of many different aspects. The role of the European Union in the peace process must be the one of an honest broker, of a force that underlines that security is the thing that Israel needs. Security is the thing that is needed and that’s why it is important that Israel remains in control of the areas where threats for the civilians in Israel come from. And as long as there is not security provided from these areas, it is important that this control remains and the peace process needs the EU as an honest broker. The overall position of the European Union must be, more than ever, to stand beside Israel in order to support Israel. Israel is the only democracy, the only rule of law state in the Middle East. Ms Mogherini, thank you for your work. I will also demand that this is the position of the EU, and is clearly underlined in the work of your successor.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Two democratic states – Israel and Palestine – living in peace, security and security side by side are the objective, but this requires all sides to respect common commitments and international law. The current situation runs counter to that. Nor does it help that other global players such as the US are contributing to polarisation rather than a solution, including by moving the Us Embassy to Jerusalem and most recently by declaring that they no longer see Israeli settlements as illegal. An important step a two-state solution is to also recognise Palestine as a state. More states should have followed Sweden's example in 2014. The occupation must be brought to an end if people in both countries are to live in peace and freedom. As Vice-President of the EU Delegation for Relations with Palestine, I would like to see the EU do more. These include the occupation. It's about settlements. These are products from settler areas, and they are also about humanitarian aid. Unfortunately, buildings and other types of infrastructure contributed by the EU and the Member States are constantly being destroyed by the Israeli military. My question is therefore quite simple: what is the Commission doing to ensure that this does not continue, and what is the Commission doing to ensure that we are compensated by the Israeli authorities for all destroyed and confiscated buildings?

name: Klemen Grošelj (Renew).
text: – Madam President! The settlement of the Palestinian issue is increasingly moving away following President Trump's decision on the capital Jerusalem and the status of Israeli settlements in Palestinian areas. At the same time, the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territories is deepening, especially in Gaza.  I cannot get rid of the impression that, because of its narrow self-interest, a part of the international community does not want a lasting solution to the Palestinian issue and even fits the status quo.  I believe that, within the framework of the common foreign and security policy, the European Union must insist more decisively on the two-state solution already agreed, and it must ask Israel to break with the policy of expanding settlements in the Palestinian territories.  But also ask all parties to return to the negotiating table and to find a lasting peaceful solution to this issue.  Notwithstanding recent moves and violence, the fact remains that this issue, which is an issue for everyone in the Middle East, cannot be resolved differently than at the negotiating table.

name: Gina Dowding (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, it is time for the EU to step up as the neutral peace broker in Israel and Palestine. That requires an unwavering commitment to international law. That is why last week’s ruling by our Court of Justice is so important. Products from illegal Israeli settlements must now be labelled as such, and now concrete steps must be taken to enforce the Court’s judgment. This is the first step.  Going forward, the EU needs to impose a ban on all imports of settlement products into the EU. Similar measures have been taken with products from Crimea and Northern Cyprus; why not from the settlements? The UN should urgently release the database of companies operating in Israeli settlements that are profiting from their construction and growth. Together these will send a clear message to the world. Any attempts to legitimise annexation and contravene international law will have concrete repercussions. Finally, I would like to ask the High Representative and her successor what other concrete steps will the EU take to ensure international law remains a respected point of reference for the Middle East peace process?

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I must confess that I am always nervous when there is talk of Israel here in the European Parliament, because it rarely comes out of something objective and balanced. I think that, above all, we should think about what is important for Europe and what will bring an advantage to its citizens. We should be able to read the geopolitical map, to realise that Israel is an important regional partner, perhaps the most important for the European Union, especially in the security area. When we talk so often about European values, we should be able to recognise that Israel is a European country in terms of all possible parameters, it is a parliamentary democracy, it is a country where the law rules, and it is simply a European country, even though it is not on the European continent, so we should show it fundamental solidarity. Last but not least, in a situation of growing anti-Semitism in many European countries, any symbolic undermining of Israel's position is just a recording of those anti-Semitic sentiments. So I would call for a much more balanced approach by the European Union, and I think we should be in solidarity with Israel.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European Union cannot be complicit in apartheid in Palestine. Trade and military relations with Israeli companies and institutions involved in serious human rights violations against the Palestinian people: this is how the European Union's complicity with apartheid suffered by the Palestinians materializes. The European Union has also refused to enforce the human rights clause that its Association Agreement with Israel envisages. Nor are the countless organizations that demand that crimes against the Palestinian people be no longer supported.  It is precisely European civil society, with campaigns like BDS, the only one that is facing human rights violations by Israel. And that's why she's just being criminalized. From here, all our solidarity with civil society.  It is time to put measures on the table: the recognition of the Palestinian people, the end of the occupation, the arms embargo on Israel until human rights are respected, and the prohibition of imports from illegal settlements. Touch (inaudible words) measures, we can't keep looking the other way.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Mr President, the recognition by the United States of America of Israeli settlements in the West Bank, the so-called 'agreement of the century', which essentially legitimises the illegal posting and occupation of Palestinian land by Israel, and the recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, are rewarding the escalation of aggression towards the Palestinian people, which is affected by assassinations - even of minor children - attacks, settlements , the "wall of shame", thousands of political prisoners. The European Union has great responsibilities, it keeps an equal distance, identifying the victim - the Palestinian people - with the perpetrator, Israel. Her stance gives her an alibi and fuels the continuation of the Israeli state's atrocities in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. The Greek governments of SW and SYRIZA also have heavy responsibilities: they have continuously expanded and upgraded political, economic, military cooperation with the Israeli state. We support the fair struggle of the Palestinian people and demand: the creation of an independent and sovereign Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital, the withdrawal of the Israeli army from the occupied territories, the cessation of settlement activity and the withdrawal of all settlers, the tearing down of the 'wall of shame', the return of Palestinian refugees to their homes, the immediate release of all Palestinian political prisoners. We demand that the decisions of the parliaments of 14 Member States, including Greece since 2015, which have recognised the Palestinian state, come into force now.

name: Anna-Michelle Asimakopoulou (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in this House, I’m going to state the obvious: we are not deaf, we are not blind, and we are not mute. We are certainly not deaf: we’ve heard the European Union’s position on Israeli settlement policy. We heard it, in fact, from the High Representative here today, as we have heard it many times in the past, including last week. We’ve certainly heard President Donald Trump, as well as Secretary Pompeo, speak very clearly on Israel. We’re also not blind: for decades we’ve seen blood-soaking terrorist attacks against Israeli civilians. I’ve seen this with my own eyes, in fact, in the Nahal Oz kibbutz, which is very close to the Gaza Strip, where four-year-old Daniel was murdered inside his own home by Hamas rockets. I’ve seen this with my own eyes, looking over villages – Israeli villages – near the Golan Heights, where the local population is often used as a human shield against Hezbollah-smuggled missiles, which are being used to attack Israeli citizens. It’s quite plain to see, in fact, that Israel has legitimate security concerns. We’re also not mute: in fact, the European Union has been very vocal in the past as a voice of peace and stability in the region. Israel is one of Europe’s closest allies and we share so many common values and common interests. What we need to do now is to advance a common bilateral agenda for deepening EU-Israeli ties, and it is critical that the newly elected Commission prioritise this. Working more closely together will not only advance peace, it will also help Europe reinforce its role as an honest and balanced broker of peace. Finally, given the current political instability in Israel, I think that Parliament has to act responsibly and refrain from interfering in internal politics. We’re not deaf, blind or mute, but sometimes silence is golden.

name: Carmen Avram (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Ms Mogherini’s balanced presentation regarding the situation in Israel and the Palestinian territories. I would also like to remind this Chamber and the people who are following our debate that Israel is the only democracy in the Middle East, and maybe we should put more of our energy into persuading all countries in the area to also follow the path of a real democracy. I believe many things would be easier to solve in the Middle East, including peace. Coming to the settlement issues, I think this should be part of the framework of negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Sanctioning only one side has never contributed to the promotion of peace. Israel is an ally and a friend and an important trade partner. Also when it comes to security, innovation, agriculture, fighting terrorism, or even fighting climate change, Israel has so much to give Europe. So we should not alienate friends by pointing them out every single time without going deeper into the region’s background and complicated reality. I call on the EU to remain an honest and balanced broker. It’s the only way we can reach a long-term agreement, and hopefully, peace in the region.

name: Martin Horwood (Renew).
text: – Mr President, we debate this issue only days after the Israeli government has joined the Venezuelan, Iranian and Egyptian regimes in banning a researcher for Human Rights Watch. I really regret that and I really think Israel is better than that, but we’re also seeing a growing alignment between the Trump and Netanyahu administrations, which increasingly damages prospects for peace. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s declaration that the West Bank settlements are not, per se, inconsistent with international law is first of all wrong but also an endorsement of Netanyahu’s strategy of changing the facts on the ground in a way that aims to undermine the feasibility of a two-state solution, the outlines of which have been clear for decades and which remains the only viable plan for peace. We must steadfastly defend Israel’s right to exist as a state, but also recognize Palestine’s right to statehood. Many believe Palestine has been fulfilling the Montevideo criteria for statehood for many years and, against the odds, it still has moderate Arab leaders on the West Bank at least. I hope a new Israeli government will recognize that compromise with such leaders is in Israel’s best interests and the best pathway to peace and security, but we must stand ready to step up the pressure in support of that pathway.

name: Magid Magid (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, as-Salaam-Alaikum. My message to the heroic Palestinian people who have resisted the extermination of their culture, their nationhood and their right to exist for 70 years is this: there are millions and millions of Europeans who grew up under occupation behind the Iron Curtain, the permanent choking hand of occupation, the never-ending nights of oppression, the daily torture and the disturbing murders. These Europeans and their allies – some are right wing and some are left wing – they know the horrors of occupation too well to allow or dismiss your struggle. And to my friends in Parliament: give the Palestinians what you would want for yourselves: the promise that weapons made in the EU will not be used to kill your children, and a comprehensive ban on all and any settlement goods entering the EU. If the settlements are illegal, then the products are illegal, and those who profit from them are criminals. Justice in words requires justice in action, so let us remember and repeat and honour the great words of Nelson Mandela when he said: ‘Our freedom is incomplete without the freedom of the Palestinians’.

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank Mrs Mogherini for her work and for her work We seem to largely agree that Pompeo and Trump's legitimization of Netanyahu's settlement policy trample sit underfoot of international law. The spiral of conflict between rocket fire and expulsion is moving into the next round. Luxembourg's Foreign Minister Asselborn proposes a new wave of European recognition of Palestine with East Jerusalem as its capital. This is charming, but only one of the objectives of an EU Middle East policy. We will not defend Oslo if we want to tackle an ever-failing peace process between Israel and Palestine, detached from peace solutions, for example, for Syria – for the whole region. How credible is our diplomacy in the Middle East if, on the other hand, we pursue an EU foreclosure policy with Turkey and Libya? How credible are we when the Member States support international law failureeverywhere with arms exports and the training of security forces? We need an international peace conference in order to find honest answers.

name: Sven Mikser (S&D).
text: – Mr President, let me thank the High Representative, dear Federica, for the excellent cooperation during the last five years, and also for her personal commitment to finding a just and sustainable resolution to this almost intractable conflict between Israel and the Palestinians. Let me also thank her for her unwavering commitment to preserving the EU’s unity regarding our approach to the peace process. A negotiated two-state solution remains the only just way of resolving the conflict, and it is also the only intellectually convincing solution which can simultaneously address Israel’s very real and legitimate security concerns and deliver the legitimate Palestinian aspirations of statehood. EU support for the negotiated two-state solution has been clear and consistent and needs to remain so. Settlement activity in the occupied territories presents an obstacle to the peace process and that’s why we should be very clear in our opposition to that activity. The same goes for the encouragement provided for such activity in the form of the recent US declaration regarding the legality of the settlements. I do not believe that unilateral actions which are clearly inconsistent with international law, are in anyone’s long-term security interests.

name: José Ramón Bauzá Díaz (Renew).
text: – Mr President, compliance with international law is a duty of all States, and Israel , in which I believe we all agree , cannot and should not be an exception. That said, Mrs Mogherini, I am concerned about the use that certain parties want to make of the conflict to show an increasingly less disguised hatred of Israel. Because the rise of anti-Semitism is one of the greatest problems experienced by the European Union. As the Agency for Fundamental Rights reported last year, in twelve of the Member States more than a third of respondents feared being assaulted because of their Jewish religion and nearly half faced insults and old age every day. But insults and aggressions are always the prelude to something worse, as we unfortunately find in horror after the recent attack in Halle during the Yom Kippur celebration. When we allow anti-Semitism to normalize, we fuel the violence suffered by our fellow Jews on European streets. That after seventy years the Jews do not feel safe in their land shows a terrible failure, and above all it demands responsibility and the active participation of the European Union.

name: Νιαζί Κιζιλγιουρέκ (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, once again the US Government is trying to legitimise Israel's unacceptable policies. Provocatively, it describes Israeli settlements in occupied Palestine as legitimate, having previously moved its embassy to Jerusalem and recognized Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights. At the same time, Israel is constantly expanding settlements. Settlers and Israeli security forces continue to violate palestinians' human rights. The European Union cannot and must not be apathetic. It must put pressure on Israel to end the settlement policy and commit itself to a roadmap for peace and finding a solution on the basis of two states. From this step I also call on the Government of my country, the Republic of Cyprus, to denounce the actions of the United States and Israel. Settlement is a war crime.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, I greet you in your last participation in a sitting of the European Parliament and I use the assertive words you used in a recently published text to simply and directly portray the dilemma we are facing today.  The two-state solution is the only way to guarantee, on the one hand, the right of Palestinians to freedom, self-determination and human development and, on the other hand, the right of Israelis to security and peace. Taking positions that go on a collision course with this solution, as the American administration did, by legitimizing Israeli settlements and recognizing Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, means going against international law, derailing the resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and thereby any possibility of lasting peace in the Middle East. The European Union is required to make more than words, acts, in the search for commitments necessary for the materialisation of the Oslo agreements, as well as the 2016 UN Security Council resolution.

name: Nikolaj Villumsen (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President! Israeli settlements in the occupied Palestinian territories are not only a blatant violation of international law, they are also a deliberate attempt to undermine the possibility of a peaceful two-state solution. We must not accept that Trump and Netanyahu continue to trample on the human rights of Palestinians. It is essential that the EUROPEAN Union unites and stands guard on international law. We need an import ban on goods from illegal Israeli settlements. We need recognition of the Palestinian State and we need a free and viable Palestine.

name: Nacho Sánchez Amor (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you Mrs Mogherini for the work of these years. In the area of American international policy, we are already outside the limit of astonishment, but we must not fail to underline the poisonous nature of this doctrine which turns the de facto possession of a territory into a legal title that legitimizes that capacity because it simply throws away the Helsinki security system. Because this case goes beyond the question of Israel and Palestine. Can we apply this doctrine that de facto sustaining a territory legitimizes its occupation in the case of Crimea? Can we consider that, if Turkey stays in Syria, I do not know how many months or years, it would be a legitimate holder of that territory? Do we apply the Pompeo doctrine to South Ossetia? That is why I say that the case far exceeds the case of Israel and Palestine.  What must be said is that we can never turn the stabilization of a conflict on a border into a legal title that legitimizes the aggressor. And so what Mr Pompeo has done is not a violation of international law: it is an attack on the heart of simple civilized international relations.

name: Pierfrancesco Majorino (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Federica Mogherini for everything she has done. It is with great concern that we must look at the long-established situation in Israel and Palestine, a situation which requires Europe and the international community to react immediately.
