We need European protagonism to try to retrace the path leading to the solution of the two peoples and two States, and it is our duty to continue along this path, without hescieting. A solution that must be based on mutual respect and the implementation of fundamental rights in order to be achieved: that of the State of Israel to live in peace and security within the borders recognised by the international community and that, absolutely identical, of the Palestinian people who must be recognised in those borders as recognising their state, their sovereignty and their legitimacy. We must also be explicit in denouncing what is going in the opposite direction. The policy of Netanyahu's government on the colonies, for example, has been a hugely destabilising factor, a further and enormous element of tension that cannot be justified and contrary to international law.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: - Mr. President! Dear Federica, your term of office is coming to an end, and thank you for all the excellent work you've done. Unfortunately, the debate over the situation in Israel and Palestine is once again marked by condemnations of the violence, with dozens dead in the attack by Israeli forces on Gaza, a constant setback of the situation on the ground.  The solution is in dialogue and in the context of the peace process, but they are both completely paralyzed. They are poisoning and thwarting unilateral and deeply damaging moves by the US and President Trump, most recently by changing their stance on illegal Israeli settlements in the West Bank.  This move is also seen as a response to a recent decision by the Court of Justice of the European Union that requires Europe to clearly mark its origins from illegal settlements.  Jewish settlements are a war crime! How is it possible for the Union to do business with them at all? The products produced there are illegal under international law and have no place in Europe.  Therefore, the Commission should act swiftly and decisively to implement the judgment today, as Israel has already announced the full annexation of the occupied territory. This, in turn, will ultimately bury the possibility of a peaceful solution to the Palestinian issue.

name: Alex Agius Saliba (S&D).
text: – Sur President, ser immur dritt għall-punt. L-abitazzjonijiet Iżraeljani fit-territorju okkupat Palestinjan huma illegali taħt il-liġi internazzjonali. Il-pożizzjoni tal-Unjoni Ewropea dwar il-politika ta' insedjament min-naħa tal-Iżrael hija ħafna u nispera li tibqa' kif inhi. Id-de-de-y-10000-09-000-000-000-0000 Minflok jingħaqdu sabiex tinstab soluzzjoni pa大ifika fuq iż-żewġ Stati, din is-sitwazzjoni kurrenti qed tkompli tqajjem il-vjolenza u d-diviżjoni kif ukoll qed thedded il-vijabbiltà fraliġ ta' soluzz li tinv żewġ Stati differenti. Ma hemmx u ma jistax ikun hemm l-ebda skuża biex tiddgħajjef il-liġi internazzjonali u għalhekk illi għandna bżonn: tmiem immedjat għal kull attività ta' insedjament; projbizzjoni fuq il-prodotti tas-saldu Iżraeljan fis-suq tal-Unjoni Ewropea, inkella ser nagħtu aktar saħħa ekonomika lil dan il-kunflitt; u anke t-tnaqqis minnufih tal-kunflitt fi u madwar l-istrixxa ta' Gaża. L-in-adiment u l-vjolenza għandhom jintemmu. In-nies iridu jkunu sikuri u protetti u gwerra oħra trid tkun evitata akkost ta' kollox.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Mr President, at the outset I just want to say that I respect Israel’s right to exist and protect itself and to live in peace and security in the Middle East. But having said that, and having visited the West Bank and seen first—hand what occupation is doing in terms of undermining the existence of the Palestinian state, let us be under no illusions. The idea that Israel can continually encroach on Palestinian lands is simply designed to undermine any chance of a two—state solution coming about. The Palestinian state is being slowly dismantled in front of our eyes, and Jared Kushner, the US envoy, simply is not seen as an honest broker in the Middle East, he’s not seen as an honest broker by the Palestinians. And we have to accept that Europe must play a more active role in being that honest broker, supporting Israel’s right to exist and, at the same time, ensuring that the two—state solution is the cornerstone of any future peace process. Equally, I sponsored a bill in the Irish Parliament a number of years ago with regard to produce from illegal settlements. And I would urge that the European Union would look at that, not only in the context of illegal settlements in the West Bank, but across the globe.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for In 1492, when the Jews were expelled from Spain, from Portugal, from German countries, when they were there on the pile, they found their place in Polish lands. In Yiddish, Polin means "rest here", "here you can live peacefully". After four hundred years, when the German Barbarians came to Polish, the Jews were again a fire, they were driven out again. In 1948, the state of Israel was founded. When I was studying, my college friend, Palestinian Nidal, explained to me that palestinians have an exclusive right to Palestine because Ismail was Abraham's beloved son. He could not answer my question as to why Abraham had established Isaac as his heir.  This conflict has also resonated today in this debate since genesis. When I hear words like 'apartheid', when I hear that Israel is committing horrible crimes, I also have the suffering of Israelis before my eyes. Let us remember that Israelis are experiencing terrorism by the Palestinians. Europe must stand on the common sense of international law. Both countries have the right to self-regulation.

name: Karoline Edtstadler (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Israel is embedded in a very unstable region called the Middle East. In German we call it Nahe Osten: that means ‘Near East’, because it’s only 3.5 hour’s flight from Vienna to Tel Aviv. Besides the inner Israeli conflict, we should not lose sight of the fact that Israel is surrounded by countries – let’s say enemies – who want nothing else than to erase the country from the landscape. That is why they have one of the most modern and innovative security systems such as the Iron Dome. Security is a raison d'être, simply because they have to defend their own country on a daily basis. Israel, as the only democratic state in the region, deserves the full support of the European Union. It is our partner and it is our security guarantee also for the European Union. The EU also has to remain relevant in a future political process between Israel and Palestine and to be perceived as an honest and balanced broker.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the US Secretary of State’s announcement that the US no longer considers Israeli settlements on occupied Palestinian land to be illegal is appalling. The Trump administration has done all it can to destabilise and bury the two- state solution: moving its embassy to Jerusalem, ending funding to the UN Palestinian Refugee Agency, and recognising Israeli sovereignty over the Golan Heights. The settlements remain illegal. Mr Trump’s approval does not change international law. Our Union was quick to reaffirm that all settlement activity is illegal, that it erodes the viability of the two-state solution and the prospects for a lasting peace, and that it should be ended. Palestinian representatives have rightly condemned the decision as a threat to the global order and one that destroys US credibility in the peace process. We must continue to present a united position on settlements. They are illegal under international law, they present an obstacle to peace, and they threaten the viability of a two-state solution. We urge the Israeli Government to halt its counter-productive settlement expansion.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Ms Mogherini has criticised illegal Israeli settlements at times, and rightly so, but the EU has refused to take decisive action against Israel. We have no control over the fact that the US allows them to be lawless in how they treat the Palestinians. Truth be told, Israel practises apartheid at home and genocide in Palestine. You said there was always hope for the two—state solution. The two—state solution is dead, it is beyond recovery. We need a one—state solution now, where the Palestinians and the Israelis both have an entitlement to full democratic human rights, and a return of the Palestinian refugees to their homeland. Anything else is not going to work anymore. And what the US is doing with Israel, they can only do because the EU and Europe tolerate it.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, unfortunately this revolting situation has been going on for far too long, and what is happening there is indescribable, a real plag on the face of the world in the 21st century. I am an emergency doctor and I see that behind the political games there are lives, there are people, there are lives lost and a lot of suffering, and I think it is time for the European Union, the European Parliament to bring to the negotiating table all those involved, so that the right solution is found and no one will suffer from now on. It has already been too long, and I hope that at least the new European Commission will find the healthy solution so that such abominable acts do not happen again. I hope that this situation can be resolved and that the solution is here in the European Union.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I am sure that the incoming Commission, the incoming High Representative, will not only take good note of this debate in this Chamber, but will also find a way to preserve the unity of the European Union and the Member States, to preserve our strong position in defence of international law and also keep the constant relations and coordination with others in the world – starting from the UN system but also looking at the Arab world in the region, and not only in the Arab world, knowing the situation on the ground very well – and will try to indicate with wisdom and realism the way forward.  I am sure they will also manage to see what kind of further initiatives can be taken to try and help the situation move forward and avoid the wars becoming irreversible, if you will allow me to put it this way. There are times when there are issues on which some advancements are possible, and some other issues and some other situations that, in certain particular periods of time or of history, require us – I would say the forces of wisdom and reason in this region, for sure, but I would like to say in the world – to try to avoid that the worst becomes a fait accompli, irreversible. And I have the impression – I have discussed this several times with many in the region – that these times we’re living in are asking us to play that role, in this moment to try and avoid that things go so far, that the positive perspectives for a solution to the conflict are still viable in the future. Let me just comment on one thing that I’ve heard during the debate and that has impressed me a lot, because there is the issue of the settlements itself, there is the work we have been doing and we will continue to do, I’m sure, as European institutions on the Israeli—Palestinian conflict, on the Arab—Israeli conflict – because there are two conflicts in one – but then, even more than that, there’s the role that the European Union has in defending and preserving the international rules—based order. And someone in this Chamber said, and I quote: ‘the settlements are disputed, yes, but illegal, no’.  I have the impression that we are moving into a place – and I hope the European institutions, including this Chamber, don’t move into that place – where it’s international law that is disputed. That is a very dangerous place.  So I hope that, beyond differences and divergences, you will manage not only to advise and ask the Commission and the Council in this respect to help contribute to unblocking the situation in Israel and Palestine, to help implement international law when it comes to the settlement issues, but also that you will always keep in mind, as Members of the European Parliament, that international law is not up for discussion, it is to be respected. And that when you reach the point of discussing whether international law is good or wrong, then you’re already in a place where Europe shouldn’t be.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: President. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the broader Middle East region, including the crisis in Iran, Iraq and Lebanon (2019/2917(RSP)). I remind you that it is possible to request catch-the-eye and blue cards using both the standard registration and the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance of the hemicycle. Blue-card requests are accepted only after the round of the speakers on behalf of the political groups. The debate will be opened by the Vice-President of the Commission, High / Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Ms Mogherini.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, on the streets of the Middle East in Baghdad, in Beirut, in Tehran and other cities, I’ve witnessed large demonstrations, which are still ongoing in all countries. Events are unfolding and each case is different, yet there seem to be some common causes. The triggers have been specific policy initiatives but the protests have then expanded, targeting inequality, sectarianism and corruption and asking for better governance and better job opportunities. Our response to these protests has common elements, too. We have condemned any act of violence, from all parties. We have urged restraint in handling the demonstrations. We have asked for respect for freedom of expression and prompt investigation of instances of violence. We have also demanded that external actors always respect this country’s sovereignty. Now, let me briefly comment on a few specific cases, the ones you mentioned on the title of the debate. First on Iraq. The challenges that Iraq is facing are unique. The country is finally coming out of a long conflict, it needs reconciliation and reconstruction. It also needs to deliver on its people’s aspirations to a better life and better opportunities for all. These expectations need to be fulfilled if Iraq is to stabilise in the long term, and I’ve seen myself during my last visit there – in July, if I’m not wrong – how far the country has come when it comes to being ready to work on reconciliation and reconstruction, but also how fragile this progress is. And I think we are now seeing this clearly. From the beginning of the protests we have been asking for dialogue and steps to quickly address the protesters’ concerns, including those steps suggested by the UN mission. This is even more urgent today. We also continue to encourage Iraq to maintain its policy of constructive engagement with all its neighbours in times when its role as a voice of wisdom is essential in the region. We Europeans have always said that we want to help the people of Iraq win the peace, and this is what the people of Iraq are asking right now. So, we will continue to be on their side and to accompany Iraq on its path towards a stronger, more inclusive and more just democracy. In Iran, the recent protests also stem from genuine frustration with the current economic hardships. Citizens have the right to peacefully demonstrate, and there is no justification for the disproportionate use of violence by the security forces. All reports of incidents deserve swift and full investigation by the relevant independent authorities. I also want to emphasise that we expect the Iranian authorities to ensure the free flow of information and access to the internet at all times. Let me add something that is clear and obvious, but it is important to clarify this once again, that this has nothing to do and should have nothing to do with the implementation of the nuclear deal with Iran. We continue to fully believe in the diplomatic and security value of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), of the nuclear deal with Iran. Yet it is no secret that the preservation of this agreement has become increasingly difficult. And let me announce today that we will have a joint commission with Iran that will be convened on 6 December to this end. As you know, together with the role of High Representative also comes the role of a coordinator of the Joint Commission of the JCPOA of the nuclear deal with Iran, and we have worked in this capacity so far very hard to keep the unity, not only of the Europeans – that has been done – but also of the participants to the nuclear deal that have remained in the agreement after the US withdrew. And I believe this unity is key to preserve the agreements as much as possible. We all agreed just a few weeks ago that we must spare no efforts to preserve the deal, and let me also say that I wish my successor all the best as he takes over also this difficult essential role: that of coordinating the Joint Commission of the JCPOA. Third and last, but not least at all, let me say a few words on Lebanon where protests have led to the prime minister’s resignation. Lebanon is a very special partner for the European Union and it holds a very special place in our heart. Today, the people of Lebanon are asking for good governance, good governance and good governance, beyond any sectarian line, and this is truly inspiring, as Lebanon society often is. It is urgent to address the demands of the Lebanese people while preserving the peace and the stability that Lebanon has worked so hard to achieve in all these years. This calls, first and foremost, for the swift formation of a functioning government to ensure political and economic stability, followed by the rapid and decisive implementation of effective reforms on governance and corruption, in line with the Lebanese people’s aspirations. This moment can become somehow an opportunity to deliver the reforms that Lebanon so urgently needs while, at the same time, preserving the country’s stability and resilience. And let me add one word on something that is not on our focus specifically tonight but is still there. Let us not forget that the whole Middle East remains an incredibly fragile place. We have just discussed the situation in Israel and Palestine, let us not forget that the situation in Syria is still far from being settled. On the contrary, in the north-west of Syria, the situation has got worse once again, only a few weeks after the Turkish military operation opened a new front in the north-east of Syria. So, regional tensions are still running high, and this is putting even more importance and pressure on those in the region and beyond the region who are trying to calm down the situation and find sustainable outcomes to the current dynamics. In these years, we’ve been trying to build multilateral solutions to all crises in the region and we have worked very closely with our partners – including Lebanon and Iraq – to stabilise those countries to bring investment for reconstruction and economic growth and to support these countries in their reform agendas. Each of these countries will have to find its own way to overcome their current difficulties. Nobody can do it for them. But the European Union will continue, I believe, to support dialogue and accompany reforms. It is one of the regions that is closest to us, I often say it is our common region, and the European Union, I believe, will continue to engage as a reliable partner and as a force for peace in the Middle East.

name: Ivan Štefanec
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we have heard about the recent demonstrations and uprisings in Iran. These protests, which have been going on for over 11 days, took place in all 31 provinces of Iran and in 176 cities. The main opposition has announced that the number of those killed during the Iranian people’s nationwide uprising is over 450, but the number of deaths could be much higher.  The names of over 150 of the young men and women who were brutally murdered by Iran’s security forces have already been published and this is really a very sad list. For example, this list includes Nikta Esfandani, who was just 14 years old, and in her case the regime’s officials told her family that since she was only 14, and was a kid, they would not ask for the cost of the bullets – this really is unbelievable. President Rouhani’s government, which some regarded as so-called moderate, quickly shut down the internet to prevent the news and videos of these crimes from coming out of Iran. The government is also refusing to hand over the bodies of those killed to their families or preventing funerals for them. I am very concerned about the fate and treatment of over 10 000 detainees. Some of the regime’s top officials have hinted that many of those who have been arrested will soon be executed – executed by public hanging even. They are especially focusing on the members of the resistance units of PMOI, which the regime has blamed for this uprising. The crimes carried out by the Iranian regime are, by any measure, crimes against humanity. We must not allow the people who have come onto the streets to stand for their rights to be arrested, tortured or silenced. I should remind you that the Iranian opposition leader Ms Rajavi has called on the United Nations to dispatch quickly fact-finding missions to Iran, and that the regime leaders must face justice for perpetrating crimes against humanity.  To conclude, we in this Parliament should stand with the people of Iran and I urge the EU High Representative to do the same by ending current policy because, from my point of view, this current policy has failed and will only damage the credibility of Europe, not only amongst the people of Iran but also among people around the world. People are watching us and wait for our action. I believe that the European Union should act now.

name: Isabel Santos
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, we are witnessing a period marked by the outbreak of social movements, political contestation in various parts of the world, so complex in nature and so unpredictable about their outcome that they do not admit generalizations or simplisms in their analysis.  However, we can identify levels of poverty, the sharpening of humanitarian conditions, the lack of freedom and expectations, especially for young people, corruption and low confidence in political power as elements that have led to strong social tensions. This is the case with popular protests in Iraq, Iran and Lebanon, countries marked by strong internal upheavals and crises, often fueled by external power games. But understanding this cannot, however, mitigate the level of our apprehension at the violence that is being exerted against the demonstrators to varying degrees. In Lebanon, repressive violence against protesters by identified groups can never be tolerated. In Iran, the repression of peaceful protests generated by rising fuel prices, the cutting of the Internet, arbitrary detentions, torture, the more than 100 dead and radical calls for the application of the death penalty are unacceptable and lead us to call for the abandonment of the use of violence and the pursuit of inclusive dialogue, the only way to resolve the economic and social crisis. Finally, in Iraq, the latest events should merit from the European Union and its Member States a response which, among other things, must include the immediate suspension of the provision of technology that can be used for human rights violations.

name: Bernard Guetta
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, blood has flowed in Tehran and is still flowing in Baghdad, with its hundreds dead. Yet behind this tragedy, it is the birth of a new Middle East that we are witnessing. Let us first observe these demonstrations in Baghdad and Beirut. In these processions, there are no Sunnis, no Kurds, no Shiites, no Christians; there are Lebanese, there Iraqis, citizens of these two countries, protesting shoulder to shoulder against the deterioration of their living conditions, the extent of corruption and the collapse of public services. No one would have thought that the Community borders could be erased in this way, but in social anger, a century after their creation by the colonial powers, these mosaic countries finally seem to become nation states. It's a breakup. In the second turning point of recent weeks, Iran is now in trouble. In Lebanon, Hezbollah, the armed arm of the Islamic Republic, is as contested as any other party. In Iraq, all communities, L.S. Shiites, denounce Tehran's control over the government and the state apparatus. These two countries are in revolt against the protectorate that Tehran would like to impose on them and this is a serious setback for this regime at a time when the Iranians are denouncing soaring prices and challenging the very foundations of theocracy. It is now more than twenty years since this power went from crisis to crisis, but their pace is accelerating while their depth is increasing. The power that we saw ascending in the Middle East may no longer be so and everything could be changed in this region whose balances are changing from month to month. All this, ladies and gentlemen, is happening on our doorstep. More than ever, we would have to be blind and deaf in order not to assert our union on the international stage and to endow it with all the instruments of power.

name: Hannah Neumann
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, 30 years ago people took to the streets in Europe and they stood up for freedom and for democracy. They were not organised, but they were united in one claim: ‘we are the people’. Two weeks ago in this House we congratulated ourselves on the successful demonstrations and how they have changed our lives for the better. Since this summer we have seen demonstrations in many countries around the Middle East. Algeria: ongoing. Egypt: violent and cruel crackdown. Lebanon: a Prime Minister stepping down and an old elite clinging to power. Iraq: their protest is met with the utmost violence. About 350 are dead. Iran: a massive media blackout. We don’t even have viable information, but more than 100 are dead for sure. In all of these uprisings we see people taking their claims to the street against corruption and for participation, against repression and for democracy. What is new in this protest is that they don’t care anymore about sectarian or regional boundaries. We are all Iraqis is what they shout in the streets of Baghdad, and that is apparently scaring the old elites. A tear gas canister fired at the head of a 17-year-old in Baghdad, a mother in jail for posting on Facebook in Cairo, protesters greeting security forces with flowers and met with live ammunition in Shiraz in Iran. And we, the European Union, the ones that have just celebrated 30 years of peaceful revolution, we are bystanders once more. In Iraq we have been present for years. We have supported with humanitarian aid. We have had reconstruction projects. We actually have a mission on security sector reform in the very same country where medics are shot in the back when treating the wounded, where snipers are firing at peaceful protesters. And those in the streets of Iraq, they refused the interference of Iran and the US and they are very clear about that. The UN has lost its credibility and protesters are clearly, clearly calling on us, the European Union, to fill the void, to organise dialogue, to stop the killing, to investigate the abuses, to do a proper security-sector reform and to just teach them crowd control. And the EU is issuing statements without commitments. Let me be clear, doing nothing or only a little in such a situation can actually do a lot of harm. We failed the demonstrators of the Arab Spring in 2011, and we should not let them down once again. We are all human beings and we are human beings with human rights.

name: Jérôme Rivière
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Lebanon, Iraq, Iran: the region has long been subject to foreign interference and perpetual regional interference. Destabilized by an unremly American intervention, Iraq continues to disintegrate around its community divides. Iran, suffocated by a totalitarian regime but hastily shoved by the United States, is sinking away from our eyes, digital communication having been cut off, in a violent repression of the aspiration of a people to regain its freedom. In both countries, our clumsy and often self-interested interventions lead to chaos. Let us be careful to avoid the same mistakes in Lebanon. To paraphrase Montesquieu, who recommended touching the laws only with a trembling hand, let us apply this wise precaution to this civilization of the Levant, which brought us the great monotheistic spirituality, the beginning of urban civilization but also agriculture. The Lebanese, in a period akin to a real revolution, carry only their own demands. Seeing only Lebanese flags flying in the heart of the demonstrations is a real sign of hope. Our responsibility is not to push for the worst and to assist this country in the preservation of a denominational system, which allows so many different religious communities to live together. This balance in Lebanon is the best response to the barbarity of Islamism that Daesh has tried to install in the region. With our respective national hisalies, let us assist this nation to emerge from this period as a calm. Let us maintain the help that people need. Defending pluralism in Lebanon is also defending it in Europe.

name: Anna Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, there are traces of Iran’s operations all over the region, in every conflict, every war, and this presence is detrimental to stability and peace there. Yet, the worst of the actions has been reserved for Iran’s own population that is multi-ethnic and diversified, yet acting in accord against the regime of the mullahs recently and during the past two years. The recent protests are massive: in all 31 provinces, in the majority of Iranian cities. The internet has been suspended and there are really barbaric, violent acts by the regime against populations. There are over 300 dead already during the recent 11 days, more than 10 000 have been arrested and we should be concerned about their fate and their whereabouts. As happened many years ago with political prisoners, their fate seems to be the fate of victims of judiciary crimes. In view of a possible crime against humanity, we are obliged by international law to intervene, to act, instead of smiling at mullahs.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the What has happened in the Middle East in recent weeks is truly a tragedy. The fact that thousands took to the streets in Iran because of the country's social imbalance was and is their right. And the fact that they did so despite the ban on demonstrations, which they dared to do despite the lack of freedom of speech and communication, has cost them enormous courage and so many people's lives. No, you do not shoot at demonstrators, and we have to say so clearly. The death of human beings is not collateral damage in the name of a larger thing or whatever other thing. That is how I stand here and, also on behalf of our group, but also of many others, Bow to the demonstrators who have been killed, to their families, women, children and parents. Mr President, on behalf of the Iran delegation of which I am chairman, I am addressing you and asking you to write a letter to your colleague in Iran – to the Iranian Parliament – because I believe that not only the Commission, but also the European Parliament, must react. We expect that from you. At the same time, I say frankly: I feel shame that we, as Europeans, have literally achieved nothing effective in countering the devastating US sanctions. Because transatlantic relations seem to be dear to us, many Iranians' hopes for the future are only cheap. The disappointment of the West is huge. Let me tell you one thing: we are part of the problem, and this half-hearted EU policy must finally be brought to an end.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in the Middle East is so complex that it should perhaps be dealt with in a more structured way. While it is true that there is a widespread crisis situation in the Shiite Crescent, it must be admitted that the specificities of individual countries deserve separate discussions.  That is why I want to concentrate on a country very close to my heart, small but of incredible strategic importance for the entire region: Lebanon. Beirut is facing an unprecedented crisis, both political and economic, with 150 % of GDP debt, out-of-control inflation and a plummeting credit rating, and the economy is on the brink of collapse. Urgent reforms would be needed, impossible to implement given the equally complex political situation, which has precipitated after the resignation of Prime Minister Haarīrī and the difficulties in forming a new government. Ladies and gentlemen, we all know how crucial this country is geopolitically and the disastrous consequences that would be in the event of its protracted destabilisation. We need a new government that can commit itself to carrying out the necessary economic reforms, but at the same time commits itself to combating widespread corruption, which remains one of the causes that led to street demonstrations. But Lebanon alone cannot emerge from this crisis, even considering that some 1.5 million Syrian refugees still live in the country to date. We need strong and timely support from the European Union, which is much biggest, much more important than the assistance we are already providing. I call on the new Commission to deal with this emergency as quickly as possible, since the consequences of a strong intervention would be unpredictable and certainly dramatic.

name: Στέλιος Κυμπουρόπουλος (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I disagree with those who say that in this Chamber we have been excessive about human rights, because Europe must be the beacon of democracy, of human rights, of development internationally. But it's true that we're idealists. We would very much like the wider Middle East, our neighbourhood, to share the same values as us towards women, children, young people, the disabled, but also dissidents, all-faiths and different ethnicities. But another Sweden and Greece and another Egypt and Syria. From our enthusiasm we may once have supported some lively revolutions, which brought far, much worse regimes than the original overthrows. So we have now learned that idealism must be balanced with a little realism and an image of the result. We must be cunning, as agents of instability act in the wider Middle East, lurking to install hard regressive regimes.  With all their weaknesses, Egypt and Israel are rocks of friendship and Europe's most stable and reliable partners in the Middle East. And we are well aware that they both have the intention of self-improvement. With regard to Iraq, I fear that, as long as we do not strongly support its rebuilt, we will respect it. 11 of the country's 36 million are in need of immediate humanitarian aid. These people are potential refugees. They may not yet be on European land, but I am sure that each of you can understand the father and mother who will do anything to save your child. And they will form the main mass of the puzing. I am sure that, in addition to halting the refugee process, humanism motivates us to help those people in need. Many are surprised by the large number of asylum seekers. First they can prove that they do not have altruism and want to help people in need in their own country, before they are forced to resort to our help.  In Iraq, we know Daes well. It will only be completely defeated when the country stabilizes and grows again. It is an extremely European feature to provide for stabilising the states before we have to face new bigger problems tomorrow. With regard to Iran, let us actively support our agreements. Let us support the joint consensus action plan.  Lebanon is a mature democracy. The basically peaceful demonstrations are a sign of the quality of society. We understand the transition to a technocratic government, which will allow the country to make the necessary reforms and call elections. The European attitude towards the countries of the region must be internal stabilisation, while promoting human rights, defending international law, cooperation and trade with conditionality clauses.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, I can only agree with the statement you have just made on the situation in the Middle East. It is true that the Middle East has been in turmoil for some time and, everywhere, the demands that are born are essentially the same: social demands and demands for good governance. I will not repeat what my colleagues have said, whether it is Mr Guetta or Mrs Neumann. Governments everywhere are seen responding to these legitimate demands through repression and, often, all too often, violence. The European Union has a real role to play in basing its foreign policy on respect for the law, once again, and on respect for multilateralism. The European Union, unlike the Trump administration, must make a concrete contribution to the de-escalation of tensions in the region and continue to defend peace and respect for fundamental rights. The stability of the Middle East, as we have said, will require a democratic transition that we Europeans must support through dialogue, as you have done, but also through the support and protection of the people.

name: Klemen Grošelj (Renew).
text: – Mr President! The Middle East is becoming a series of crises and wars that can push the region and its neighbourhood into an even deeper a haven.  In addition to the Syrian tragedy, Yemen, Iraq and Lebanon are also in or on the edge of the a haven. Ironically, the key to solving many problems is in the hands of Iran, which decisively and fatally co-shapes the fate of the region.  The region's countries have become hostages to Iranian influence and politics through the so-called Shiite Crescent. Following the collapse of the nuclear agreement, Iran is abusing the crisis in the region as a means of putting pressure on the region and on the international community. It is a crude real policy to which neither the EU nor the international community has an answer, and US sanctions do not affect Iran's behaviour.  However, the enlargement of instability in the region is also increasingly a direct threat to the security of the European Union, and I therefore call on the new Joint Representative of Foreign and Security Policy to focus on this as a matter of priority and to avoid further destabilisation of the region, which would also be reflected, among other things, in the increased number of refugees at the Borders of the European Union.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr. President. Mrs Mogherini, social protests have epped in several areas of the Middle East in a few months. Although they may seem isolated, protests in Lebanon, Iraq and Iran have much in common in some respects: the provision of basic services, unemployment, corruption. Anti-government protests in these three countries have been harshly suppressed, killing more than three hundred people, for example in Iraq. And the total blockade of the internet in Iran has not yet confirmed the more than two hundred deaths encrypted by several NGOs. From this Parliament we must condemn the use of force and lethal means used by Iranian and Iraqi security forces to crush mostly peaceful protests. We must call on the Iranian authorities to respect the rights to freedom of peaceful assembly and freedom of expression, including the lifting of the total blockade of internet access that has been decreed. The rise in gasoline prices, decreed by the Iranian government, adds to the impact of economic sanctions imposed by the US administration last summer, which are having a devastating effect on iran's economy and population, and they are also, as we know, putting the future of the nuclear agreement at risk. According to the United Nations and several NGOs, these economic sanctions are causing people to suffer greatly on a daily basis and do not just affect the Government. This does not obviously exempt the Iranian regime from its responsibilities with regard to the human rights of the population, which we know is something that is also of concern to you and which we must constantly demand from this Parliament. In any case, from Iran to Lebanon to Iraq, the leaders of these countries must listen to their people and initiate economic reforms that improve the living conditions and social well-being of the population and end corruption. And we, as the European Union, must have a regional approach to the area to understand and be able to accompany and to be a resolution actor of the various root causes that are currently affecting these countries and which are generating so much instability.

name: Elena Lizzi (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, I would also like to mention the five Italian soldiers who were injured in an attack in the Kirkuk area of Iraq, just on the eve of the anniversary of the Nassiriya massacre. In Iraq, the demonstrations of the last few days are the most intense since 2005 and are taking place mainly in Shiite areas: they are people who are demanding work and fighting corruption. So far, the Kurdish North and the areas affected by the territorial conquest of the Islamic State have remained unrelated to the demonstrations. Attacks are multiplying in Iraq and the Islamic State is reorganising itself. The European Union cannot stand by and watch. One of the works adorning the tunnel that passes through Baghdad's Tahrir Square, the center of anti-government protests, depicts the face of Jesus crowned with thorns, also a symbol of Iraqi punishments. There are also Christians in Iraq, who have fallen from one and a half million to 250 000 since 2003 and are in danger of being wiped out after two thousand years of history. Leaders of Christian churches and communities support popular peaceful protest demonstrations. Trump, too, has rightly funded Iraqi Christian organizations. In Iraq, the role of minorities is crucial, as a guarantee that the region will not become a clash between Sunnis and Shiites. The European Union must also support iraq's Christian minority.

name: Charlie Weimers (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I say to High Representative Mogherini: instead of bowing before the mullahs and stringing along the failed Iran deal, which only enables the regime, European leaders should raise the spirits of the Iranian people, throw off the hijab and state: we recognise that this is a regime that cares more about terrorists than its own people, that cannot tolerate dissent and free thought, that faces annual widespread protest, that orders soldiers to fire at will on their fellow citizens, that oppressed its people for decades. In our hearts, we Europeans join the brave Iranian people in their outcry: jumhuuriya islami namikhaaham namikhaaham. ‘We don’t want an Islamic republic’.

name: Idoia Villanueva Ruiz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, not only is Latin America in the midst of a political and social earthquake, but also the Middle East. Iraq, Lebanon, Iran, Egypt, Sudan, Algeria: countries going through deep crises in a Maghreb and in the Middle East that have suffered the brazen fight over seized their resources.  Many people take to the streets and demand bread, freedom and social justice, dignity, for years. The answer has been more repression, more impunity and more geopolitics of chaos in a devastated region: from the illegal invasion of the United States in Iraq to the drama in Syria, Yemen and Libya, not forgetting the Israeli occupation in Palestine, Western Sahara or the Kurdish peoples. Each and every one of these crises suffered European interventions; now suffer their abandonment. Mrs Mogherini, is Europe going to have any role in the Middle East, or are we going to let these people suffer and the far right take advantage of the consequences of this disaster? Europe must bury military interventions, be an independent, stabilising actor, bet on equal-to-equal relations. For justice with those who manifest themselves on the streets of the countries we have destroyed, and for the very fate of our continent.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, as you have said, this region we are talking about this evening, the Middle East, is in serious tension. In this situation, the Europeans we are must have three major objectives. First, we must help these countries in their quest for democracy, in any case, in their desire to move towards a stronger rule of law. I am thinking in particular, as a French elected official, of our friends in Lebanon who can and should benefit from our support in this transition. Secondly, the protection of minorities must be guaranteed, as is our historic role. I am thinking in particular of the Christian minorities, of whom we must be the protectors in this region, but also, for example, the Yezidi and all those who might be affected by violence. Ensuring peace and respect for the rights of every human being in this region, regardless of their faith, should be a priority of our diplomacy. Thirdly, as my colleague pointed out at the time, it is important to ensure that these developments are not captured by what is now our major enemy, not only in this region, but in our territory, i.e. Islamism. As we know very well and we have already experienced it, we must be concerned about how radical Islam can take control of these territories, in a demand for democracy. Today, we must be vigilant. Thirteen French soldiers died the day before yesterday in the Sahel-Saharan strip in Mali to fight this enemy. Dear friends, we have been very touched by the support you have shown to France in this moment of mourning, but this support must also be concrete today. Our country cannot carry this fight alone. We must join forces in this commitment, unite our military forces, of course. We will not have strong and effective diplomacy if we do not have, at the same time and collectively, the means of our action. Thanks to the European Defence Fund, for example, as well as through a more constant commitment to this effort to defend Europe, Europe can serve the peace of tomorrow by assuming to develop its strategic autonomy and serve a free voice in the world that is emerging.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are discussing very different countries but today they share a broad protest movement by thousands of people who are calling for a decent life, a job, social inclusion and the fight against corruption. Protests that are certainly far removed, even by characteristics, from the events of 2011 but which are not surprised, as parliament's report bearing my name on the Arab post-spring has feared, due to the persistence of structural problems. The economic and social fragility of Lebanon, for example, europe's important partner, which has welcomed, as we know, well over a million Syrian refugees, over 30 % of the population, a situation that is leading the country to collapse. Europe cannot and must not let this happen and must support Beirut even more strongly in order to respond to the demands of the Lebanese people. However, I must also draw attention to the many cases of the return of several refugees to the hands of the Syrian army, cases that are reported to us by various sources on the ground, such as Amnesty and Operation Colomba, which constitute a serious violation of the obligation not to reject them, as well as condemning those who suffer them to certain death. In Iraq, we are keeping a high level of attention on the Kurdish population, so that the unrest is not used as a pretext for questioning regional autonomy. As an Italian, I must also recall the tragic death of the military on 10 November, claimed by Daesh, and I would like to say that, having reiterated our US support for Iraqi Kurdistan, it surprises a little after the scandalous disengagement with the Syrian Kurds. Today, as never before, there is a need for a clear signal from Europe, strong in its external action. That is why I would like to thank Federica Mogherini, who is here with us, for her work in this regard over the years.

name: Abir Al-Sahlani (Renew).
text: – Mr President, let me just start by saying that in this House, and under this roof, we have now tried twice to get a resolution about Iraq but have failed and I will ask the political parties here, the Groups, why are you blocking a resolution on Iraq? Talking the talk is one thing, but walking the walk is another.  Addressing the High Representative, Ms Mogherini, now we have a historical choice: either we stand with the Iraqi people or we choose to stand with the government. We know all the governments – they come and go – but the Iraqi people will always be there. What are the concrete measures, Ms Mogherini, that you are going to take to help the Iraqi people to facilitate a dialogue so those protesters who are screaming on Tahrir Square, ‘Norid Waten’ – ‘We want our country’ – their voice is heard. I want to applaud the Ambassador of the EU in Iraq for his very obvious and strong positions, but we have to make those positions into concrete actions. The UN has lost its credibility and now someone else has to step up and take this responsibility. The only ones that have this credibility is the EU, the only union of democracies in the world.

name: Bernhard Zimniok (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report I would like to urge you to highlight a security problem that poses a massive threat not only to the Middle East, but also to Europe: the IS fighters who are in detention in Syria and Iraq. Some 4,000 people from Europe joined ISIS at the time. We Europeans have still not developed a coherent strategy on how we want and must deal with these terrorists. This is a political declaration of bankruptcy. The Turkish invasion of northern Syria has now made the problem urgent. An unknown number of terrorists have already fled. This is a huge security problem that we are facing. How do we deal now with these criminals, these butchers – this human scum – who have brutally murdered, raped and tortured, beheaded, crucified and burned alive? Judicial proceedings in Europe would normally lead to acquittals or maximum sentences, which would be a fatal signal to the countless victims of this terrorist regime. These terrorists must be severely punished and deserve no mercy. Let us therefore support Iraq and Syria in setting up a war crimes tribunal! European terrorists and IS terrorists are enemies of all of us: they must answer for their atrocities where they were committed. This is the only way to ensure justice for the victims. All of us here are responsible for the safety of our citizens. Let us live up to this responsibility!

name: Beata Kempa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for your I would like to thank you very much for everything that has been done so far, including the summits that you have organised, where successive countries have declared their assistance first and foremost for Syria, but also for the countries that are directly affected by the war in Syria and that the whole region is destabilised. But it will allow you to believe that the European Union should have an even more consolidated action plan at the moment. In particular, in addition to diplomatic procedures, which are difficult, a very precise financial plan. A plan that should concern not only Jordan, Lebanon, but, above all, Iraq at the moment. Because in Iraq individual countries are trying to help, for example, the Hungarians have rebuilt the town of Telskuf. That's probably about $8 million. I think there are more villages, especially in the Nineveh Valley, Bashiba, Bartella, Batnaya, where, if these people had somewhere to return from the camps, they would come back immediately. I think destabilisation would have to go away, and above all we also need to think about making these concrete projects show in tribute to the founding fathers that we are doing very concrete things there.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, Madam Vice-President and High Representative, for your work and also for the statement you made today, which I support. If we look at what is happening in the Islamic Arab world—we see the situation in Algeria, the situation in Lebanon, the situation in Iraq, the situation in Iran—one would be tempted to think that we are facing a kind of second Islamic Arab Spring.  If there is regime change in Algeria, there is a change of government in Lebanon and Iraq, and there are large protests in Iran that have been suppressed in a totally unacceptable way. I believe that what our colleague from Renew has said is true. This Parliament must position itself on the situation in Iraq with a resolution, and our future high representative, Mr Borrell, has to take the situation of these three countries very seriously, and we must have a strategic approach to the whole situation.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (Renew).
text: – Mr President, today the Middle East is in the spotlight, but in reality we have never stopped thinking about that region in recent years. Unfortunately, it continues to be a cradle of poverty, suffering, wars and ethno—religious conflicts – without a clear direction for development and hope for millions of citizens, but spreading terrorism and extremism that has led to hundreds of thousands of innocent victims, with deadly demonstrations and violence in Iraq, Iran, Lebanon and a refusal of politicians to accept reality and give hope for the future. These are not movie scenes but a painful reality. Not by coincidence, one Iraqi newspaper asked the question: if you kill us all, whom do you rule over? Europe cannot stay silent. I urge the authorities of these countries to stop the violence against peaceful protesters immediately, and to open the door to dialogue. Parliamentarians must act by reflecting the public interest for a new and different way of conducting politics, restoring hope and bringing a brighter future.

name: Thierry Mariani (ID).
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, we must listen and understand the anger of the Lebanese people, but we must ensure that all developments in Lebanon preserve religious diversity and, in particular, the place of the Christian community, which, as you know, is particularly threatened in this region. As European elected representatives, however, we must ask ourselves the following question: what happens to the millions that are paid to Lebanon to help it? I will give you a letter from an elected official from Lebanon, from the Tripoli region, who tells us that the European Union has financed a waste treatment plant that has never worked. Why don't donors control? Why did this money never get to the recipient? Finally, why is Europe not doing anything to ensure that money does not go through the channels of corruption? In my opinion, the service we could give to the Lebanese would be to ensure that the money that the Europeans give them to help them really benefits the people and does not get lost in corruption.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in the previous debate I said Israel is our main regional strategic partner. Now I have to say that, particularly, Iran is our main regional strategic rival, the main anti-Western Force there. What we have seen over many years has been an endless attempt by Iran to achieve regional hegemony. The Iranian fundamentalist theocracy has been spreading its influence over Iraq, Syria and, of course, Lebanon, undermining constantly their internal coherence, and it is time to stop this. It’s time to change our appeasement policy vis-à-vis Iran. it is time to support the exiled opposition. If we want to pursue our own EU interests in the region, we are obliged to do that. To curb Iran, I believe, is the key to stability in the region.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr High Representative Mogherini! According to testimonies from international organisations, Iranian forces are using excessive force against those who protest against the injustices in the country. Hundreds of demonstrators have been killed, thousands have been injured or imprisoned. It is unacceptable that people who protest for their social and economic rights should be killed, injured, imprisoned or treated with brutality by the regime. In addition, the internet's blackout is deeply offensive and a violation of human rights. It is also deeply unsympathetic to hear at the same time about the President, who is tweeting, while people's lives are being pruned because you do not have access to what we find quite natural. The Internet must be opened immediately. I, like many of my colleagues, condemn what is happening in Iran and want to see resolute action and clarity from the European Union. I would like to take this opportunity to thank you, Federica Mogherini, for your important work over these years. I've followed you and seen a lot of your work as admirable. I would like to see that you are now clearly making a final mark against Iran to help the people who are now affected.

name: Martin Horwood (Renew).
text: – Mr President, as Vice—Chair of this Parliament’s Iran delegation, I’m going to focus on that country, and I speak as a supporter of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, an outspoken critic of illegal US sanctions and one who would encourage, rather than undermine, moderates within the Iranian regime. But all these positions become harder and harder with each infringement of international norms by Iran. The current civilian protests have been met with wholly disproportionate force, and we in Europe must condemn without reservation the killing of at least 100 civilian protesters and the arrest of, perhaps, 1 000 more. I remain a supporter of dialogue, so I very much welcome the announcement of a new joint commission, but we must robustly condemn atrocities when they take place. Can I finish by thanking Ms Mogherini for her impressive, respectful and, above all, patient attendance at this Parliament and for all her hard work on behalf of all of us, including the United Kingdom? I do hope her successor can do likewise and won’t have to deal with us as a foreign country.

name: Silvia Sardone (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, violent street protests have shocked Iran in recent weeks. What has the European Union done? Nothing. We have here the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs, Mr Mogherini. What did you do? Nothing. In recent years, Europe has forgiven Iran for the unforgivable: torture, summary trials, threats to the West, even financing for terrorism. He pretended there were no hangings. Among those convicted were 90 women, hanged in 2019 alone. Where did feminists and movements #metoo? Instead of proposing modernity and freedom, Europe has decided, in the name of oil and business, to talk in fact with the ayatollah. So I ask, quite simply: in view of the dead, the injured, the censored Internet, and the fact that the citizens there want the end of the Islamic Republic, when Europe will take note of it and finally support freedom and democracy?

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, today we are here to discuss the situation in the Middle East and especially the serious protests that have taken place, for different reasons, in several countries: in Lebanon, in Iraq or in Iran. We want to explain some common patterns about what's happening today in the Middle East. Huge social discontent over the lack of opportunities, access to public services, access to economic growth that reaches the population as a whole, unfortunately, conflicts suffered in recent years by the populations of the Middle East, a regional polarization. And not only that, but unenclusive institutions for, moreover, normally multi-ethnic countries. What we are calling for — and what the European Union has also tried over the last few years — is: one, to support the pieces that the international community puts in place to stabilize the area; the iran nuclear deal is an example; two, to ask Iraq to hold accountable those who have been suppressing the protests and provoked dead in the streets; and three, in the case of Lebanon, please support a country that is hosting many refugees, and which has very serious financial and economic problems.

name: María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos (Renew).
text: – Madam President. Mrs Mogherini, thank you very much for your work, effort and dedication during these years. The protests that run through the region are protests in which citizens call for more freedom, more democracy, more social rights. In Iran these revolts have been repressed with enormous harshness, with the use of firearms against civilians.  Amnesty International tells us that there are dozens, hundreds of dead, four thousand injured, ten thousand arrested, although there has been a closure of information in the country, a digital closure. Again, the authorities have also put pressure on women. They're being placed in a red circle saying they're responsible and agitating for these riots. We therefore call on the Commission and the international community to clearly condemn these facts, to ask the Iranian authorities to stop the repression and to make a clear appeal to political and democratic dialogue.

name: Lars Patrick Berg (ID).
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has I shall confine my remarks to the situation in Lebanon. We have all seen how the current crisis has developed as a matter of the resignation of the Lebanese Government in the face of public protests and the inability of political leaders to form a new government. Behind it all is Hezbollah, an organization classified as terrorist, and Hezbollah is sponsored by the Iranian government. Lebanon has long suffered from outside interference and has become a battleground for competing interest groups. Hezbollah acts as Iran's proxy and continues to destabilize Lebanon's already fragile institutions through its terror. Hezbollah and the Amal movement are attacking anti-government demonstrators in Beirut, trying to ensure that Iran's influence continues. Israel has said it will not tolerate further attacks by Hezbollah on its territory. Hezbollah is acting at the instigation of Iran. It must be in our interest that this does not happen any further. We cannot allow Lebanon to once again become a battlefield.

name: Andreas Schieder (S&D).
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by thanking you in particular for the many initiatives and for your successful work, particularly as regards the attempt to reach an agreement with Iran. But we have received harrowing images of Iran in recent days: demonstrations and unrest, because the economic, social and political-democratic situation has become intolerable for the population. The brutal reaction of the Iranian regime – hundreds of dead, thousands of prisoners – shows how inhumane this regime is. The Iranian Government must respect human rights, freedom of expression, freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, freedom of demonstration, freedom of information and also the free Internet. But there is also a need for de-escalation, and it also needs a return to the negotiating table in foreign policy. The crisis must be defused and no more oil should be poured into the fire, as the American President, for example, is doing.

name: Елена Йончева (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I express my concern at the tension sparked by the situation in the Middle East region. Coming from Bulgaria, one of the first border states of the European Union on the path of refugee flows, I would like to draw the European Parliament's attention that the escalation of tensions poses a real threat of a new refugee wave to Europe. I see a danger in the Turkish state's intentions to displace over 2 million people. Arab refugees in kurdish areas of northern Syria, where a Turkish army operation is currently under way. I believe that such resettlement should only be carried out at the free will of refugees. It should not come at the expense of the indigenous Kurdish population.  A change in the ethnic map in the region, especially in the case of undetermined peace in Syria, poses a great risk to a new and long-lasting refugee wave, this time from Kurdish refugees to European Union member states. I therefore call on the European Parliament to propose an international monitoring mechanism for transparency and process control.

name: Eero Heinäluoma (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is indeed very sad to see every single day what is happening in the Middle East at the moment. People are still dying in Syria. Human rights are seriously violated in Iran, and iraq too is again having considerable problems in respecting human rights. The democratic rights of demonstrators are being cured and violence is being used against dissidents. We have seen all this since the US-led invasion of Iraq contributed to the great instability throughout the region and triggered a spiral of violence that has still not been broken. The European Union must be clear in its opinions and support human rights and the strengthening of democracy. But patience is required. There are no quick wins.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Tehran, Beirut and Baghdad are three painful points on the world map at the moment and, instead of bread and democracy, people are receiving bullets and violence. I am saddened that there are colleagues of mine, doctors, who are dying at the moment while defending their patients. But do we, the European Parliament, have done enough so far? And there is a need for an international mechanism for intervention, transparency and protection of those who are suffering at the moment. And, High Commissioner, I have a question: what measures do you leave to the next committee so that such things do not happen again and, if possible, tell me whether there is a certain deadline for them to be implemented.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would first like to start by thanking Mrs Mogherini for her work throughout the period. We have also debated the situation in the Middle East many times here, and I will admit that we did not quite agree on this subject. I believe that our policy towards the Iranian regime has been too positive, too idealistic, and now it is proving that it will be up to the new Commission to assess how tough we need to be in this area. The demands of the people of the Middle East are perfectly legitimate, the social conditions are appalling, huge corruption, a slightly different regime in each state, but I believe that the biggest problem is in the Iranian regime. The new Commission will need to rethink whether we should take a little harder on the Iranian regime and whether we should make it clear that the Iranian regime is now, unfortunately, a source of destabilisation in the Middle East and a source of human rights suppression. On the other hand, we must do everything we can to ensure that islamists do not take advantage of this chance and do not further intensify in this area.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Mogherini, on this day when we voted extensively with the Von der Leyen Commission, I join in the recognition of your work during these five years — which has been very hard — and your record in this European Parliament at this late hour, debating the situation in three Countries in the Middle East with very little in common with each other , except for instability and protests. Lebanon owes much of its instability to Iranian intrusion in recent years. And between Iraq and Iran there was a very bloody war. The most worrying situation from afar is that of Iran, exactly because it lasts the longest; because it is the one that has become most repressively incarnate against women; because it is the one that yields a greater balance of death sentences executed; and because in recent protests sheds an also unacceptable balance of death: about a hundred deaths, including that of Nikta Esfandani, just a 14-year-old girl.  As reported by all international organizations, the use of force is not only disproportionate but systematic, to brutally suppress all dissent, and that is simply unacceptable. We support the nuclear agreement, but we cannot be silent in the face of this systematic brutality of the Iranian regime.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we really just can’t stand by and ignore what is happening in Iran. Both the EU and the international community has got to absolutely denounce the intentional lethal use of force by the Revolutionary Guards, the Iranian police and the plainclothes agents of the Iranian regime. The deaths of some 143 people have been carefully documented by Amnesty International, but they believe that the death toll is significantly higher. Most of those who have been killed have been shot – like Nikta Esfandiari. She was 14 years old. She was shot in the head. Her family searched for her for three days before they were given her body by the officials of the regime. Our response so far has been woefully inadequate. We have got to demand that the leaders of the regime face justice for their crimes. There must be no joint commission with Iran while the Iranian regime is perpetrating crimes against humanity.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I was actually very glad to hear Ms Mogherini talk about Europe’s continued opposition to the unilateral withdrawal of the US from the Iranian nuclear deal and the efforts to attempt to salvage that programme. But I think we have to go further and we have to acknowledge that the imposition of sanctions to coerce Iran has caused immense hardship on Iranian citizens and the poor and the vulnerable in particular – the very people that we are protesting that we need to defend.  We now have the spectacle of the US attempting to exploit the legitimate and authentic protests in Iraq and Lebanon in order to target Iran. I think we should be very careful not to fall for that trap. Mike Pompeo says the protests are caused by Iranian corruption. These are real people, with real problems: corruption, under—development, a wrecked economy. The Iraqis are still dealing with the after—effects of the Iraq war. We should not allow ourselves to fall into the trap of US manipulation. We must work for stability in Iran and Iraq and Lebanon, and peace in Syria and Yemen and oppose the US—Saudi attempts to isolate Iran.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I too found Ms Mogherini’s contribution on Iran more balanced than a lot of the others I heard in here tonight. But the particulars and differences of the unfolding events in Iran, Iraq and Lebanon are huge. That being said, there is something that these countries have in common. They’ve all suffered from relentless foreign interference in their affairs, regime change, wars, civil wars, long-standing economic sanctions, and the pillage of natural and public resources by politicians, bankers, billionaires and global corporations. There are people dying in these different countries. Any killing of peaceful protesters by Iranian police has to be condemned by us. Obviously, it doesn’t help matters that some foreign entities are funding opposition groups inside Iran in order to destabilise the government. We should also condemn any deaths of protesters in Iraq and Lebanon. Likewise, we should condemn the death of protesters in Bolivia and Iran. Let’s keep it even.

name: Matthew Patten (NI).
text: – Madam President, I deplore the recent deaths and human rights violations in Iran and the continued imprisonment of political prisoners like Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who should be freed immediately. But the number-one policy aim in Iran is to stop it building a nuclear weapon, but it is now restarting uranium enrichment. While I support the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) nuclear agreement, I think we have to brace ourselves for its failure and urgently look for a plan B. The EU is not blameless for this mess. The Instrument for Supporting Trade Exchange (INSTEX), its plan to circumvent US sanctions, has come up short. As a result, Iran is now threatening reprisals against the EU and its Member States. It must be right that a coalition of Member States and other global players is part of that solution, but only the active involvement of the US will help. Many people in this Parliament deny President Trump, but if we want to keep the Middle East nuclear-free, resume trade and support the human rights of Iranians, we urgently need to restore friendships and influence in Washington, not Tehran. I’m certain that Britain’s special relationship with the US can help.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I have seen that the majority of interventions tonight on this topic confirm and encourage the approach that I described at the beginning of this debate. Thank you for that.  Let me just answer specifically one question that was asked, even if I don’t see the Member of Parliament present in the room – but I am sure that she will be watching us carefully from her office. She was inviting the European Union to finance some concrete projects in the Middle East and she mentioned, in particular, the case of Iraq.  Just as an example, to name the numbers, just for Iraq specifically, we have been financing concrete projects and that means demining, that means job creation, that means reconciliation – projects that exist and that we visit constantly, at my level, at the level of our delegation on the ground. I’m sure some of you have visited as well some of these projects we finance in the Middle East. Just for Iraq in the last years: EUR 1.25 billion of concrete projects just for Iraq. That is to say that this is not just diplomacy – even though diplomacy in this particular time of global politics is a valuable element, and sometimes I believe we underestimate the power of our diplomatic engagement. But it’s not just diplomacy. It’s also about supporting very concretely the projects that help people on a daily basis. Many of you have said it’s real people, it’s real people with real needs. It’s children, women and men that have faced difficulties not just for years, but sometimes for decades, and that live under very difficult situations in security terms, in economic terms.  The European Union and the European institutions are also financing those concrete projects that are literally life—saving projects for millions of people. I would have expected that members of the European Parliament would know this. So if I can invite you to document yourself, at least on the projects you agree on financing in these areas, I think this would be a service to the way in which you can represent your constituencies.  Having said that, let me say clearly that obviously I cannot state – and it would not be appropriate for me to indicate – what the position of the next Commission and the next High Representative will be on this. It is obviously for them to shape it, together with the Council, but let me say that I hope and I believe that the European Union, with your support, will have to be – even more so in the future – a fundamental partner for the people of the region, because sometimes we don’t realise how important the role we play is. Whenever you visit you hear from your interlocutors, and not only the governments or institutions, but the people, civil society and simple citizens that are the key of democracy, that they count on us. Sometimes I have the impression that they recognise our role much more than Europeans do.  So I think that the road ahead will have to be investing even more in economic and diplomatic but also security terms, in supporting this region in finding its way to a sustainable peace and sustainable security. And obviously, as many all of you have said, and as I’ve said in the beginning, with the firmest rejection of any form of violence and disproportionate reaction and handling of the protests from the authorities. This is clearly unacceptable. And this is exactly why, for instance in Iraq, we are engaged in the security sector reform system, because we see the need for a reform – otherwise we wouldn’t be engaging in that respect. We see the need to change and improve the way in which the institutions can handle the security situations of the country, and many other situations. So again, I hope I that this Parliament will give all its support to an even further engagement and work of the European Union institutions in the Middle East.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: I close the debate.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: The next item is the debate: – on the oral question to the Council by TomasTobé, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the ongoing negotiations on a new EU-ACP Partnership Agreement (O-000035/2019 - B9-0057/201 (9) and the oral question to the Commission by Tomas Tobé, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the ongoing negotiations on a new EU-ACP Partnership Agreement (O-000036/2019 - B9-0058/2019). I would like to remind you, speaking from the chamber and in the blue card procedure, you can apply both traditionally and in the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance to the plenary chamber.

name: Tomas Tobé
text: author. – Madam President, the Cotonou Agreement between the European Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States is the most comprehensive partnership agreement which the EU has concluded to date. The Cotonou Agreement covers cooperation with nearly 80 countries worldwide and it covers a wide set of policy areas. In these times, times of increasing global uncertainty, we, the European Union, must defend and promote multilateralism, global cooperation and a rule-based world order.
