These are all core values of our European Union. The Cotonou Agreement expires in February next year. Negotiations for the next agreement have already started. Prior to that, Parliament has outlined what we want to see in the new agreement. Parliament’s consent will be required once the negotiations are concluded. So far, the ACP and the EU have agreed that the foundation of the future partnership shall focus on key values and principles and on overarching priorities. Attached to the foundation agreement, three regional partnership protocols will detail cooperation priorities tailored to the regions’ specificities. It is agreed that the foundation and the regional partnerships will be one legally binding instrument. The latter was not a given when the first discussions with EU Member States started, but it was one of Parliament’s key demands. But in today’s debate we need more clarity and we also need the new resolution, because some of Parliament’s key concerns have not been addressed. On behalf of the Committee on Development, I have therefore tabled questions to the Council and to the Commission. We would like to hear clear answers to them today. We believe that these questions will provide guidance to the incoming Commissioner. The first question is: where do we actually stand on the key demand of Parliament that the new agreement should reinforce the parliamentary dimension at ACP level? I would like to make clear that the European Parliament cannot accept that the executive level of government might have no parliamentary counterpart: that there will be a Joint Council of Ministers, a Joint Committee, but no parliamentary meetings. We agree with a reinforcement of parliamentary cooperation at the level of the three regional pillars, but this is not sufficient. We don’t want to lose the benefits of peer-to-peer discussions at ACP level. Another important issue, and also on behalf of the Committee on Development: where do the Council and the Commission and the ACP stand when it comes to reinforcing provisions to combat discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity and to ensure that sexual and reproductive health and rights are integrated and supported through the new agreement? These are key values of the European Union, and we need to make sure that this will also be within the agreement. Another important question is about civil society. We know that in some countries this is of very serious concern, and we want to see an increased role for civil society. This needs to be recognisable in the agreement and also at ACP-EU levels. Last, but not least, Parliament clearly stated that the new agreement should provide for a peer-review mechanism for monitoring progress as well as gaps in implementing the Sustainable Development Goals on a regular basis. We need more clarity on which way this will be integrated into the next agreement. Before I end with a very clear message from the European Parliament, I would like to thank Commissioner Mimica for all your hard work. You have worked very hard with the European Parliament and we are really thankful for the cooperation so far, and also with the Council. We now count on the Commission and the Council to be champions of our demands in the coming weeks and the coming months and to provide answers also today; hopefully clear answers.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it’s a pleasure to address this House on the ongoing negotiations for the future agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) and the European Union. This is indeed a very timely discussion. Post—Cotonou continues to be a key file for the Council. Negotiations are ongoing and until now five negotiation rounds took place at political level, the latest one in September in New York. The next meeting of the chief negotiators is foreseen to take place in December. Both parties agree that the future development cooperation framework should be based on the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement on climate change and must reflect and adapt to the changing global context, new challenges and opportunities. The ambitions are high on both sides to use the relationship for joint positions in international fora. The EU shares the ambition of the ACP—EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and the European Parliament to strengthen the parliamentary dimension. Our EU negotiating directives clearly stipulate that the parties shall pursue an inclusive and open multi—stakeholder approach, including by strengthening the role of national parliaments, local authorities, civil society and the private sector. These directives aim to strengthen regular political dialogue at all levels, enabling the active engagement of a wide variety of actors, including civil society, in dialogue and cooperation processes. They also aim to strengthen the role of civil society and the private sector as the key partners in realising the objectives of the partnership. The negotiations on migration issues are ongoing. The EU’s aim is to arrive at a more operational text compared to the Cotonou Agreement. The EU negotiation mandate also stipulates that all elements of migration cooperation would be addressed in the regular political dialogue, which would ensure regular discussions with our partners on this important topic.  Economic partnership agreements help regional economic communities by providing necessary expertise, technology and experience for trade integration. They are tools to enhance trade and investment, value addition and industrialisation, and economic integration. The work done so far on these agreements should inspire the future trade arrangements between the ACP and the EU. The EU negotiating directives are very clear when it comes to non—discrimination based on sexual orientation and sexual and reproductive health and rights. They aim to commit the parties to the promotion, protection and fulfilment of the right of every individual to have full control over and decide freely and responsibly on matters related to their sexuality and sexual and reproductive health, free from discrimination, coercion and violence. The EU aims for an agreement that ensures universal access to quality and affordable comprehensive sexual and reproductive health information, education, including comprehensive sexuality education and healthcare services.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Chair, Mr Tobé, and all the members of the Committee on Development for their excellent work and for the close collaboration between our respective institutions on this important file. I welcome your resolutions and the questions on the ongoing negotiations on the renewed partnership agreement between the European Union and the countries of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States.  The negotiations are progressing, I would say, at moderate pace. As chief negotiator, I have to be realistic. When the Cotonou Agreement expires on 29 February next year, the negotiations will not have sufficiently advanced and there will be a need to have transitional measures in place. Therefore, I am glad that the Council has adopted a decision supporting the extension of the Cotonou Agreement until 31 December 2020. This way, a solid legal basis can remain in place during the transition period. The EU-ACP Committee of Ambassadors will take the final joint decision by the end of January 2020 at the latest.  At this advanced stage of the negotiations I appreciate that Parliament wishes to reiterate the core elements formulated in the two earlier resolutions of October 2016 and June 2018. Your opinion has been heard. You have one key demand: the strengthening of the parliamentary dimension, including at the EU-ACP level. I strongly believe that the role of Parliament should be enforced in the future agreement. However, in line with the negotiation directives from the Council, I also believe that this can best take place at the level of the regional protocols and less so at the level of the EU—ACP. Nevertheless, the Commission takes note of the recommendation formulated by Parliament on this heading.  I would also like to recall that the recommendation by the Commission to the Council of December 2017 included the proposal that the three regional parliamentary configurations could be brought into one on specific occasions. Eventually, that proposal did not become part of the Council’s negotiation directives. Honourable Members, I welcome your question on political dialogue. We have put forward to our ACP partners a proposal for comprehensive dialogue covering all objectives, priorities and policy areas. I also welcome your concern for a genuine multi—actor partnership. The EU has a clear position: we are seeking from all parties a commitment to facilitate the active engagement of a wide variety of actors in dialogue and cooperation processes.  Concerning your call for reinforcing provisions to fight against discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity, and for upholding sexual and reproductive health and rights, I can say that we are aligned on this but I note that our proposals to the ACP side have not received a positive feedback and further negotiation is required. So far, we have a bracketed part of this paragraph. On migration, the Commission appreciates the concern of Parliament. The European Union and the ACP are currently negotiating a balanced text seeking a substantial compromise between the negotiation interests of both parties. Concerning the economic partnership agreements, I would like to recall that these are self—standing international agreements. However, the post—Cotonou Agreement will provide a coherent framework for cooperation with ACP States, linking all negotiated and future EPAs to respect for essential and fundamental elements.  Lastly, honourable Members, your question on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) is welcome. It gives me the opportunity to recall that the UN Agenda 2030 will frame the future ACP—EU partnership agreement. Our comprehensive dialogue with the ACP partners and a multi—actor approach will be essential to put in place the conditions and instruments for regular monitoring and implementation of the SDGs.

name: György Hölvényi
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Colleagues, Without cooperation between the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries and the Union, it is inconceivable that challenges such as migration, climate change, contribution to education, access and security could be overcome.  The Cotonu Agreement, which is still in force, offers a framework for cooperation to address these challenges. The possible delay in the entry into force of the new convention simply puts Europe at a competitive disadvantage. Europe can only be interested in reducing the effects of emigration in developing countries, strengthening democratisation processes and security.  Education and vocational training are the most important elements of the development of cooperation. Allow me to draw attention to something special in this. Cooperation with Ecclesiastical organisations is almost essential for ACCS countries, but is now almost zero. Note that, according to World Bank data, 50% of health and education care in sub-Saharan Africa is provided by religious organisations. Accordingly, it is very important that our development partners include Church organizations.  In the new solution – the Commission needs a solution – in the new agreement, the Commission must find a solution to address the root causes of migration, or at least try to do so. As Commissioner Urpilainen said during her hearing, we must focus on tressoning the root causes in the coming years. We expect an agreement that settles the readmission of migrants more effectively than before, sees remaining in the homeland, security, quality education and the strengthening of decent work locally as a strategic objective.  For these purposes, from 2021 we need to use the NDICI, which, on the basis of a proposal from the Commission, may also include the EDF, the most important source of development contributions to the ACCS countries. We need to be clear about how the Commission plans to establish a link between the Post-Cotonu Agreement and the NDICI. We must take into account the specific needs of the ACCS countries, treating them as equal partners.  In conclusion, we expect an agreement from the Commission to help us stay in place and return to migration, to take into account the specific characteristics of the different ACCS countries and to strengthen the Role of the European Parliament in ACCS-EU cooperation. Thank you for listening.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the debate raised by the Committee on Development on the negotiations for a new ACP-European Union agreement is very timely, and I welcome your President on the initiative. And as has been said here, the European Parliament has over time expressed very clear positions on the objectives and mechanisms for implementing the future agreement. A position which, moreover, was reflected and shared last week in Quigali, Rwanda, where the 30th Joint Parliamentary Assembly took place, to which I co-chaired on behalf of the European Parliament. And from that meeting, among more than 100 countries representing nearly two billion people, a strong consensus emerged, a consensus to fulfill the timings and mandates to be able to close the agreement in November 2020, translating a robust partnership between equals, inspired by the Millennium Agenda. But also a consensus that a flexible vision will prevail to reconcile a shared framework for sustainable development within the ACP-European Union relationship, but also with sub-regional economic and trade partnerships, and in particular with the European Union-African Union partnership. And finally, a consensus to rationalise and strengthen the parliamentary dimension of the agreement as part of our differentiating matrix in an increasingly competitive geopolitical context in which we have to know how to make a difference. I am aware that talking about the Cotonou Agreement or the agreement that will succeed it says very little to most Europeans. But if we make it clear how decisive it is to deal with certification, climate change, forced migration, conflicts generated by the exploitation of endemic poverty and the fragility of the institutions, we will be able to show that a good design, a good implementation of the agreement, is good for the peoples of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, the European Union and humanity in general. And then we will have the majority of Europeans with us and we will be stronger as the European Union.  I would like to take advantage of the last few seconds of my speech to greet and congratulate the Commissioner on his excellent work.

name: Chrysoula Zacharopoulou
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, deep down, we all know in this room that our destinies, those of the ACP countries and the European Union, are linked and that they will be even more so tomorrow. Only together can we provide the answers to global challenges, starting with the management of the climate crisis and the biodiversity crisis. Our friends in the ACP countries are sounding the alarm because the consequences of climate change are jeopardizing their survival. The European Union's support for adaptation to climate change is essential if we are to act before it is too late. Another major challenge is the fight against poaching and wildlife trafficking, which must be a priority to save biodiversity. Secondly, I would like to recall the role of youth and women. African youth, in particular, depends absolutely on the fate of a continent in transition. The European Union and the ACP countries will need to build bridges between their young people in the field of education, entrepreneurship and academic and cultural exchanges. This will allow them to build their common future but also gender equality, women's empowerment, education, including their sex and reproductive education, which are essential. Unlocking the feminine potential is the best bet we can make for the future. Commissioner, after more than 60 years of partnership and with new players on the international cooperation scene, the European Union cannot do without its historic allies. In Kigali, we saw that our partners in the ACP countries wanted a real partnership. I too, as a European, want this true partnership. We have everything in our hand to build a new relationship, based more and more on cooperation and mutual respect.

name: Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, the new European Union-ACP agreement will be an opportunity to forge partnership relations on an equal footing, based on a genuine partnership and not on a paternalistic relationship. It will depend on the outcome of the negotiations, which is already proving problematic. Indeed, with the opening of free trade, many ACP countries are not able to compete with the cheap products of the European Union that flood the Sahel countries in Africa. Let's illustrate our point with the example of powdered milk from Europe sold on African markets. This milk defies all competition with local milk. In addition, migration is the current issue of concern to both the European Union and the ACP countries. However, we must ensure that development funds are not linked to the draconian measures of the European Union's migration policy, which has become a double-edged sword. It allowed racists to turn on the sirens of fear and thus conceal their hatred and xenophobia under the guise of lack of security. On the contrary, we must seek to adjust our priorities to that of our partners - the elimination of poverty, education and vocational training, the promotion of legal migration and the possibility of a return to the country of origin followed by voluntary reintegration - in order to reach a genuine agreement that corresponds to the sustainable development goals. We must not condition development aid by erecting too high barriers to climate, migration and security. Promoting such a policy is contradictory to the values of the European Union and to the principles that govern relations between partners. Imposing this kind of policy on ACP countries is in many ways comparable to a neo-colonialist policy. We must have hooked atoms with our partners for a partnership that reflects the aspirations of both the European Union and the ACP countries.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, at a time when, from China to Russia, all have seen the potential of Africa as a continent of the 21st century, the European Union, for its part, is approaching these negotiations in a weak position, not only because nothing has been planned to compensate for the departure of the United Kingdom, a financial contributor and major diplomatic actor. , but because we can only see the failure of Cotonou. Failure is primarily political, since neither multilateral dialogue, embodied by institutions that have struggled to produce any concrete results, nor binding instruments have been successful. The failure then concerns immigration, since, even though Article 13 has been ineffective, this resolution is locked in the rejection of any conditioning of aid to control migration flows by the countries of origin, which should be, on the contrary, one of our first requirements. Finally, on the economic front, the indigent progress report, revealed last week, of the pact with Africa, launched by Germany, is yet another blow in the water in terms of reviving private investment. The same will be true of its global framework of action, pompously dubbed the Marshall Plan for Africa. How could it be otherwise when basic material conditions are not guaranteed? In the Sahel, the tragic disappearance of thirteen of my compatriots is a reminder that, against Islamic terrorism, French soldiers are fighting alone. While so many international commitments have not been kept on the ground, indifference is paid for at the cost of blood.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, a year ago the European Parliament approved the negotiations for a new agreement between the European Union and the seventy-eight countries of the Association of African, Caribbean and Pacific States. This negotiation integrated into its initial text the need to face challenges such as the climate crisis. It gave greater prominence to civil society and strengthened parliamentary control of the agreement. We do not understand how a month ago, in the Committee on Development, the text of this agreement was mostly endorsed, but now the People's Party Group is threatening to undermine the agreement. What do the People's Party Group and the far right want? They said this loud and clear in the previous intervention: to make development aid conditional on immigration control, which, in practice, is in many places assuming systematic violations of human rights. Too many barbarities we have seen in recent years with the use of European Union development aid funds and for now continue to have an influence on conditioning development aid on migration control. This, ladies and gentlemen, is not only infamous and neocolonial, but it is also – and it must be said loud and clear - it breaches all international protocols. Let's not make that mistake tomorrow, ladies and gentlemen. Let us bet on a development policy that is not at the service of the 'Fortress Europe', which does not respond to the interests of the far right but is at the service of the peoples and the planet. Your vote will depend on what you decide, it will depend on being in people's service or being against people. You decide.

name: Álvaro Amaro (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this debate is being discussed in good time and this post-Cotonou partnership agreement and the future of the path we have started together with our partner countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific in Lomé in 1975 are discussed with the Commission and the Council. It is never too much to remember that this agreement has three fundamental objectives: reducing poverty and in the long term to eradicate it, sustainable development and contributing to the progressive integration of ACP countries into the world economy. If these are your first, and post-Cotonou, objectives, you have to reassume these commitments. The Commission's negotiating mandate says exactly this: the agreement will be based on and strengthen the fundamental values and principles of this agreement which ends now next year. This is therefore the first idea I would like to leave in a current scenario where concrete measures need to be taken to promote and enforce human rights or defend democracy, economic growth and investment, combat climate change, promote peace and security, and act in terms of mobility and migration. The primary objective of eradicating poverty in line with the objectives of sustainable development should remain our ultimate goal. And on the future of the agreement I would like to leave three notes, not least because much has already been said in this debate. Firstly, the maintenance of the parliamentary dimension in the future acp-EU partnership. The resolution we will vote on tomorrow underlines this very well, reiterating the importance of strengthening this parliamentary dimension, i.e. the future institutional framework should include an ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, and as our Co-Presidents of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly have done, and I greet my colleague Carlos Zorrinho in Quigali in his joint statement, and of course the Chairman of the Development Committee on this subject , I also believe that this claim should not be negotiable in the context of the adoption of the future agreement by the European Parliament. Secondly, to defend multilateralism as the only truly effective path to lasting peace, economic prosperity and sustainable development. We will only be able to implement in practice on a truly effective scale the ambitious goals of sustainable development if we do so through the various existing global forums, and with this partnership ours this could act as a lever for common positions. We should also spread our ideals and principles to the people in these forums, as that saying goes very well: we alone can go faster, but together we will surely go further. Thirdly and lastly I would like to underline something that is little talked about, and that is the importance of parliamentary diplomacy for stimulating institutional rapprochement in multilateral terms, both at the level of parliaments, governments, regional or local powers and, of course, public administrations, and also, finally, i will add greater involvement of civil society in the political process to encourage the holding of various types of events.  Parliamentary diplomacy also contributes, and I end up, Madam President, in spreading the fundamental values that we stand for, in particular human rights.

name: Monica Semedo (Renew).
text: – Madam President, last week I had the honour of attending the 38th ACP-EU Joint Assembly in Kigali, Rwanda, and I had many fruitful conversations with my ACP colleagues who expressed their regret and concern that the post-Cotonou negotiations are taking longer than anticipated. We agreed that the greatest future potential of the ACP countries lies with the youth, and we should promote it now. Young citizens have innovative ideas for shaping the future relations between the ACP and the EU. Therefore, my question is, have youth organisations and associations been involved in the consultation on the post-Cotonou negotiations? If so, at what level and, if not, given that the negotiations are still ongoing, would you consider including their voices?

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we are at an important moment in time. The new treaty between the EU and the ACP countries will consolidate and give new impetus to our strong partnership and we are happy to learn that we are approaching the final stage of concluding a treaty. However, there are still some problem issues, and they seem to concentrate on the issue of migration and mobility, and this is why I focus on this issue. The treaty is based on the principle of equality and shared responsibility. But if you look at the EU text proposal, it applies very concrete requirements on the ACP countries, such as readmission of migrants, strengthening border controls and combating irregular migration, whereas in exchange, the EU hardly offers any concrete commitment regarding legal migration. Adopting this text would deprive the countries of remittances and other benefits of migration, without any clear perspective on labour migration. This does not really resonate the equality of the partnership. Regarding shared responsibility, I find the only provision on refugees and international protection pretty meagre. Africa hosts so many more refugees than we do. Why don’t we see a stronger EU commitment to support the protection and reception of refugees through financial means or through resettlements? That would be shared responsibility, and also in line with the UN Global Compact on Refugees. The EU’s responsibility for refugees in Africa will even grow if this migration cooperation leads to more refugees stuck in transit countries without any access to asylum. So, if this paragraph is still in negotiation, please make sure that the EU also delivers on migration, mobility and international protection.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the relationship between the European Union and the ACP countries – Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific – must be guided by genuine development cooperation which is distancing itself from interest-growing views and neocolonial cutting practices, and which is respectful of the sovereignty of these countries. The future framework for cooperation must recognise and preserve the integrity and unity of the ACP bloc. We therefore reject attempts to divide to reinthat have already been made in the imposition by the European Union of so-called economic partnership agreements against the will of the ACP countries, and are again visible in the negotiation of the future partnership. Contrary to ways that accentuate the dependence and subordination of ACP countries, it is necessary to stimulate the diversification of their economic base, strengthen their production systems, stimulating their autonomy and coherence, promote the development of public services, invest in health, education, sanitation and water supply, housing and better use of the endogenous potential of each country.  The role of the European Development Fund needs to be strengthened by strengthening its appropriations and aligning it with these priorities, rejecting any logic of conditionality on the acceptance of Eu policies, in particular in the field of migration. It is necessary to break with the logic of structural adjustment policies, with free trade and with the permanent attempts to export neoliberal models that have proved disastrous. The cancellation of the debt of the least developed countries, and I will end, Madam President, is a question of justice that would allow additional resources to be channelled into development. This was approved at the recent Joint Parliamentary Assembly in Quigali, Rwanda, and we did not want to fail to value it here.

name: Pietro Bartolo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are still many questions that remain open about the negotiations for a new partnership agreement between Europe and the ACP group. Sustainable growth and poverty reduction, the rule of law and democracy, economic and cultural development, migration management and climate change: these are the crucial issues to be relaunched within the framework of joint enhanced cooperation after 2020. The Cotonou Agreement has enabled us to take the paths of dialogue and cooperation, and in recent years the results achieved have been important, but let us be honest, they are not significant. We are still light years away from the objectives of reducing and eliminating poverty, as well as integrating the ACP countries into the world economy. Let us therefore continue along our path of open, democratic and global parliamentary dialogue and never lose sight of respect for human rights and democratic principles and the rule of law, which must remain the basis of our cooperation.

name: Marie-Pierre Vedrenne (Renew).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the future of our relations after February 2020 and the expiry of the Cotonou agreement were at the heart of our discussions last week in Kigali. As Vice-President of the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly, I deeply regret that this multilateral framework, for which we are all deeply committed here, is threatened by these negotiations. A genuine win-win partnership with the ACP will only emerge with the maintenance and strengthening of the parliamentary dimension. If it is true that the functioning of this assembly must be reformed in order to become more effective, removing it would be a counter-attack. Protecting human rights, the rule of law, sustainable development goals and combating climate change are all themes that will find solutions if we act together, and parliamentary diplomacy is the vehicle for real progress. For example, in Kigali, we have adopted a common approach for COP 25, which will be held in Madrid in a few days. In this sense, I would like to reiterate my call on the European Commission to make the Paris Agreement an essential element of this future partnership.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to raise and really emphasise four important messages to the Commission and the Member States. 1. Ensure that the agreement is firmly anchored in the UN's global sustainability goals and strengthen the issues of respect for human rights, democracy, fundamental freedoms, the rule of law and good governance. 2. It is important that future agreements play a greater role for civil society, and diversity must be a watchword for inclusion. It is extremely important in order to counteract the shrinking democratic space that we see around the world. 3. Gender equality and women's empowerment must permeate the whole agreement. Sexual and reproductive health and rights must be a priority. 4. Finally, we must not forget the question of fate: environmental and climate issues. We must all take joint responsibility if we want to ensure a planet to live on in the future. I hope that these messages will be included, and that you will work towards a broad, equal and more modern partnership that covers our common challenges and which can help combat poverty and inequalities.

name: Alex Agius Saliba (S&D).
text: – Sinjura President, minn meta ġie adottat il-Ftehim ta' Cotonou għoxrin sena beauty, id-dinja nbidlet b'mod mill-aktar sinifikanti. Għalhekk in-negozjati tagħna fil-Ftehim il-ġdid AKP-UE għandhom iwasslu kunsens politiku ambizzjuż u komprensiv illi javvanza żvilupp sostenibbli u inklużiv, u jiffoka fuq il-prijoritajiet imfassla, bħad-demokrazija u d-drittijiet tal-bniedem, it-tkabbir ekonomiku u l-investiment, it-tibdil fil-klima, il-qerda tal-faqar, il-pa大i u s-sigurtà, il-migrazzjoni u l-mobbiàlt. Barra minn hekk nixtieq ukoll nenfasizza l-importanza tat-tisħiħ tad-dimensjoni parlamentari tal-futur, fejn jeħtieġ illi tkun assigurata responsabbiltà democratics fil-livelli kollha. Għalhekk huwa essenzjali illi l-Assemblea Parlamentari Konġunta AKP-UE tkompli tiltaqa' darbtejn fis-sena fit-totalità tagħha fis-sessjoni plenarja u darba fis-sena f'kull waħda mit-tliet rejuġni. Ix-xhur li ġejjin se jkunu kru大jali hekk kif wasalna biex nidħlu f'era ġdida fir-relazzjoni tagħna mal-pajjiżi AKP, li se jippermettu wkoll l-iżviluppi ulterjuri għar-relazzjonijiet tagħna bħala "continent ma' kontinent" Afrikan.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the Partnership Agreement between the EU and ACP, known as the Cotonou Agreement, was signed in 2000 and will expire in February 2020. Negotiations for the successor to the agreement are still ongoing and we must remember why this partnership is important. It’s fostered key political dialogue, strengthening relations between us and the ACP countries via frameworks based on human rights, democracy and the rule of law. It’s allowed for important discussions on issues such as freedom from discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation or gender identity, and sex and relationship education, as well as provisions for corporate social responsibility and assistance to tackle tax evasion.  We must revitalise and reinforce the EU’s relations with the ACP countries. We must emphasise the importance of the parliamentary dimension of the future agreement in order to ensure democratic accountability at all levels and to promote the legitimacy and visibility of the partnership. We must also scale up the involvement of civil society and ensure any new agreement is rooted in the 2030 Agenda with a peer review mechanism for SDG implementation. The EU and the ACP are collectively a strong global voice and we can tackle shared challenges, and the new Partnership Agreement must reflect this.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Mimica, I greet you with appreciation in this last appearance in a plenary session of the European Parliament to discuss nothing less than the Agreement between the European Union and Africa-Caribbean-Pacific – seventy-eight countries - after twenty years of validity, and with Parliament's mandate to strengthen the character of civil society, commitment to values and parliamentary control.  But above all, we must keep alive this exercise of parliamentary diplomacy, which is an opportunity for horizontal dialogue to explain the European Union's gigantic efforts in cooperation and humanitarian aid, which must be true to its values. Under no circumstances should it be a tool or subterfuge for the policy of returns or control of emigrations, but it must be to exchange good experiences in human rights, to strengthen the rule of law, to integrate, to include, to combat all forms of discrimination and, of course, to enhance the role of women in Africa , the Caribbean and the Pacific. They are very different regions, but Africa is the great giant. Africa is the inexorable interlocutor of the European Union.  I encourage the Von der Leyen Commission, which has just received its endowment today, to bring this negotiation to fruition and to make Parliament's role in the relationship with Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific prevail.

name: Irena Joveva (Renew).
text: – Madam President! Last week, I had the privilege of being part of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly in Kigali, where I experienced what such a partnership agreement actually means.  It enables countries on different continents to integrate to resolve or improve the situation in common areas such as human rights, democracy, equality, peace and security, climate, environment and more.  We have before us a document that will have an impact on the development of future cooperation between the ACP countries and the EU, and it is therefore important that MEPs, as institutional actors involved, participate in this agreement in its creation.  The basis for the preparation of the new agreement is to build on the upgrade to be made so far, and the resolution calls for equal representation of the countries of Africa, the Caribbean, the Pacific and the EU countries, for greater involvement of civil society, political dialogue and for sustainable development. Only together can we achieve peaceful, stable, prosperous countries and societies.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, since the official launching of the negotiations on 28 September last year, the European Union and the ACP Group of States have gone a considerable distance in establishing our future partnership. Leading the negotiations for the EU has been an honour and a challenge for me. I believe we have made sufficient progress in a relatively short time. My successor, Jutta Urpilainen, will have a solid and comprehensive base upon which to conclude the negotiations with success.  I’m confident that already negotiated but bracketed parts of the future agreement, tabled differences in our respective positions and parts of the agreement that we still have to open and address do not constitute unsurmountable difficulties that could endanger final consent on the draft text of the post—Cotonou partnership agreement. This negotiation process is very much about the time needed to conclude an agreement, rather than about the lack of political will of the parties to have it concluded. The support and the engagement of Parliament all along this process are so important. I remain certain that Parliament will continue working to ensure a strong parliamentary dimension and will contribute to ensuring that the EU keeps on standing for its values in our partnership with ACP countries.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, post-Cotonou continues to be the key file for the Council. Let me assure you of that. I would like to also take the opportunity to thank Commissioner Mimica for his strong commitment to this work.  The EU welcomes the commitment of the African, Caribbean and Pacific region’s side to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement on climate change, as well as adapting the partnership to the changing global context, new challenges and the obvious opportunities that we also have.  We believe that the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement should facilitate reaching an agreement, even on the most difficult topics. Our Finnish Presidency will continue to pay the utmost attention to the ongoing negotiations and will seek to ensure that the Council contributes to the progress on this important dossier. Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen, for your important and valuable remarks.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 28 November 2019. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Janina Ochojska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Cotonou Agreement signed in 2000 is a pillar of the partnership between the EU, its Member States and the 79 ACP States. It aims to m.in poverty, guarantee the rule of law, promote the sustainable economic and social development of partner countries and gradually integrate their economies into the global economy. The global situation and new global challenges such as the migration crisis, terrorism and climate change have meant that the basic principles of the partnership must be redefined. Negotiations and work on the new shape of the agreement are protracted, but we must ensure that the legal and political foundations of the future EU-ACP agreement are sound and based on the principles of equality between partners and not on the existing recipient-donor relationship, which is not working.  It is also important to ensure that the three regional agreements based on other frameworks between the EU and Africa, the Pacific and the Caribbean separately do not distract from the main priorities of the partnership as a whole. I am therefore pleased that the achievement of the SDGs is recognised as a key element of the future agreement, and I agree that a mechanism must be created to ensure that the implementation of the Agreement effectively contributes to achieving and promoting these objectives.  I am of the opinion that the EU-ACP Joint Assembly plays a significant role in the democratic oversight of the future agreement and should maintain its position as a control and opinion body.
